(e)  Where the abatement action does not commence in the superior court, review of a court order requiring improvement, or demolition of a dwelling, building, or structure shall be by direct appeal to the superior court pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 5-3-29. 
(f)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
(Code 2005, § 10-124) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.  
Sec. 10-133. - Additional authority of licensing officer. 
The licensing officer is hereby authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purpose and provisions of this division and O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-10 and O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-12 through 41-2-17, including the following powers in addition to others granted in O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-10 and O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-12 through 41-2-17: 
(1)  Investigate the dwelling conditions in the unincorporated area of the city in order to determine which dwellings, buildings, or structures therein are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes, are vacant, or constitute an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions; 
(2)  Administer oaths and affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive evidence; 
(3)  Enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
(4)  Appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this division; and 
(5)  Delegate any of his functions and powers under this division to such officers and agents as he may designate. 
(Code 2005, § 10-125) 
State Law reference— Powers of public officers, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-11.  
Sec. 10-134. - Service of complaints. 
(a)  Complaints issued by the licensing officer pursuant to this division and under O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7 through 41-2-11 and O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-13 through 41-2-17 shall be served in the following manner. In all cases, a copy of the complaint and summons shall be conspicuously posted on the subject dwelling, building, or structure within three business days of filing of the complaint and at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. A copy of the complaint and summons shall be served in one of the following ways: 
(1)  Personal service upon each owner and party in interest if such parties are residents of the city. Service shall be perfected at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. Service may be made by the licensing officer designated by ordinance to abate nuisances or by any law enforcement officer of the city, and a return of service, filed with the clerk of the appropriate court, shall be deemed sufficient proof that service was perfected; 
(2)  Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 4, art. 5 (O.C.G.A. § 48-4-75 et seq.); or 
(3)  Statutory overnight delivery. 
(b)  If any owner or party in interest is a resident of this state but resides outside of the city, service shall be perfected by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, to the most recent address shown in appropriate tax filings and mailed at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(c)  Nonresidents of the state, whose mailing address is known, shall be served by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, mailed at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. For nonresidents whose mailing address is unknown, a notice stating the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements appear in the county once a week for two consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. 
(d)  If either the owner or any party in interest is a minor, an estate, an incompetent person, or person laboring under disabilities, the guardian or other personal representative of such person shall be served, and if such guardian or personal representative resides outside the county or is a nonresident of the state he shall be served as provided for in subsection (c) of this section. If such owner or party in interest has no guardian or personal representative, service shall be perfected by serving the judge of the probate court of the county at least 30 days prior to the date of the hearing, which judge shall stand in the place of and protect the rights of such minor, estate, or incompetent person or appoint a guardian ad litem for such person. 
(e)  In the event of unknown persons or unborn remaindermen who are likely to have any rights in the property or interest or the proceeds thereof, the judge of the probate court of the county shall be personally served at least 30 days prior to the date of the hearing, and it shall be the duty of the judge of the probate court to stand in the place of and protect the rights of such unknown parties or unborn remaindermen. 
(f)  If the whereabouts of any owner or party in interest is unknown and the whereabouts of such person cannot be ascertained by the licensing officer in the exercise of reasonable diligence, or if any owner or party in interest cannot, after due diligence, be served as provided in this section, the licensing officer shall make an affidavit to that effect and serve by publication in the manner provided in subsection (c) of this section, and such publication shall be sufficient proof that service was perfected. 
(g)  A notice of lis pendens shall be filed in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county at the time of filing the complaint in the appropriate court. Such notice shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. 
(h)  Orders and other filings made subsequent to service of the initial complaint shall be served in the manner provided in this division on the owner and any party in interest who answers the complaint or appears at the hearing. Any party who fails to answer or appear at the hearing shall be deemed to have waived all further notice in the proceedings. 
(Code 2005, § 10-126) 
State Law reference— Service of complaints, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12.  
Sec. 10-135. - Appeals. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13, any person affected by an order issued by the licensing officer may petition to the superior court for an injunction restraining the public officer from carrying out the provisions of the order and the court may, upon such petition, issue a temporary injunction restraining the public officer pending the final disposition of the cause; provided, however, that such person shall present such petition to the court within 15 days of the posting and service of the order of the public officer. De novo hearings shall be had by the court on petitions within 20 days. The court shall hear and determine the issues raised and shall enter such final order or decree as law and justice may require; provided, however, that it shall not be necessary to file bond in any amount before obtaining a temporary injunction under this division. 
(Code 2005, § 10-127) 
State Law reference— Injunction against order, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13.  
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 42. 
State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Fowl or livestock running at large prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner or person in control of any domestic fowl or livestock to allow that domestic fowl or livestock to run at large within the city. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-1; Code 2005, § 14-1) 
State Law reference— Livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-4 et seq.  
Sec. 14-2. - Impoundment of fowl or livestock running at large. 
(a)  Any fowl or livestock found running at large in violation of section 14-1 shall be impounded by any officer of the police department and transported to such facility as designated by the mayor and city council. 
(b)  The owner of any impounded animal, when known, shall be notified of such impoundment and of the proper steps necessary to secure release of the animal, including payment of such fees as fixed from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(c)  Animals impounded under this section shall be maintained for five days, at the end of which time they may be sold or otherwise disposed of in a humane manner, if not redeemed by their owner. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-2; Code 2005, § 14-2)  
Sec. 14-3. - Cleanliness of pens and enclosures. 
Any housing or enclosure used for the keeping of animals or fowl shall be well drained, free from accumulations of animal excrement and objectionable odors, and otherwise clean and sanitary. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-3; Code 2005, § 14-3)  
Sec. 14-4. - Minimum distance of hog pens from neighboring premises. 
The minimum distance a hog pen may be from any neighboring residence or business premises shall be 300 feet. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-4; Code 2005, § 14-4)  
Sec. 14-5. - Minimum distance of fowl from neighboring premises. 
It shall be unlawful to keep, pen or maintain upon one's premises, whether those premises are leased, owned or rented, any fowl of any kind or character within a distance of 150 feet of any property line of any of the adjoining property owners to the person maintaining and keeping the fowl. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-5; Code 2005, § 14-5)  
Secs. 14-6—14-28. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DOGS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-29. - Running at large prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having control of any dog to allow or permit the dog to run at large within the city. 
(b)  A dog is considered at large when it is not: 
(1)  Within a structure; 
(2)  Completely enclosed within a fence; or 
(3)  Securely attached to a leash or chain under the control of a responsible person. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-11; Code 2005, § 14-31)  
Sec. 14-30. - Collar and tag. 
Each dog four months of age and older shall wear a collar and tag at all times while in the city. The tag shall be issued by the county health department or a licensed veterinarian and shall show evidence of a current valid rabies inoculation. The owner or person in control of the dog shall be responsible for complying with this section. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-12; Code 2005, § 14-32) 
State Law reference— Removal of collar prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 16-9-71.  
Sec. 14-31. - Animal control board. 
The mayor and city council shall serve as an animal control board established for the purpose of enforcing the Dangerous Dog Control Law, provided that the mayor and city council may designate three persons to sit as an animal control board in their stead. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-15; Code 2005, § 14-33) 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-171 et seq.  
Sec. 14-32. - Dangerous and potentially dangerous dogs. 
(a)  No dangerous or potentially dangerous dog, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-21, shall be kept or maintained in the city without the owner first having complied with the requirements of the Dangerous Dog Control Law and having obtained a certificate of registration from the city. No certificate of registration shall be issued without payment of such fee as established from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(b)  Upon issuance of a certificate of registration the chief of police shall provide the dog owner with copies of the Dangerous Dog Control Law and this article. 
(c)  Any dog confiscated pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27 shall be kept at the impound facility designated by the mayor and city council for the statutorily prescribed period of time. A daily boarding fee, as fixed from time to time by the mayor and city council, shall be charged for each day the dog is housed at city expense. 
(d)  Failure to pay any fee assessed by the city for a certificate of registration or boarding of a confiscated dog shall be an offense and, upon conviction, shall be punishable as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3-16; Code 2005, § 14-34) 
State Law reference— Dangerous dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.  
Sec. 14-33. - Enforcement of article and Dangerous Dog Control Law. 
The police chief or his designee shall be responsible to enforce the provisions of this article and the Dangerous Dog Control Law. 
(Code 2005, § 14-35) 
State Law reference— Responsible Dog Ownership Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.  
Secs. 14-34—14-54. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT 
 
Sec. 14-55. - Authorized; notification of owner. 
(a)  The police chief or his designee, pursuant to section 14-33, shall impound all dogs found at large in violation of this division. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the police chief or his designee when impounding an animal to notify the owner of such action regarding the animal immediately upon impoundment. Such notice shall state the name and business address of the officer responsible for impounding the animal, the name and address of the agency having custody of the animal, a description of the animal, the reason why the animal was impounded, and a statement of the time limits for the owner to respond and request a hearing, as provided in section 14-57. 
(c)  The notice shall be provided by personal service or by registered mail, certified mail, or statutory overnight delivery sent to the last-known address of the owner. Service of the notice which complies with O.C.G.A. § 9-11-5(b) shall in all cases be sufficient. 
(d)  If the owner of such animal is unknown or cannot be found, service of the notice on the owner shall be made by posting the notice in a conspicuous place at the location where the animal was impounded and by publishing a notice once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county. 
(e)  An animal impounded pursuant to this division is deemed to be in the custody of the police chief, who is responsible for enforcement of this article within the city. 
(Code 2005, § 14-61) 
State Law reference— Impoundment of animal and notification, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-11-9.4, 4-11-9.5.  
Sec. 14-56. - Care of impounded animals; return of animal to owner. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any person impounding an animal under this division to make reasonable and proper arrangements to provide the impounded animal with humane care and adequate and necessary veterinary services. Such arrangements may include, but shall not be limited to, providing shelter and care for the animal at any state, federal, county, municipal, or governmental facility or shelter; contracting with a private individual, partnership, corporation, association, or other entity to provide humane care and adequate and necessary veterinary services for a reasonable fee; or allowing a private individual, partnership, corporation, association, or other entity to provide humane care and adequate and necessary veterinary services as a volunteer and at no cost. 
(b)  Any person impounding an animal under this division or providing care for an impounded animal shall have a lien on such animal for the reasonable costs of caring for such animal. Such lien may be foreclosed in any court that is competent to hear civil cases, including, but not limited to, magistrate courts. Liens shall be foreclosed in magistrate courts only when the amount of the lien does not exceed the jurisdictional limits established by law for such courts. 
(c)  The chief of police or his designee is authorized to return the animal to its owner, upon payment by the owner of all costs of impoundment and care and upon the entry of a consent order, unless such owner was, in a prior administrative or legal action in Georgia or any other state, found to have failed to provide humane care to an animal, committed cruelty to animals, or engaged in dog fighting in violation of the laws of this state or of the United States or any of the several states. Such consent order shall provide conditions relating to the care and treatment of such animal, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Such animal will be given humane care and adequate and necessary veterinary services; 
(2)  Such animal will not be subjected to cruelty; and 
(3)  The owner will comply with this article. 
(d)  The provisions of subsection (c) of this section shall not apply to an animal that was an object or instrumentality of a crime, nor shall any such animal be returned to the owner without the approval of the prosecuting attorney. The police chief or his designee having custody of an animal that was seized as an object or instrumentality of a crime may, with the consent of the prosecuting attorney, apply to the court having jurisdiction over the offense for an order authorizing the police chief to dispose of the animal prior to trial of the criminal case as provided by law. 
(Code 2005, § 14-62) 
State Law reference— Requirements for the care and disposition of impounded animals, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-9.3.  
Sec. 14-57. - Failure of owner to respond to notice; request for hearing. 
(a)  If the owner of an animal impounded pursuant to this division fails to respond in writing within five business days of the date the notice of impoundment was served, or if the owner is unknown or could not be found within 30 days of publication of the notice of impoundment, the impounded animal may be disposed of pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-11-9.6. 
(b)  If the owner of an animal impounded pursuant to this division refuses to enter into a consent agreement with the city that such animal will be given humane care and adequate and necessary veterinary care, the owner may request, in writing, a hearing within five business days of the date the notice of impoundment was served on such owner, or, if the owner is unknown or could not be found, within 30 days of the date of publication of the notice of impoundment. 
(1)  Such request for hearing shall be served upon the police chief or his designee having control of the animal. 
(2)  If no hearing is requested within the time limits specified in this subsection (b) and the failure to request such hearing is due in whole or in part to the reasonably avoidable fault of the owner, the right to a hearing shall have been waived. 
(Code 2005, § 14-63) 
State Law reference— Impoundment of animal and notification, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-11-9.4, 4-11-9.5.  
Sec. 14-58. - Hearing procedures. 
(a)  Within 30 days after receiving a written request for a hearing under this division, the city shall hold a hearing, as provided in O.C.G.A. tit. 50, ch. 13 (O.C.G.A. § 50-13-1 et seq.), the Georgia Administrative Procedures Act. The hearing shall be held before the animal control board. 
(b)  The hearing shall be public and all testimony shall be received under oath. 
(c)  A record of the proceedings at such hearing shall be made and maintained by the hearing officer as provided in O.C.G.A. § 50-13-13. 
(d)  The scope of the hearing shall be limited to whether the impounding of the animal was authorized by O.C.G.A. § 4-11-9.2(c). 
(e)  The hearing officer shall, within five business days after such hearing, forward a decision to the police chief or his designee who has custody of the animal. 
(f)  If the hearing officer finds that the animal was improperly impounded, the animal shall be returned to the owner and the cost incurred in providing reasonable care and treatment for the animal from the date of impoundment to the date of the order shall be paid by the city. 
(g)  If the hearing officer finds that the animal was lawfully impounded, the hearing officer may: 
(1)  Recommend that the police chief or his designee dispose of the animal as provided in section 14-59; or 
(2)  Unless, in a prior administrative or legal action in the state or any other state, the owner has been found to have failed to provide humane care to an animal, committed cruelty to animals, or engaged in dog fighting in violation of the laws of this state or of the United States or any of the several states, recommend conditions under which the animal may, upon payment by the owner of all costs of impoundment and care, be returned to the owner. Such conditions shall be reduced to writing and served upon the owner and the police chief or his designee. Such conditions may include, but are not limited to, the following: 
a.  Such animal will be given humane care and adequate and necessary veterinary services; 
b.  Such animal will not be subjected to mistreatment; and 
c.  The owner will comply with this article. 
(h)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to an animal that was an object or instrumentality of a crime, nor shall any such animal be returned to the owner or disposed of without the approval of the prosecuting attorney. 
(Code 2005, § 14-64) 
State Law reference— Impoundment of animal and notification, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-11-9.4, 4-11-9.5.  
Sec. 14-59. - Disposal of impounded animals. 
(a)  The police chief or his designee having custody of an animal impounded pursuant to this division which is not returned to the owner as provided in O.C.G.A. §§ 4-11-9.3 and 4-11-9.5 may: 
(1)  Dispose of the animal through sale by any commercially feasible means, at a public auction or by sealed bids; or 
(2)  If, in the opinion of a licensed accredited veterinarian or a veterinarian employed by the city, such animal has a temperament or condition such that euthanasia is the only reasonable course of action, humanely dispose of the animal. 
(b)  Any proceeds from the sale of such animal shall be used first to pay the costs associated with the impoundment, including, but not limited to, removal of the animal from the premises, shelter and care of the animal, notice, hearing, and disposition of the animal. Any funds remaining shall: 
(1)  If the owner is unknown or cannot be found, be paid into the city treasury; or 
(2)  If the owner is known, be paid to the owner. 
(c)  The police chief or his designee is responsible for conducting the sale and shall keep a record of all sales, disbursements, and distributions made under this division. 
(Code 2005, § 14-65) 
State Law reference— Disposition of impounded animals, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-9.6.  
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to establish building regulations for city, § 1.21. 
Cross reference— Registration of building and repair services during state of emergency, § 30-3; environment, ch. 42; failure to comply with order to repair or demolish structure, § 42-83; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; floods, ch. 50; planning and development, ch. 74; signs, ch. 78; solid waste, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 102; building sewers and connections, § 102-105 et seq.; zoning, ch. 106; building permit required, § 106-205; application for building permit, § 106-207. 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12). 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Technical codes adopted. 
(a)  The following codes as they now exist or as adopted by the state are hereby adopted by reference as though they were copied fully in this section (subsections (a)(1) through (9) of this section are mandatory): 
(1)  International Building Code: 2012 Edition. 
(2)  International Residential Code: 2012 Edition. 
(3)  International Plumbing Code: 2012 Edition. 
(4)  International Mechanical Code: 2012 Edition. 
(5)  International Fuel Gas Code: 2012 Edition. 
(6)  International Energy Conservation Code: 2009 Edition. 
(7)  International Fire Code: 2012 Edition. 
(8)  International Electrical Code: 2017 Edition. 
(9)  International Swimming Pool and Spa Code: 2102 Edition. 
(10)  International Property Maintenance Code: 2012 Edition. 
(11)  International Existing Building Code: 2012 Edition. 
(b)  A current copy of each of the codes adopted in subsection (a) of this section shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk, where it shall be available for public inspection. 
(Code 1990, § 8-2-1; Code 2005, § 18-1; Ord. No. 01287, § 1, 2-12-2018)  
Sec. 18-2. - Additional electrical standards. 
In addition to the National Electrical Code, in regard to the requirements for electrical hook-ups, the city shall require that every electrical hook-up located within the city be made in accordance with the approved standards and requirements of either Georgia Power Company or Carroll EMC. The standards and requirements of the Georgia Power Company and Carroll EMC are incorporated into this section by reference, and copies of such standards are maintained on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1990, § 8-2-2; Code 2005, § 18-2)  
Sec. 18-3. - Enforcement of adopted codes. 
Within the codes adopted by this chapter, when reference is made to the duties of certain officials named therein, that designated official of the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in the code shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of the code are concerned. 
(Code 1990, § 8-2-4; Code 2005, § 18-3) 
Editor's note— Building inspections are performed by the city inspector.  
Sec. 18-4. - Temporary structures. 
Temporary structures may be employed as on-site office or storage facilities at the site of new construction or subdivision development, provided that a permit is obtained for each structure and all such temporary structures shall be completely removed within 15 days of substantial completion of the project. 
(Code 1990, § 8-2-5; Code 2005, § 18-4)  
Sec. 18-5. - Work requiring building permit. 
(a)  The threshold whereby a citizen must acquire a building permit is $100.00 and/or 50 square feet of heated space. However, all construction projects with a cost of less than $1,000.00 shall be processed and inspections conducted at no cost to the owner of the property, provided that the construction/renovation/rehabilitation falls under one of the following categories or projects of a similar nature: 
(1)  All projects including the construction or repair of loadbearing elements (such as a deck, porch, detached or attached garage, storage shed, etc.). 
(2)  All projects having a potential bearing upon the property line of a neighbor (such as an accessory building, a deck/porch, new sidewalk or replacement of a sidewalk or driveway and fence construction). 
(b)  All home additions in excess of 50 square feet of heated space shall be treated as though a new home was being built. If necessary, an electric, plumbing and mechanical permit may be required. Additions less than 50 square feet are not required to obtain a building permit; however, an electrical, plumbing or mechanical permit may be necessary depending upon how extensive the improvements are. If the cost of the addition is over $1,000.00, but the square footage is less than 50 square feet heated, a building permit must be obtained. 
(Code 2005, § 18-5; Res. No. 05460, § 1, 5-14-2001; Res. No. 05466, § 1, 7-9-2001)  
Sec. 18-6. - Plan review fees. 
(a)  Commercial and industrial site plans. There shall be a fee as set from time to time by the mayor and city council for commercial and industrial site plan review and preliminary plat and final plat evaluations, which shall include a preliminary plan review and initial plan review service. 
(b)  Home design plans. A fee set from time to time by the mayor and city council is required for home design plan review. 
(c)  Re-evaluation fee. A re-evaluation fee for plans which, after being preliminarily evaluated and corrections made, are submitted and do not include all required elements on the initial plan review, as detailed in chapter 106, pertaining to zoning, and chapter 90, pertaining to subdivisions, shall be set from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(d)  Payment. Fees must be paid at the time that the plans are submitted for review. 
(Code 2005, § 18-6; Res. No. 05481, § 1, 12-10-2001)  
Sec. 18-7. - Re-inspection fee. 
A re-inspection fee of $25.00 must be paid by the builder/property owner prior to any necessary re-inspections or subsequent inspections which would be conducted after a failed inspection was completed. 
(Code 2005, § 18-7; Res. No. 05476, § 1, 11-12-2001)  
Sec. 18-8. - Demolition permit. 
(a)  Required. A demolition permit is required prior to demolishing or modifying any building within the city. 
(b)  Fee. A fee set from time to time by the mayor and city council for the demolition permit is payable prior to: 
(1)  City inspection of property to determine if asbestos is present. 
(2)  Issuance of the demolition permit. 
(c)  Asbestos inspection. If the building inspector suspects asbestos to be present, the building owner shall be required to have a qualified state-certified professional evaluate the building for asbestos contamination. If the building subsequently is determined to not have asbestos, the demolition permit shall be issued. However, if asbestos contamination is positively established, then required abatement shall be accomplished and a statement certifying such has been accomplished from a state-certified professional shall be provided prior to the city issuing a demolition permit. 
(Code 2005, § 18-8; Res. No. 05475, § 1, 11-12-2001)  
Sec. 18-9. - Stop work orders. 
(a)  The city manager or his designee shall issue and enforce stop work orders due to construction work having been initiated without the required building permit. 
(b)  A stop work order shall be issued in writing to the property owner and/or the construction foreman/contractor. 
(c)  Any employee or project worker who fails to comply with the stop work order shall be subject to arrest and citation in accordance with section 1-7. 
(Code 2005, § 18-9; Res. No. 05482, § 1, 4-8-2002)  
Sec. 18-10. - Water-conserving plumbing fixtures required. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial means any type of building other than residential. 
Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. 
Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but shall not include a hotel or motel. 
(b)  New residential construction. On or after July 1, 1991, no construction may be initiated within the city for any residential building of any type which: 
(1)  Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this subsection (b)(1) shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; 
(2)  Employs a showerhead that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; 
(3)  Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of 1.0 gallons per flush; 
(4)  Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute; or 
(5)  Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. 
(c)  New commercial construction. On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the city for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Repair, renovation or additions. The requirements of subsection (b) of this section shall apply to any residential construction initiated after July 1, 1991, and to any commercial construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers or both. 
(e)  Exemptions. 
(1)  New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of subsections (b) through (d) of this section when: 
a.  The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; 
b.  Such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this section were installed; 
c.  Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or 
d.  Units to be installed are: 
1.  Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; 
2.  Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 
3.  Toilets for juveniles. 
(2)  The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsection (e)(1)b, c or d of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the building inspector for the city. A minimum fee of $25.00 shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. 
(f)  Enforcement; penalty. 
(1)  The office of the building inspector of the city and county shall enforce this section. Citations for violations may be issued by the chief building inspector of the city or county. 
(2)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 2005, § 18-10; Ord. No. 01161, §§ 1—6, 4-22-1991) 
Charter reference— Authority to establish building regulations for city, § 1.21.  
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; taxation, ch. 94; business and occupation taxes, § 94-46 et seq.; motel tax, § 94-122 et seq.; utilities, ch. 102; P, Professional District, § 106-137; I, Institutional, 106-142; CH, Historic Downtown Commercial District; 106-139; C-1, Modern Retail Commercial District, 106-140; C-I Commercial Interstate, 106-141; M-1, Light Manufacturing Industrial District, 106-143; M-2, Heavy, Manufacturing Industrial District, 106-144. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 22-1. - Junk dealers. 
(a)  No person shall collect junk of any kind on private property within the city without first obtaining a junk dealer's license. No junk dealer shall operate his business on public property or on any property not allowing such a business under chapter 106, pertaining to zoning. 
(b)  All junk dealers shall enclose the property used for their business with a solid, opaque fence six feet high. No junk may be maintained on such property in such a manner as to be visible from passersby on a public right-of-way or by persons on neighboring property. 
(c)  It is required to obtain and maintain a junk yard cleanup bond equal to a value of $25,000.00 per acre of the lot where the junk yard is to be located. Proof of the issuance of the bond must be shown prior to the new or subsequent license being issued. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-1; Code 2005, § 22-1)  
Sec. 22-2. - Closing hours for pool rooms. 
No pool room or billiard hall shall remain open in the city later than 12:00 midnight. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-2; Code 2005, § 22-2) 
State Law reference— Regulation of pool rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2.  
Sec. 22-3. - Peddling on streets. 
No person shall peddle or sell from any vehicle on city streets or rights-of-way. 
(Code 1990, § 9-4-3; Code 2005, § 22-3)  
Secs. 22-4—22-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TATTOO STUDIOS 
 
Sec. 22-25. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Moral character. 
(1)  Good moral character means the propensity of the person to serve the public in the licensed area in a fair, honest and open manner. 
(2)  A judgment of guilt in a criminal prosecution or a judgment in a civil action shall not be used in and of itself as proof of a person's lack of good moral character. It may be used as evidence in the determination and when so used the person shall be notified and shall be permitted to rebut the evidence by showing that: 
a.  At the current time he has the ability to, and is likely to, serve the public in a fair, honest and open manner; and 
b.  He is rehabilitated, or that the substance of the former offense is not reasonably related to the occupation or profession for which he seeks a business license or business permit. 
(3)  The following criminal records shall not be used, examined, or requested by the city in a determination of good moral character when used as a requirement to obtain a business license or business permit: 
a.  Records of an arrest not followed by a conviction. 
b.  Records of a conviction which has been reversed or vacated, including the arrest records relevant to that conviction. 
c.  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor or a felony unrelated to the person's likelihood to serve the public in a fair, honest, and open manner. 
d.  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor for the conviction of which a person may not be incarcerated in a jail or prison. 
Tattoo, tattoo artist and tattoo studio mean the same as found in the definitions section of O.C.G.A. § 31-40-1. Further, should there be additional defined terms under state law which apply to tattoo establishments, these terms are likewise incorporated into this article by reference. 
(Code 2005, § 22-31; Ord. No. 01216, § 9-5-1, 3-12-2001) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Terms defined, O.C.G.A. § 31-40-1.  
Sec. 22-26. - Adoption of state law. 
The city hereby adopts the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 31-40-1 et seq., as if set out fully in this section, with additions as further noted in this article. 
(Code 2005, § 22-32; Ord. No. 01216, 3-12-2001) 
State Law reference— Tattoo studio regulations, O.C.G.A. § 31-40-1 et seq.  
Sec. 22-27. - Business license required; insurance. 
(a)  A normal business license shall be required to operate a tattoo studio pursuant to this Code. 
(b)  Any person operating a tattoo studio within the corporate limits of the city shall maintain a general public liability policy covering any acts, errors or omissions in connection with the operation of the studio in an amount to be set by the mayor and city council from time to time. Further, medical payments coverage, also to be set by the mayor and city council from time to time, shall be obtained, so as to adequately protect the public against injury, death, medical complications, sickness or other matters which might occur as a result of negligent failure of operations, or similar tortuous conduct, of any tattoo studio. Evidence of the certificate of insurance meeting the minimum requirements of this section shall be provided to the city prior to the issuance of a license. 
(Code 2005, § 22-33; Ord. No. 01216, § 9-5-2, 3-12-2001)  
Sec. 22-28. - Prohibited locations. 
It shall be unlawful for a tattoo studio to operate in any location which is presently a prohibited location for the operation of malt beverage establishments in the city pursuant to this Code. 
(Code 2005, § 22-34; Ord. No. 01216, § 9-5-3, 3-12-2001)  
Sec. 22-29. - State permit; compliance with state regulations. 
No person shall be authorized to operate a tattoo studio within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a valid permit for such operations by the duly authorized representative of the state department of human resources, through the county board of health or such other agency as might review the permit procedure. The provisions concerning the issuance of permits, suspensions and revocations and rules and regulations concerning tattoo studios as contained in O.C.G.A. § 31-40-2 et seq., are incorporated in this section by reference and made a part of this article. Further, the rules of the state department of human resources governing tattoo studios and artists, presently promulgated in chapter 290-5, as currently enacted or as hereafter amended, are incorporated in this section by reference and made a part of this article. Any applicant and/or license holder shall comply with all terms, provisions and conditions of both state law and state regulatory authority concerning the operation of a tattoo studio, and first obtain a state permit prior to applying for a city license. 
(Code 2005, § 22-35; Ord. No. 01216, § 9-5-4, 3-12-2001)  
Sec. 22-30. - Persons to whom license may be issued; transfer of license. 
A license may only be granted to a person (or if a partnership to a managing partner, and if a corporation a local outlet manager of the corporation) for any tattoo studio. Such license is not transferable. 
(Code 2005, § 22-36; Ord. No. 01216, § 9-5-5, 3-12-2001)  
Sec. 22-31. - Revocation of license. 
Any person who shall conduct a tattoo studio or otherwise engage in the business of tattooing without first securing a state permit license and city license, or operating in violation of the permit and/or license, shall be subject to revocation of the license upon appropriate notice and hearing by the city. Where public health and emergency exist, the license may be forthwith (in only exigent circumstances) suspended, provided that a hearing is conducted within ten days of the exigent suspension concerning the reason for emergency suspension and for a decision affecting partial or permanent revocation of the license. Grounds for revocation of a license shall be violations of the provisions of this article or the provisions and regulations of state law, or similar violations of federal, state or local laws governing tattoo studios and these establishments in general. 
(Code 2005, § 22-37; Ord. No. 01216, § 9-5-6, 3-12-2001)  
Secs. 22-32—22-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WRECKER AND TOWING SERVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
 
Sec. 22-51. - Prerequisites for placement on rotation list; rotation list procedures. 
(a)  No person engaged in the wrecker/towing service business within the city shall be called upon by city police officers or other authorized employees of the city to furnish the service of towing any vehicle upon city streets unless the person's firm or corporation shall have been placed on the approved scheduled rotation (month-to-month) call list after having complied with the following conditions: 
(1)  Such person must complete the full on-call wrecker service application shown in section 22-57. 
(2)  Such person must possess a valid/current occupational license. 
(3)  Such person must possess a valid state public service commission certificate and meet all federal motor carrier safety regulations and other applicable state public service commission requirements for operating a wrecker/towing service. 
(4)  Such person must have an established business location (as defined in this article) within the three-mile trade area of the city. 
(5)  The service must be available 24 hours a day, seven days per week, and be able to respond within 20 minutes on at least 90 percent of calls made by the city police department. 
(6)  The wrecker/towing service shall have qualified employees skilled in performing their duties and possessing a valid Georgia driver license of the proper class. 
(7)  The wrecker/towing service shall have available at least two wreckers, one of which must be a roll-back wrecker in good operating condition. This means meeting requirements of local rules/regulations, local ordinances, federal motor carrier regulations, state law, and state public service commission requirements. 
(8)  All wreckers shall be equipped with an amber flashing light meeting the most current regulatory requirements of the Georgia State Patrol, and also sufficient red flares, lanterns, or warning lights and reflectors (as required by section 393.95 of the Federal Motor Carrier Regulations) so as to be able to mark the scene of a wreck on both sides of the wreck, so as to warn all traffic on the highway of the emergency existing while the wreckers are in operation. The wreckers shall also carry brooms, shovels, and a bucket (pail), and fire extinguishers, suitable for extinguishing fires in wrecked vehicles and for cleaning up the debris and glass from the area where the wreck has occurred. The fire extinguisher shall meet the requirements of section 393.95 of the Federal Motor Carrier Regulations. 
(9)  There shall be painted in a conspicuous place, on both the right and left side of the wrecker, the name of the company, the address where the wrecker is based, and a telephone number. 
(10)  All persons engaged in the wrecker/towing business shall carry insurance, including liability insurance in the form of comprehensive, general, and automobile liability, and the policy shall protect it from claims for bodily injury, including death, to its employees and all others, and from claims for property damage, all of which may arise out of the result of the wrecker's operation under this article. This insurance shall be sufficient to reasonably ensure the contractor's solvency in the event of any injuries, deaths, or property damage, with the following minimum limits: 
a.  Bodily injury: $100,000.00 per person, $300,000.00 per accident. 
b.  Property damage in the amount of $50,000.00 or single limit of $300,000.00. 
A valid certificate of insurance must be maintained. Expiration of insurance will result in immediate removal from the list. 
(11)  The wrecker/towing service shall provide a storage area located within the three-mile trade area of the city for the storage and safekeeping of vehicles towed under this article and enclosed with a solid wall or substantial wire fence not less than six feet in height. The storage area shall be staffed weekly during regular business hours. Garage liability insurance in the same amount as required in subsection (a)(10) of this section shall be required. 
(12)  All wrecker/towing services agree to permit regular inspection of wrecker/towing vehicles and storage premises by representatives of the city police department. These inspections may be conducted by the state public service commission. 
(b)  The police officer or lawfully authorized officer shall determine whether or not a wrecker is needed, and if a wrecker is needed shall ascertain if the owner or operator is able to make his preference known as to what wrecker service the owner or operator desires called and have the dispatcher call the preferred service desired by the owner or operator of the vehicle. No police officer or other authorized officer may recommend to any person the wrecker service company to be called or employed. 
(c)  If the owner or operator is unable (due to injury or physical or mental impairment) to make a choice, or does not have a preference, the city police department will call the wrecker on the scheduled call list. 
(d)  If the city police are unable to reach the wrecker service on call, or for any reason the wrecker service on call is unable to furnish the service, the backup wrecker service (which will be the service next on call) shall be called. A wrecker/towing service shall not be able to designate its own backup service. 
(e)  Except in extreme emergencies, the police officer or other authorized officer shall await the arrival of the wrecker and shall, in the meantime, try to make the scene of the accident safe, giving warnings and directing traffic. 
(f)  The police officer or other authorized officer shall make out a tow-in report, which shall contain the information and details prescribed by the city. 
(g)  If an officer requests that a vehicle be towed to the police department, the wrecker operator shall have the shift sergeant sign the tow-in bill. At this point, the shift sergeant or designee will assume the responsibility for the vehicle and indicate where the vehicle is to be placed. 
(h)  Additional wrecker/towing services meeting the requirements of this section may be added to the rotation list. The first scheduled on-call rotation for additional service shall occur after all services on the list have completed one regular month rotation. 
(Code 2005, § 22-61; Ord. No. 01191, § I, 5-12-1997)  
Sec. 22-52. - Responsibilities of operators. 
(a)  Wrecker firms shall be responsible to the owner for all damage done during towing and storage of any vehicles entrusted to them under this article. 
(b)  Wrecker services shall cooperate with all duly authorized law enforcement officers in the protection of any evidence or in any investigation arising out of a wreck or seizure of a vehicle by any official. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the wrecker service (prior to leaving the scene of any collision) to clean the pavement of all debris, including all glass. 
(d)  The wrecker service shall not release any vehicle placed on hold from storage unless approved by an authorized representative of the city police department with issuance of a signed release form. 
(e)  The wrecker service shall maintain all wrecker units and all related equipment adequately, and be able to perform towing services in a responsible, workmanlike, and safe manner. 
(f)  When responding to a wrecker call the service shall use due regard and shall not be equipped or operated as an emergency vehicle. A wrecker service shall not follow or attempt to overtake, remain close to, or use authorized emergency vehicles to assist in violating state traffic laws or ordinances of the city unless authorized by officers on the scene as relayed by dispatch. 
(Code 2005, § 22-62; Ord. No. 01191, § II, 5-12-1997)  
Sec. 22-53. - Established business location required; business license, insurance and state certification; sharing wreckers. 
(a)  Office facilities and storage area. Each wrecker service must have a separate office and garage/storage area located within the three-mile trade area of the city. The garage/storage area cannot be shared with any other services on the approved scheduled call list. 
(b)  Telephone. Each service must have a separate telephone listing. This telephone number must be manned on a 24-hour-a-day basis during the on-call status. 
(c)  Occupational license. Each service must have a separate valid occupational license in the name of the service. 
(d)  Insurance. Each service must have separate insurance coverage issued in the name of the service, meeting all limits required in this article. 
(e)  State public service commission certificate. Each service must have a separate state public service commission certificate as required by law or by regulation. 
(f)  Sharing wreckers. Wrecker/towing units and equipment required under this article must be assigned and allocated to a specific service. Wreckers/towing units may not be assigned or allocated to more than one service or shared between or among services for the purposes of meeting the requirements of this article. 
(Code 2005, § 22-63; Ord. No. 01191, § III, 5-12-1997)  
Sec. 22-54. - Suspension or removal from rotation list. 
(a)  Upon written notice, the chief of police, or his designee, may suspend or remove any wrecker service assigned to the scheduled rotation call list for, but not limited to, violations of this article, violations of local ordinance, state law, or state public service commission regulations, or other just cause. 
(b)  Removal by the chief of police, or his designee, may be appealed in writing to the city manager, or his designee, within ten working days following the effective date of the notice. 
(c)  The city manager, or his designee, shall act as a hearing officer to conduct an appeal hearing and render an impartial decision based on the testimony and/or evidence presented. 
(d)  No later than five working days following the completion of the hearing, the city manager, or his designee, shall render an impartial decision on the appeal. The decision of the city manager will be final. 
(e)  Any grievance or complaint against the action of a city employee shall be rendered in writing. This grievance shall be returned to the sergeant within five working days of the date of the incident. 
(f)  The sergeant shall review the complaint for merit and, upon his recommendation, shall forward the complaint through the chain of command for review. 
(g)  Upon the request of the wrecker/towing service, any decision rendered by the sergeant may be appealed to the chief of police. The decision of the chief of police shall be final. 
(h)  If a complaint against an employee is filed in conjunction with a disciplinary action against a wrecker/towing service, both will be handled concurrently. 
(Code 2005, § 22-64; Ord. No. 01191, § IV, 5-12-1997)  
Sec. 22-55. - Fees for wrecker services. 
Fees for services rendered under this article shall be established by the respective wrecker/towing service. A listing of such fees shall be clearly posted at the garage/storage site and a written copy available for distribution on each wrecker unit. 
(Code 2005, § 22-65; Ord. No. 01191, § V, 5-12-1997)  
Sec. 22-56. - Use of rotation call list. 
A schedule shall be set up on a one-week rotating basis of all qualified wrecker/towing services under this article, which service shall be used as provided in this article except in extreme emergency, where persons are trapped or pinned in or under a vehicle, or in burning vehicles, or in danger of drowning by submersion, or where traffic is blocked to prevent the normal flow of vehicles, in which event and only in which event the police officer shall be authorized to call the nearest, most qualified service, to prevent serious injury or death. 
(Code 2005, § 22-66; Ord. No. 01191, § VI, 5-12-1997)  
Sec. 22-57. - On-call wrecker service application form. 
The on-call wrecker service application form referred to in this article is as follows: 
ON-CALL SERVICE WRECKER/TOW TRUCK INFORMATION/REGISTRATION FORM 
Company Name: 	_____
(Please Print as Shown on Business License) 
Company Address: 	_____
Company Telephone: 	_____
Owner Name: 	_____
Owner Address: 	_____
Owner Telephone: 	_____
 
COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING SECTION REGARDING ALL AUTHORIZED DRIVERS FOR YOUR COMPANY: 
Driver #1: _____ 
Date of Birth: ________ Driver License # _____ 
Driver #2: _____ 
Date of Birth: ________ Driver License # _____ 
Driver #3: _____ 
Date of Birth: ________ Driver License # _____ 
(Code 2005, § 22-67; Ord. No. 01191, 5-12-1997)  
Secs. 22-58—22-87. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - TAXICABS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
 
Sec. 22-88. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Moral character. 
(1)  Good moral character means the propensity of the person to serve the public in the licensed area in a fair, honest and open manner. 
(2)  A judgment of guilt in a criminal prosecution or a judgment in a civil action shall not be used in and of itself as proof of a person's lack of good moral character. It may be used as evidence in the determination and when so used the person shall be notified and shall be permitted to rebut the evidence by showing that: 
a.  At the current time he has the ability to, and is likely to, serve the public in a fair, honest and open manner; and 
b.  He is rehabilitated, or that the substance of the former offense is not reasonably related to the occupation or profession for which he seeks a business license or business permit. 
(3)  The following criminal records shall not be used, examined, or requested by the city in a determination of good moral character when used as a requirement to obtain a business license or business permit: 
a.  Records of an arrest not followed by a conviction. 
b.  Records of a conviction which has been reversed or vacated, including the arrest records relevant to that conviction. 
c.  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor or a felony unrelated to the person's likelihood to serve the public in a fair, honest, and open manner. 
d.  Records of an arrest or conviction for a misdemeanor for the conviction of which a person may not be incarcerated in a jail or prison. 
Taxicab means a vehicle used to convey human beings over the public streets of the city, for which a fee is charged. 
Taxicab driver means any person who drives or operates a taxicab or offers himself for such purpose, or any agent or servant employed or allowed by the owner or proprietor of a taxicab to operate a taxicab as such. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-2; Code 2005, § 22-91) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-89. - Driver's permit required; qualifications. 
(a)  All taxicab drivers shall comply with the requirements of this section before operating a taxicab within the limits of the city. 
(b)  The driver shall have a valid, current permit issued by the city. An annual fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and city council shall be paid the city in order to obtain a taxicab driver's permit. All taxicab driver's permits shall expire on December 31 of the year of issuance, regardless of the issuance date. 
(c)  No taxicab driver's permit shall be issued unless the applicant therefor: 
(1)  Possesses the appropriate class state license; 
(2)  Has not been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor or violation of law other than minor traffic offenses during the past five years; 
(3)  Possesses a good reputation for moral character in the community; 
(4)  Allows himself to be fingerprinted; and 
(5)  Furnishes a two-inch by two-inch recent front view photograph of his face. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-3; Code 2005, § 22-92)  
Sec. 22-90. - Business license. 
In addition to the fee for a taxicab driver's permit, no company or individual shall operate as a taxicab or taxicab company without first obtaining a business license from the city. A business license tax, including an additional tax per vehicle operated in the city, shall be paid before the license is issued. The annual license tax shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-4; Code 2005, § 22-93) 
Charter reference— Regulation of vehicles for hire, § 1.21(j).  
Sec. 22-91. - Insurance. 
No vehicle shall be used as a taxicab unless it is covered by a valid policy of liability insurance. The conditions and minimum financial amount of coverages required shall be established from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-5; Code 2005, § 22-94; Ord. No. 01195, § 1, 11-10-1997)  
Sec. 22-92. - Vehicle markings. 
Each vehicle used as a taxicab shall at all times have a sign or lettering on the vehicle clearly showing the name of the company or proprietor of the vehicle, and the term "Taxi" or "Taxicab." Lettering must be at least two inches in height and spaced and colored so that the sign can be readily visible at a distance of 200 feet in daylight. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-6; Code 2005, § 22-95)  
Sec. 22-93. - Display of driver's permit. 
(a)  No taxicab driver shall operate a taxicab unless his driver's permit is conspicuously displayed in the taxicab in his possession at all times so that the permit is clearly visible to passengers. 
(b)  The taxicab driver's permit shall reflect the following information, without obliteration or covering: 
(1)  The name and address of the person to whom the permit is issued; 
(2)  The age, height, weight, nationality, social security number, and chauffeur's license number of that person; and 
(3)  A two-inch by two-inch recent front view photograph of that person. 
(Code 1990, § 9-2-8; Code 2005, § 22-96)  
Secs. 22-94—22-114. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PAWNBROKERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; municipal authority to supervise, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136. 
 
Sec. 22-115. - License required; compliance required; revocation of license. 
No person shall conduct or operate the business of pawnbroker without having first obtained a license from the city, nor shall such person conduct the business in violation of any of the provisions contained in this article. Any pawnbroker's license may be revoked by the mayor and city council for any violation of any provision of this article. 
(Code 1990, § 9-3-1; Code 2005, § 22-121) 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136.  
Sec. 22-116. - Application for license; investigation. 
(a)  Application for a pawnbroker's license shall be made to the city clerk and shall state thereon: 
(1)  The name of the applicant; 
(2)  The place of business; and 
(3)  The number of employees intended to be engaged. 
(b)  The chief of police or any other officer designated by the mayor and city council shall investigate each applicant for a license and shall report back to the mayor and city council whether or not the applicant is a person of good moral character. No license shall be issued to a person who has been convicted of the offense of receiving stolen goods or of burglary, larceny or robbery. 
(Code 1990, § 9-3-2; Code 2005, § 22-122)  
Sec. 22-117. - License fee. 
The annual fee for a pawnbroker's license shall be as fixed from time to time by the mayor and city council, payable in advance. No license shall be issued until the fee is paid. 
(Code 1990, § 9-3-3; Code 2005, § 22-123)  
Sec. 22-118. - Records. 
Every pawnbroker doing business in the city shall keep a record of every article pledged with him or sold to him in a manner prescribed by the chief of police. 
(Code 1990, § 9-3-4; Code 2005, § 22-124) 
State Law reference— Content of records required to be kept, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-132.  
Sec. 22-119. - Transactions with persons under 18 years of age; minimum age of licensee and employees. 
No pawnbroker shall have any business dealings as a pawnbroker with any person less than 18 years of age, except with the written consent of the parent or guardian of the minor to each particular transaction. No pawnbroker's license shall be issued to any person who is not 21 years of age or over, and no pawnbroker shall employ a person of less than 21 years of age to assist him in his business. 
(Code 1990, § 9-3-5; Code 2005, § 22-125)  
Sec. 22-120. - Report of stolen goods. 
It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the police any article pledged with him, or which it is sought to be pledged with him, if he shall have reason to believe that the article was stolen or that the article was lost and found by the person attempting to pledge it. 
(Code 1990, § 9-3-6; Code 2005, § 22-126)  
Sec. 22-121. - Secondhand dealers. 
No pawnbroker shall conduct the business of a secondhand dealer without having obtained the license required for such dealer in addition to his pawnbroker's license. 
(Code 1990, § 9-3-7; Code 2005, § 22-127)  
Secs. 22-122—22-145. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - YARD SALES 
 
Sec. 22-146. - Permitted; regulations. 
The city hereby proclaims that the occurrence of yard sales is permitted without any necessary paperwork being completed, and no permit, with a permit number, being issued by the city, provided that the following regulations are complied with: 
(1)  Yard sales are restricted to land either zoned residential and occupied with a residential building, or land zoned for another land use but occupied by a residential structure, and occupied by people as their place of residence. 
(2)  Yard sales are strictly prohibited on property which is vacant. 
(3)  The person conducting the yard sale must be a citizen of the city and the yard sale which is occurring must be conducted on the residential property which the citizen owns. The citizen may, at their discretion, allow nonresidents to conduct a yard sale simultaneously while they are conducting a yard sale on their own property, provided that the non-citizen sets up their yard sale on the same property as the sponsoring citizen. 
(4)  A citizen can conduct no more than three yard sales per year, with a maximum of three consecutive days of operation (such as Friday, Saturday and Sunday). Yard sales on consecutive weekends are prohibited. 
(5)  Any individual setting up a yard sale or yard sale type display on land zoned as either commercial (any district) or manufacturing (any district), whether occupied by another building utilized for commercial/manufacturing activity or vacant land, shall be construed to be a business operating for pecuniary benefit. Therefore, that entity must acquire a occupational tax permit (business license) from the city, the fees for which are established in Ordinance Nos. 01183, 01198 and 01225, and in chapter 94, article III. 
(6)  Any individual or entity occupying a commercially zoned or manufacturing zoned parcel of land for a minimum of two hours shall be required to purchase a occupational tax permit from the city, as though they have opened a business up and located an office in Tallapoosa, the fees for which are established in Ordinance Nos. 01183, 11198 and 01225, and in chapter 94, article III. 
(7)  Failure to comply with any aspect of these regulations shall result in a citation to appear in the municipal court of the city being issued by the city police department. Punishment is in accordance with section 1-7, with a maximum penalty of $1,000.00 and/or 30 days' incarceration. All activity in violation of this section shall be ordered halted, and a cease and desist order issued by the chief of police or an officer designated to do so by the chief of police. 
(8)  No activity currently occurring or previously having been conducted shall be allowed to continue. (No grandfather clause shall be extended.) 
(9)  Exemptions. The above-enumerated regulations shall be suspended for the weekend of the city-wide yard sale, which currently occurs during on the first weekend of October, and shall include the Friday immediately prior to that Saturday, and the immediately proceeding Sunday. Such exemption shall be provided for whatever weekend city-wide yard sales occur on in the future. 
(Ord. No. 01250, exh. 2005-D, 9-12-2005)  
Chapter 26 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Purchase of lots. 
All persons desiring to purchase a lot in the city cemetery shall apply to the city clerk, who, upon payment of the fixed price for each lot, shall cause a deed or other instrument of receipt therefor to be given to the purchaser. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-1; Code 2005, § 26-1)  
Sec. 26-2. - Lot charges. 
The cost of lots in the cemetery shall be as from time to time established by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-2; Code 2005, § 26-2)  
Sec. 26-3. - Burial permit. 
No person shall be buried in the cemetery without there first having been obtained from the city a burial permit for the person who is to be buried in the cemetery. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-3; Code 2005, § 26-3)  
Sec. 26-4. - Digging of graves. 
All graves shall be dug in accordance with regulations approved by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-4; Code 2005, § 26-4)  
Sec. 26-5. - Approval required for planting of trees or other plants. 
No person shall plant or set any tree, shrub, flower, grass, or other plant of any kind in the cemetery except with the approval of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-5; Code 2005, § 26-5)  
Sec. 26-6. - Cutting of trees and shrubs. 
The pruning or cutting of all trees and shrubbery in the cemetery is hereby prohibited unless done under the immediate supervision of a city employee. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-6; Code 2005, § 26-6)  
Sec. 26-7. - Work to be done by city. 
All grading, landscaping and improvements of every kind shall be made or done by the city only. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-7; Code 2005, § 26-7)  
Sec. 26-8. - Conduct in cemetery; damaging trees or other plants; trespassing. 
No person shall disturb the quiet, repose and good order of the cemetery, nor shall any person deface, remove, disturb, injure or destroy any tree, plant, or shrub therein except in the manner provided in this chapter. Trespassing within the cemetery is hereby prohibited, and no person shall commit any immoral act therein. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-8; Code 2005, § 26-8)  
Sec. 26-9. - Vehicles. 
Vehicles shall be driven only upon the public roadways within the cemetery and at a rate of speed not in excess of 15 miles per hour. No vehicle shall enter the cemetery except for the purpose of attending funerals, visiting graves, or other lawful mission. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-9; Code 2005, § 26-9) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98.  
Sec. 26-10. - Deposit of waste. 
No person shall deposit any rubbish, filth, waste, or other unclean or unsightly substance in the cemetery. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-10; Code 2005, § 26-10) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 82.  
Sec. 26-11. - Lot regulations. 
All lots within the cemetery of the city, and within any extension of the cemetery at any time hereafter made, shall be subject to and regulated and controlled by the provisions of this chapter and any rules adopted by the city. 
(Code 1990, § 5-4-11; Code 2005, § 26-11)  
Sec. 26-12. - Rules and regulations pertaining to all city cemeteries. 
(a)  Permits. 
(1)  A no-cost notification permit must be obtained from the city hall before any construction can be commenced. A fee shall be charged for subsection (a)(1)d of this section. 
a.  A grave to be dug. 
b.  A grave to be reopened. 
c.  A grave to be disinterred. 
d.  A grave or lot to be owner transferred. 
e.  A monument (headstone) to be installed in a cemetery grave. This permit will require a footing inspection to be performed prior to the monument (headstone) being installed. 
(2)  Such permits should be obtained 24 hours prior to the planned activity, if possible. 
(b)  Corner markers required. All purchasers of municipal cemetery grave spaces shall be required to place corner markers on said spaces. These markers shall be designated by the city, on lot locations and at various areas within the city cemetery, so as to more accurately and clearly designate the lot spaces, sections, or other areas within the city cemetery. 
(c)  Grave digging or maintenance. 
(1)  All graves shall be dug and prepared under the direction of the city. 
(2)  Only approved (authorized) persons, or firms with a state license, upon receipt of a permit from the family, may dig graves in the city cemeteries. 
(3)  General maintenance may be done by lot owners on their lots at any time except while a burial is in progress. 
(4)  The lot owner is responsible for ensuring that all excess dirt is removed from a city cemetery, leaving at least two feet covering the vault and shall level off and place, or make a permanent grave site covering, with grass seed. At the end of 30 days, or a reasonable time, if the lot owner has not done this, the city will remove the excess dirt to level off the grave site, make the permanent grave site covering and bill the lot owner or family $100.00 for the service. The city will contact the owner prior to the work being started. 
(5)  No grave shall be less than four feet to the bottom of the vault. No wooden boxes shall be used for burial. Vaults are required for all burials having a length of five feet. Vaults must be made of concrete, fiberglass, steel, or equal. 
(6)  Markers must be removed and replaced by the company digging the grave, and that charge, if there is an additional fee, added to the grave opening fee, as established by the grave digging company and billed to the customer by the grave digging company. That company is responsible and accountable for this action, and failure of the company to do so may subject that company to additional fees assessed by the city, and perhaps loss of authorization to work in the city cemeteries. 
(d)  Trees and shrubs. 
(1)  Trees and shrubs are not permitted. 
(2)  If trees or plants currently exist on a grave lot, the city has the authority to remove them if they become unsightly, or interfere with the maintenance or orderly operation of other plots. 
(3)  The city will notify the lot owner of maintenance needs, which shall be done by the owner. 
(4)  If the city maintenance crew is required to perform necessary lot maintenance, the owner will be billed for the work at $25.00 per hour, with at least one hour billed. However, the city will contact the owner prior to the work being started. 
(e)  Lot flowers, wreaths, etc. 
(1)  Lot owners may place flowers, wreaths, etc., on their plots at any time. 
(2)  The owner shall remove live flowers within a reasonable length of time of their placement. 
(3)  Plastic or silk arrangements must be removed when worn and/or faded. 
(4)  Items not removed by the owner may be removed by the city upon being determined they are unsightly or faded. 
(5)  Following a burial, the owner shall remove all original arrangements, after a reasonable length of time. 
(6)  If lot arrangements are vandalized, the city may immediately clean the lot without notifying the owner. 
(f)  Erection of monuments, gravestones, and markers. 
(1)  Grave markers (headstones) will carry very limited restrictions, as described below. However, they must be inside the boundaries of the owner's lot by a minimum of six inches on all sides. Damage to markers shall be repaired within two weeks of a city notification to the owner of the damage. 
(2)  Each headstone and footstone shall have a six-inch concrete base, or "footing." All footings will be inspected by the city prior to the stone being set. 
(3)  Plot boundary markers shall be only ground level, flush with the ground, such that a lawn mower can cut over the marker. The permitted marker shall be constructed out of bronze, granite or marble. Markers must be maintained within the boundaries of the owner's lot. 
(4)  No monument shall be more than six feet (72 inches) in height above the ground, and must be at least four inches thick (Pollard section only). 
(5)  The plan, design and location of all monuments and markers must be submitted to, and approved by, the city before work thereon is commenced. 
(6)  Only flat markers shall be permitted in the First Addition (lower Hollywood section). No walls or masonry markers will be allowed. No flowers can be planted on or around lots. All flower arrangements, including vases and potted plants, must comply with subsection (e) of this section and should be removed once they become faded, unsightly or wilted. 
(g)  Above-ground vaults, crypts, or mausoleums. No above-ground vaults, crypts, or mausoleums shall be placed in the city cemetery, except in certain sections. Mausoleums may be a maximum of nine feet in height, designed to accommodate two vaults (bodies). 
(h)  Burial of paupers. The mayor and city council, or their assigned representatives, must approve the burial of paupers. At the request of the assigned representative, the party requesting burial shall disclose pertinent information that is related to the burial. 
(i)  Burials. 
(1)  The city cemetery will accommodate the burial of human remains only. 
(2)  Cremation burial policy: 
a.  The city must pre-approve any grave opening in the city cemetery. 
b.  A licensed grave digger must dig all grave sites. 
c.  Cremation vaults are required. 
d.  Cremation vaults must have a minimum of 24 inches of dirt covering the top. 
e.  Burial of cremated remains are limited to two per grave. 
f.  All rules regarding standard grave opening shall apply, except depth. 
(j)  Disinterment. No disinterment shall be allowed, except as provided by state law. The city shall make arrangements with the owner or person obtaining the permit for disinterment for such work. 
(k)  Vandalism. 
(1)  No person shall damage, injure, obliterate or desecrate any grave or lot. 
(2)  No person shall trespass upon any grave. 
(3)  No person shall cut, deface, mutilate or otherwise damage or injure any monument or other memorial or marker. 
(4)  No person shall damage, injure, destroy, or remove any flower, shrub, tree, or other plant or any structure or other object in the cemetery. 
(l)  Cemetery hours. The city cemetery is closed every day from sundown to sunup. 
(m)  Burial notification. The owner or his assigned representative shall notify the city 24 hours prior to a burial. 
(n)  Fees and charges. A burial lot in a city cemetery consists of four grave spaces. Fees and costs for burial lots (which includes all permit fees and costs), transfer of ownership records, maintenance work and mausoleums, in the city cemetery, shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, as follows below: 
(1)  Current fees and charges (these may be amended by the mayor and council by resolution): 
a.  Lower section Hollywood Cemetery, lot: $1,200.00 (includes all fees and permits). 
b.  New addition, Pollard section, lot: $1,600.00 (includes all fees and permits). 
c.  Transfer of ownership records: $25.00 per lot. 
d.  Commercial mausoleums (per vault space): $300.00. 
(o)  Payment arrangements for burial lot purchase. At the request of the burial lot purchaser, the city may make arrangements for the purchaser to acquire a burial lot by paying the fee in monthly installments. The maximum number of months that either burial lot, lower section Hollywood Cemetery or new addition, Pollard section, may take to fully pay for the burial lot is 12 months. Such an arrangements' details shall be agreed upon with the city manager. Normally, the payments would be either $100.00 per month or $133.00 ($137.00 first payment), respectively. The first month's payment must be paid at the signing of the burial lot deed, and continue in consecutive months until the debt retirement is completed. The burial lot deed shall be held by the city until that time that the entire cost of the burial lot has been paid. However, if events require the purchaser to use the burial lot prior to the debt being completely paid, purchaser must pay the entire unpaid balance to the city, prior to the city providing permission to have one of the grave sites opened. 
(p)  Abandoned cemetery lots. Any grave lot or space, or portions thereof, within the city cemetery, which have been abandoned or the rights of the owner of said lot have been terminated or forfeited, for any reason, shall be addressed, pursuant to the provisions of the O.C.G.A. § 44-5-211, as presently enacted, or as may from time to time be subsequently amended or revised. 
(q)  Miscellaneous rules and regulations.
