(1)  The grades of all lots shall be fixed at the time of the preparation of the lot for sale; and no change will be allowed when that grade has been established. 
(2)  No coping, fence, sidewalk, wall or any other kind of enclosure of a grave, lot or burial space will be allowed. 
(3)  No benches, fences, seats, boxes or other articles or fixtures shall be allowed on any lot. 
(4)  All prior sales of lots shall be grandfathered, in as much that no further fees regarding grave opening shall be levied, as of the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this amendment is derived. 
(r)  Penalty for violation of article. All violations of this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-7, upon conviction. 
(s)  Archive and record of amendments of the cemetery rules and regulations. 
(1)  Originally adopted by the mayor and council on May 12, 2003. 
(2)  Amended/revised by the mayor and council on July 14, 2003. 
(3)  Amended/revised by the mayor and council on August 9, 2004. 
(4)  Amended/revised by the mayor and council on May 12, 2008. 
(5)  Amended/revised by the mayor and council on September 14, 2015. 
(Ord. No. 01283, exh. 2015-A, 9-14-2015)  
Chapter 30 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention, ch. 46; law enforcement, ch. 58. 
State Law reference— Local organizations for emergency management required, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 30-1. - Authority to waive procedures and fees during state of emergency. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fee means any fee or rate charged by the city for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits, and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair and cleanup of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fee" shall not include those fees collected by the city on behalf of the federal or state government or those fees charged by the city pursuant to a federal or state statute or regulation. 
State of emergency, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), means a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. 
Subsequent recovery period means the period of time that the disaster or emergency continues to cause disruptions in the area impacted by the disaster or emergency. The subsequent recovery period shall not exceed six months after the state of emergency declaration by the governor is terminated unless extended by official action of the mayor and city council. 
Temporary dwelling means any mobile or easily movable home, trailer, recreational vehicle or structure not otherwise permitted by the zoning regulations in a particular zoning district. 
(b)  Meetings. Upon proclamation by the appropriate state official of an emergency or disaster of manmade or natural causes or enemy attack impending on or affecting the state or the United States, the affairs and business of the city may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual place thereof, within or outside of the city, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such meeting occurs outside of the city, all actions taken by the local governing body shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the city. Such meetings may be called by the mayor without regard to or compliance with time-consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by law. 
(c)  Public works contracts. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon determination by the mayor and city council, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the mayor and city council, its designee or the emergency interim successor may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four weeks; provided, however, that any public works contract entered into pursuant to this subsection shall be entered on the minutes of the city as soon as practical and the nature of the emergency described therein. 
(d)  Code enforcement. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the mayor and city council, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the mayor and city council, its designee or the emergency interim successor may temporarily suspend the enforcement of this Code, or any portion thereof, where: 
(1)  The emergency or disaster is of such nature that immediate action outside this Code is required; 
(2)  Such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety and welfare; and 
(3)  Such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state statutes or regulations. 
(e)  Fees. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the mayor and city council, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the mayor and city council, its designee or the emergency interim successor may reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures as necessary to encourage the rebuilding of the area impacted by the disaster or emergency. 
(f)  Temporary dwellings. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the mayor and city council, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the mayor and city council, its designee or the emergency interim successor may issue temporary permits for mobile homes, trailers, recreational vehicles, or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district while the primary dwelling is being repaired, provided that such temporary dwellings or parks are designed by an engineer and the plans are approved by the county health department and county permits office. The temporary permit shall not exceed six months in duration. In the case of continuing hardship and in the discretion of the mayor and city council or its designee, the permit may be extended for an additional six months. Upon expiration of the temporary permit or an extension, the temporary dwelling shall be removed. 
(Code 2005, § 30-1; Ord. No. 01221, §§ 1, 2, 12-10-2001) 
State Law reference— Authority to act to protect safety, health and welfare, O.C.G.A. §§ 38-3-27, 38-3-28; waiver of formalities, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-54; Emergency Management Act definitions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3.  
Sec. 30-2. - Overcharging for goods, materials, services or housing during state of emergency. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Overcharging means charging prices for goods, materials, services, or housing which are substantially in excess of the customary charges or in applicable cases substantially in excess of the supplier's or provider's costs for such goods, materials, services or housing. The existence of overcharging shall be presumed from a substantial increase in the price at which the goods, material, service, or housing was offered in the usual course of business immediately prior to the onset of the emergency, but shall not include increases in costs to the supplier directly attributable to higher costs of materials, supplies, and labor costs resulting from the emergency. 
State of emergency means, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster or emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship or suffering threatened or caused thereby. 
Subsequent recovery period means that period during which the disaster continues to cause disruptions in the disaster area, but shall not exceed six months after the emergency declaration has been terminated by the governor unless extended by official action of the mayor and city council. 
(b)  Overcharging prohibited. In order to preserve, protect, or sustain the life, health, or safety of persons or their property, it shall be unlawful, during the duration of a state of emergency or subsequent recovery period in which the city has been designated as a disaster area, for any person located or doing business in the city to overcharge for any goods, materials, services or housing sold within the city. 
(Code 2005, § 30-2) 
State Law reference— Emergency Management Act definitions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3; police powers of municipality, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-28.  
Sec. 30-3. - Registration of building and repair services during state of emergency. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building contractor means any person engaging in, undertaking or carrying on any business consisting of or relating to building construction, repairs, renovation or making improvements to real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures or fixtures attached thereto. 
Doing business means any building contractor if: 
(1)  He has or operates an office, agency, project site or place of business located in the incorporated areas of the city, whether permanently, temporarily, periodically, or otherwise, that provides activities in the incorporated areas of the city, expressly including, but not limited to, the following: the construction, renovation, or repair of dwellings or buildings or the making of improvements to real property or any fixtures attached thereto; or 
(2)  He performs activities or services in the incorporated area of the city, expressly including, but not limited to, the following: the construction, renovation or repair of dwellings or buildings or the making of improvements to real property or any fixtures attached thereto, regardless of the location of the principal office. 
State of emergency means, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster or emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. 
Subsequent recovery period means that period during which the disaster continues to cause disruptions in the disaster area, but shall not exceed three months after the emergency declaration has been terminated by the governor. 
(b)  Registration required. No person shall engage in, undertake or carry on any business in whole or in part within the incorporated areas of the city consisting of or relating to building, constructing, repairing, renovating, or making improvements to real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures, or fixtures attached thereto, without having registered the name of the business with the mayor and city council and having paid fees as provided by this section. 
(c)  Application for registration. All building contractors doing business or proposing to do business in the incorporated area of the city during a state of emergency or the subsequent recovery period shall register and file applications with the city clerk or such other person designated by the mayor and city council at such place as designated by the city. The building contractor shall, under oath, provide the mayor and city council with a statement describing the general nature of the business to be conducted and give true and correct information as may be called for on the registration form, application or certificate provided by the city. 
(d)  Fees. Building contractors' per-annum registration fees shall be fixed periodically by the city council. Registration fees shall be paid in full at the time of issuance of the registration certification. 
(e)  Transfer of certification. Each certification issued under this section is granted to and shall be accepted by the building contractor under the conditions that the certification is not transferable, and after issuance no such certification shall be transferred by the city or the building contractor to another individual or entity. 
(f)  Display of certification. Each certification issued under this section shall be posted conspicuously by the building contractor in the place of business of the building contractor or shall be carried on his person or in the vehicle used in such business. Such certification shall be exhibited to any authorized enforcement officer when requested. 
(g)  Suspension or revocation of certification. Each certification granted under this section is a mere permit to engage in the business only so long as such business is conducted in a lawful manner. The mayor and city council hereby reserves the right to revoke or suspend any certification granted under this section if the building contractor, or the building contractor's agent or employee acting within the scope of his employment, violates this section or any other city, county, state or federal law. If, after issuance of a certification, the city desires to revoke such certification, written notice shall be given to the building contractor, which notice shall specify the violation with which the building contractor is charged and a date, time, and place at which a hearing shall be held with regard to the violation. The building contractor shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing, shall have the right to be represented by counsel, and shall have the right to introduce and submit evidence in opposition to such revocation. 
(Code 2005, § 30-3; Ord. No. 01223, §§ 1—4, 6—8, 12-10-2001) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
State Law reference— Authority to register building and repair contractors during an emergency, O.C.G.A. §§ 38-3-28, 38-3-56; Emergency Management Act definitions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3.  
Sec. 30-4. - Curfew during state of emergency. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Curfew means a regulation requiring the withdrawal from any person not otherwise exempt from this section from appearing in certain public areas during specified hours. 
Exempt individuals, unless otherwise specified in the resolution implementing the curfew, means and includes those individuals engaged in the provision of designated essential services, such as fire, law enforcement, and emergency medical services, military services and utility emergency repairs. The resolution may, in the discretion of the mayor and city council, also exempt regular employees of local industries traveling to and from their jobs with appropriate identification, news media employees, and building and repair contractors, properly registered according to section 30-3, performing activities related to construction, repair, renovation, or improvement of buildings and other structures damaged during the disaster or emergency. 
State of emergency, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), means a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary effort in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. 
(b)  Institution of curfew. 
(1)  Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the mayor and city council, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the mayor and city council, its designee or the emergency interim successor may adopt a resolution instituting a curfew when it is determined necessary to protect and safeguard the people and property of the city. 
(2)  All of the territory of the city shall be subject to the terms of the curfew, unless otherwise specified in the resolution. 
(3)  The resolution instituting the curfew shall include the dates and hours that the curfew shall be in effect. 
(c)  Prohibited acts during curfew. It shall be prohibited for any person, other than exempt individuals, to appear in public in the territory subject to the curfew, including, but not limited to, streets, highways, alleys, sidewalks, vacant lots, parks, public buildings or any other public places in all or a delineated part of the city, during the stated hours of the curfew. 
(Code 2005, § 30-4; Ord. No. 01224, §§ 1—3, 12-10-2001) 
State Law reference— Protection of health and safety, O.C.G.A. §§ 38-3-27, 38-3-28; Emergency Management Act definitions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3.  
Secs. 30-5—30-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 30-27. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency management means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions, other than those functions for which military forces or other state and federal agencies are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, of manmade or natural origin. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, and warning services, communications, defense from radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for and carrying out of such functions. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-1; Code 2005, § 30-31) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 30-28. - County emergency management office; emergency management coordinator. 
(a)  In agreement with the governing officials of cities and/or towns within the county, there is hereby established the county emergency management office. The commissioner of the county, with concurrence of officials of cities and towns within the county, shall nominate, for appointment by the governor, a coordinator of emergency management for the entire county. A deputy director of emergency management shall be appointed by the mayor to serve on the staff of the county emergency management organization. 
(b)  The emergency management coordinator is charged with the following duties: 
(1)  Represent the governing official of the county and cities and/or towns therein on matters pertaining to emergency preparedness. 
(2)  Assist county and city officials in organizing county and city departments for emergency operations. 
(3)  Develop, in conjunction with city and county departments and agencies, the county plan for emergency functions set forth in section 30-27. Such plan will be in consonance with the state emergency management plan and shall be submitted to the governing officials of the county and the cities and/or towns therein for approval and thence to the state emergency management director for approval. 
(4)  Maintain the emergency management office in carrying out the day-to-day administration of the county emergency management program, including the rendering of required reports to the state emergency management office. 
(5)  Render reports, such as financial reports, daily activity reports, etc., as required by governing officials in keeping with good business practices. 
(6)  Procure, with the authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the county emergency operating center. 
(7)  Coordinate the activities of the county emergency operating center staff during periods of a declared emergency, under the supervision of county governing officials. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-2; Code 2005, § 30-32)  
Sec. 30-29. - County emergency management organization. 
(a)  The county emergency management organization shall be established around existing city and county departments and agencies and the emergency functions listed in section 30-27 are assigned as follows: 
Emergency Functions Assignments 
Department 	Emergency Functions 
Executive (county and city elected 
officials) 	Direction and control; public information; supply finances 
Police (county sheriff's office, city police departments) 	Security; movement; search; communications; warning 
Fire control (city and county firefighting units) 	Fire control; rescue; damage assessment 
Public works and engineering 	Utilities and public services 
restoration; hazards analysis 
Human resources, including: 	Human needs, including: 
Department of family and children services 	Welfare 
Division of physical health 	Health control 
Hospital services 	Medical and mortuary services 
Ambulance services 	Casualty transport 
Emergency management 	Shelter; relief; assistance in industrial and institutional emergency planning 
 
(b)  Heads of departments listed in subsection (a) of this section are responsible for developing the plan for their assigned emergency function. Such plans will be submitted through the emergency management coordinator to the county commission and governing officials of cities and/or towns for approval. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-3; Code 2005, § 30-33)  
Sec. 30-30. - Emergency powers. 
In the event of a manmade or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States or any other emergency which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the county, the county commissioner, jointly with the mayors of the cities and/or towns or, in their absence, a legally appointed successor, or the city clerk, may declare that a state of emergency exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise, for such period as such state of emergency exists or continues, the following emergency powers: 
(1)  To appropriate and expend funds, execute contracts, and obtain and distribute equipment, materials, and supplies for emergency management purposes. 
(2)  To provide for the health and safety of persons and property, including emergency assistance to the victims of any emergency or disaster resulting from manmade or natural causes or enemy attack, and to direct and coordinate the development of emergency management plans and programs in accordance with the policies and plans set by the federal and state emergency management agencies. 
(3)  To appoint, employ, remove, or provide, with or without compensation, chiefs of services, warning personnel, rescue teams, auxiliary fire and police personnel, and other emergency management workers. 
(4)  To establish a primary and one or more secondary control centers to serve as command posts during an emergency or disaster. 
(5)  Subject to the order of the governor or the chief executive of the political subdivision, to assign and make available for duty the employees, property, or equipment of the subdivision relating to firefighting, engineering, rescue, health, medical and related services, and to police, transportation, construction, and similar items or services for emergency management purposes, within or outside of the physical limits of the subdivision. 
(6)  In addition to the powers and authorities stated in subsections (1) through (5) of this section, to acquire, temporarily or permanently, by purchase, lease, or otherwise, sites required for installation of temporary housing units for disaster victims; and to enter into whatever arrangements, including purchase of temporary housing units and payment of transportation charges, which are necessary to prepare or equip such sites to utilize the housing units. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-4; Code 2005, § 30-34) 
State Law reference— Emergency management powers, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27.  
Sec. 30-31. - Volunteers. 
All persons, other than officers and employees of the cities, towns and county, performing emergency functions pursuant to this article, shall serve without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as county officers and employees. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-5; Code 2005, § 30-35) 
State Law reference— Liability of volunteers during natural disaster, O.C.G.A. § 51-1-29.2; no liability for official acts, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-3; no liability for failure to perform, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-2; immunity of emergency management workers, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-35.  
Sec. 30-32. - Offenses. 
It shall be an offense, punishable as provided by section 1-7, during an emergency, to: 
(1)  Willfully obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article or in the performance of any duty imposed upon him by virtue of this article. 
(2)  Do any act forbidden by any lawful rules or regulations issued pursuant to this article if such act is of such a nature as to give assistance to the enemy or to imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of the city or to prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof. 
(3)  Wear or carry or display without authority any mark or identification specified by the emergency management organization. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-6; Code 2005, § 30-36) 
State Law reference— Penalty for violation, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-7.  
Sec. 30-33. - Interpretation. 
This article shall be construed liberally in order to effectuate its purpose. 
(Code 1990, § 4-3-7; Code 2005, § 30-37) 
State Law reference— Liberal construction, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-6.  
Chapter 34 - COURTS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 34-1—34-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COURT 
 
Sec. 34-19. - Written summons required; rights of accused. 
Any person who is charged with any offense against any of the ordinances of the city shall be served with written summons informing him of the nature of the charge against him, shall have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his behalf, shall have a speedy trial before the judge, shall be confronted with the witnesses against him, and shall have the privilege of cross examination. The accused shall have the privilege of defending himself by counsel or by himself, as to him shall seem proper. No one shall be convicted without the opportunity of being heard in his own defense. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-1; Code 2005, § 34-31)  
Sec. 34-20. - Contents and service of summons. 
The judge shall designate a court clerk who shall, in all cases where complaint is made or information given of any violation of any of the laws and ordinances of the city, issue a summons directed to the accused requiring the defendant to appear before the judge to answer the charge, which summons shall contain the offense and the time and the place of trial, bear teste in the name of the mayor, be signed by the court clerk and be directed to the chief of police or designee or other officer or member of the police department to be executed. The summons shall be executed by serving a copy upon the accused in person or by leaving it at his residence. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-2; Code 2005, § 34-32)  
Sec. 34-21. - Failure to obey summons. 
Any person summoned who shall fail, neglect, or refuse to appear or to render a satisfactory showing for such failure, neglect, or refusal to appear and answer the charge shall be in contempt of court, and the case may be continued to such time as the court may direct. The court shall issue an order requiring the chief of police or other members of the police department to arrest the offender and bring him before the court to answer the contempt charge, and it shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep the offender in custody until he is brought before the court unless he gives bond for his appearance as provided by law. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-3; Code 2005, § 34-33) 
State Law reference— Fines and penalties, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-32-1, 36-32-5.  
Sec. 34-22. - Witnesses. 
(a)  Whenever the attendance of any witness may be required before the court to establish any fact, the court clerk shall issue a subpoena directed to the witness stating the time and the place of trial and the parties to the case. Such subpoena shall bear teste in the name of the mayor and be served as other summons by the chief of police or any police officer. 
(b)  If any person so summoned as a witness shall fail, neglect, or refuse to attend the trial or render, at the time, a sufficient excuse in the judgment of the court, the defaulting witness shall be in contempt of court. If the case is continued on account of the witness's absence, the court may issue attachment against the witness requiring him to show cause or on the day appointed for trial why he should not be further dealt with for contempt; and the chief of police, by virtue of the attachment, shall arrest such person, or cause him to be arrested so as to have him before the judge at such time as he may appoint for further hearing of the original complaint. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-4; Code 2005, § 34-34)  
Sec. 34-23. - Continuances. 
Where the ends of justice may require, all cases may be continued. All continuances shall be addressed to the sound discretion of the court under the rules governing the superior courts of the state. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-5; Code 2005, § 34-35)  
Sec. 34-24. - Court rules. 
The municipal court shall be controlled by the rules of the superior court as far as they are applicable to the municipal court and a sound construction of the Charter and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-6; Code 2005, § 34-36)  
Sec. 34-25. - Penalties. 
(a)  All offenders against the laws and ordinances of the city shall be tried by the judge, and the court may impose such punishment as is provided by the laws and ordinances of the city for the offenses of which the offender may be guilty. 
(b)  For violation of any ordinance or any section of any ordinance for which no particular penalty has been prescribed, the court may impose, in its discretion, punishment as stated in section 1-7. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-7; Code 2005, § 34-37) 
State Law reference— Authority to impose fines, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-32-1, 36-32-5.  
Sec. 34-26. - Collection of unpaid fines. 
The clerk of the court may issue an execution, where any fine is imposed by the judge to be levied upon the goods, chattels, lands, and tenements of the person fined if such fine is not immediately paid, which execution shall bear teste in the name of the mayor and be signed officially by the clerk and be directed to the sheriff or deputy sheriff of the county. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-8; Code 2005, § 34-38)  
Sec. 34-27. - Bond forfeitures. 
(a)  All bonds given by persons for their appearance before the judge to answer for the violation of any city law shall, upon failure of the principal to appear, be forfeited in the manner provided in this section. 
(b)  A bond forfeiture occurs at the end of the court day upon the failure of appearance of a principal of any bond or recognizance given for the appearance of that person. 
(1)  An appearance bond shall not be forfeited unless the clerk of the court gave the surety at least 72 hours' written notice, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, before the time of the required appearance of the principal. 
(2)  Notice shall not be necessary if the time for appearance is within 72 hours from the time of arrest, provided the time for appearance is stated on the bond, or where the principal is given actual notice in open court. 
(c)  The judge shall, at the end of the court day, upon the failure of the principal to appear, forfeit the bond and order an execution hearing not sooner than 120 days but not later than 150 days after such failure to appear. Notice of the execution hearing shall be served within ten days of such failure to appear by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery to the surety at the address listed on the bond or by personal service to the surety within ten days of such failure to appear at its home office or to its designated registered agent. Service shall be considered complete upon the mailing of such certified notice. If, at the execution hearing, it is determined that judgment should be entered, the judge shall so order and a writ of fieri facias shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the court where such judgment is entered. The provisions of this subsection shall apply to all bail bonds, whether returnable to superior court, state court, probate court, magistrate court, or municipal court. 
(Code 1990, § 2-4-9; Code 2005, § 34-39) 
State Law reference— Authority of municipal court to prescribe procedure for forfeiture of appearance bonds, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-4; when forfeiture occurs, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-70; execution procedure on bond, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-71.  
Secs. 34-28—34-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL COURT PROSECUTOR 
 
Sec. 34-46. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "Tallapoosa Office of Prosecuting Attorney of the Municipal Court Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(40), 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 34-47. - Findings and intent. 
The ordinance from which this article is derived is adopted to address requirements made under state law for the city to pass an ordinance or resolution creating the office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court should the city choose to hire or have a prosecuting attorney of the municipal court. Under state law, in order to have a municipal court prosecutor, the city must pass an ordinance or resolution and provide to the prosecuting attorneys' council of the state a copy of the same. The city is also required to submit the name of the person appointed to be the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court within 30 days of such appointment in order to maintain the office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court. It is therefore the intent of the city to comply with state law, particularly O.C.G.A. tit. 15, ch. 18, art. 5, and to enact the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(41), 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 34-48. - Establishment of office. 
The office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court is hereby established for the purpose of providing representation of the city in matters pertaining to ordinance violations of the city and state offenses enforceable in the municipal court as allowed by state law. The prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall be a part-time position. 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(42), 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 34-49. - Qualifications. 
Any person appointed as the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court of the city shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia and admitted to practice before the trial and appellate courts of the state. Nothing in this article shall prevent the city from appointing the city attorney to be the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court, so long as all other requirements under the law are met. 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(43), 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 34-50. - Oath. 
The prosecuting attorney of the municipal court for the city shall take and subscribe to the following oath: 
"I swear (or affirm) that I will well, faithfully, and impartially and without fear, favor, or affection discharge my duties as prosecuting attorney of the municipal court for the City of Tallapoosa." 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(44), 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 34-51. - Term of office. 
Unless otherwise provided by the city Charter, the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court shall serve a term of office of one year. Said term shall automatically renew unless revoked by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(45), 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 34-52. - Jurisdiction, duties, and authority. 
The office of prosecuting attorney of the municipal court for the city shall have the duty and authority to represent the city as defined by the city charter and by state law, particularly as described in O.C.G.A. § 15-18-96. 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(46), 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 34-53. - Assistant prosecuting attorney. 
If the city council believes that there is a need for an assistant prosecuting attorney, the prosecuting attorney of the municipal court may appoint one or more assistant prosecuting attorneys whose appointment shall be ratified by the city council before becoming an assistant prosecuting attorney for the municipal court. Such assistant prosecuting attorney shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia or satisfy the provisions of the Third Year Practice Act, found in O.C.G.A. § 15-18-22. 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(47), 9-10-2012)  
Sec. 34-54. - Ratification. 
This article shall ratify all actions that have been taken by the persons acting in the positions of the office of the prosecuting attorney for the municipal court to date as authorized by the mayor and the city council. 
(Ord. No. 01276, § 1(48), 9-10-2012)  
Chapter 36 - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ENTERPRISE ZONES 
 
Sec. 36-1. - Establishment of enterprise zones within the city. 
The city does hereby establish enterprise zones for the purpose of economic development in designated areas of the city suffering from unemployment, general distress and blight in addition to underdevelopment. The enterprise zones hereby created within the city are established by the Enterprise Zone Employment Act of 1997, hereinafter referred to as the "Act," and to provide employment to residents of such an area and the city in general. 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(95-1), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-2. - Designated zones. 
The mayor and city council does hereby designate the areas described in exhibit A attached to the ordinance from which this chapter is derived and incorporated herein as section 36-9 as enterprise zones to be known as the "North Tallapoosa Enterprise Zone" and the "Tallapoosa Interstate Regional Business Activity Enterprise Zone." 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(95-2), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-3. - Finding of qualifications. 
The mayor and city council find that the two areas delineated in section 36-2 meet the qualifications of the Act. 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(95-3), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-4. - Business incentives. 
The mayor and city council hereby ordains and declares that upon designation of the area as an enterprise zone, the city, in partnership with the county, may provide the following incentives in the area, including tax incentives, to qualifying businesses, in accordance with the definition of such businesses outlined in the Act, which are not applicable throughout the city or county: 
(1)  The city and the county may exempt qualifying businesses as outlined in the Act and further in section 36-9, from state, county and municipal ad valorem property taxes, excluding property taxes imposed by school districts, that would otherwise be levied on the qualifying business and service enterprises in accordance with the following schedule: 
a.  Up to 100 percent of the property taxes may be exempt for the first five years; 
b.  Up to 80 percent of the property taxes may be exempt for the next two years; 
c.  Up to 60 percent of the property taxes may be exempt for the next year; 
d.  Up to 40 percent of the property taxes may be exempt for the next year; and 
e.  Up to 20 percent of the property tax may be exempt for the last year. 
(2)  Other incentives that may be granted will be negotiated on a case-by-case basis by the city, and could include exemption from any or all of the following: 
a.  Building permit fees. 
b.  Sign permit fees. 
c.  Business license administrative fees. 
d.  Rezoning fees. 
e.  Engineering fees. 
f.  Other local fees authorized by the mayor and city council, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(95-4), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-5. - Authorization to negotiate enterprise zone incentives. 
The mayor and city council, or their official designated representative, is the authorized agency to act in all matters pertaining to the enterprise zone and reserves the power to grant the incentives listed in section 36-4 to qualifying businesses in accordance with the authorization powers granted local governments in the administration of the enterprise zone in the Act. This authority shall be exercised on a case-by-case basis. 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(95-5), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-6. - Specific authorization to negotiate; liaison with state agencies, on behalf of the mayor and city council. 
The mayor and city council duly authorizes the city manager and/or the mayor to act as representative of the city as liaison for communication with the state department of community affairs, the state department of economic development, the business community, and all others to oversee the enterprise zone activities and administration, and communications with qualified businesses, as outlined in section 36-10. 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(95-6), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-7. - Authorization to administer enterprise zone. 
The mayor and city council has the power to administer, require, and enforce compliance with the provisions of this chapter and such administrative rules or regulations adopted hereinafter by way of resolution or as contained in section 36-10, including, but not limited to, reports and data information from businesses within the enterprise zone to verify compliance with this chapter and state law. 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(95-7), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-8. - Authorization to enter into a contractual relationship regarding specific available incentives in the enterprise zones, and remedies for failure to comply with contract. 
(a)  A qualifying business shall consent to enter into a contractual agreement that outlines the incentives offered to the business and a guideline for the recapture, revocation, or reimbursement of incentive values should the terms of the contract be violated by the target business. 
(b)  Evaluation of criteria designated in the state law for the city's enterprise zones: North Tallapoosa Enterprise Zone and the Tallapoosa Interstate Regional Business Activity Enterprise Zone. 
(1)  Enterprise zone 1: North Tallapoosa Enterprise Zone. 
a.  Pervasive poverty: 
1.  Poverty rates for this proposed enterprise zone are shown in the following Census tract data (2010 Census information): 
131439804005: Poverty rate is 28.1 percent. 
2.  Abutting 131439804005 are the following tracts: 
131439802004: Poverty rate is 5.1 percent. 
131439803004: Poverty rate is 6.5 percent. 
b.  General distress. Evidence of general distress: 
1.  High rate of vacancy in existing store fronts. 
2.  Poor, deferred maintenance on many existing structures and parking lots throughout the enterprise zone. 
3.  Underutilization of valuable land. 
c.  Underdevelopment: 
1.  The high rate of vacancy, despite the availability of utilizable retail store fronts. 
2.  The high rate of unused, vacant land throughout the zone. 
3.  Building permit issuance for residential development in the zone has been non-existent the last five years. 
4.  Commercial/industrial permits in the zone have been severely decreased in the last five years. 
(2)  Enterprise zone 2: The Tallapoosa Interstate Regional Business Activity Enterprise Zone. 
a.  Pervasive poverty: 
1.  Poverty rates for this proposed enterprise zone are shown in the following Census tract data: 
131439804005: Poverty rate is 28.1 percent. 
b.  General distress: 
1.  The area surrounding Exit 5 off of I-20 has a number of abandoned and dilapidated structures which are preventing proper development of the interchange. 
2.  The current design of the GA 100 and the Exit 5 interchange is problematic as it restricts traffic flow, currently as well as future development. GA 100 throughout the interchange area needs to include two lanes in each direction and a dedicated turning lane for each on ramp, east and west, providing access for I-20. This would allow long-term successful, intensive development around the interchange without creating undesirable congestion. This intensive development would provide a large quantity of jobs for the people in the enterprise zone district and surrounding region, especially for people living in Census Tract 104. 
3.  Hundreds of acres of land surrounding this interchange lie undeveloped and exceptionally underutilized. 
4.  Poor general condition of the area. 
c.  Underdevelopment. Over the last five years, the area surrounding Exit 5 has seen a severe reduction and elimination of development, despite being in close proximity to almost 40,000 cars travelling by daily. The utter lack of building permit issuance that last five years, and the preponderance of undeveloped land, is excellent evidence of the need for development incentives. 
(c)  Building permit issuance for both of the proposed enterprise zones, in comparison to building permit issuance for the remainder of the city indicates that there is a substantial decrease in development, improvement and upkeep in the enterprise zones as compared to the remainder of the city. 
(d)  From 2008 through 2012, building permits issued within the enterprise zones, which encompass a large geographical area of the city and almost the entire retail and manufacturing areas of the city's incorporated area, were substantially lower than the remainder of the city. Permits issued over this time period within the proposed enterprise zones number 60 permits; permits issued throughout the remainder of the city numbered 94. This data indicates economic activity within the enterprise zones is 36 percent less than the economic activity throughout the rest of the city, and, considering the large undeveloped tracks, and the exceptionally high vacancy rate of existing buildings, that the geographical area proposed for designation as an enterprise zone is experiencing substantial underdevelopment. The state law requires that development activity in the nominated area be at least 20 percent lower than other areas within the local government's jurisdiction. This building permit data provides adequate evidence that this criteria has been met. 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(95-8), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-9. - Enterprise zone boundaries. 
(a)  Enterprise zone 1: North Tallapoosa Enterprise Zone. Please see North Tallapoosa Enterprise Zone map below. 
(b)  Enterprise zone 2: The Tallapoosa Interstate Regional Business Activity Center Enterprise Zone. Please see Tallapoosa Interstate Regional Business Activity Enterprise Zone map below. 
ENTERPRISE ZONE #1 (NORTH TALLAPOOSA ENTERPRISE ZONE) AND ENTERPRISE ZONE #2 (THE TALLAPOOSA INTERSTATE REGIONAL BUSINESS ACTIVITY ENTERPRISE ZONE) 
 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(exh. A), 4-13-2013)  
Sec. 36-10. - Enterprise zone administrative policies. 
(a)  Incentives and city responsibility. The incentives outlined in this chapter will be administered by the city. The city will have the responsibility to process applications, convene a preliminary review committee as applications are received, confer with the county, and prepare final documents for mayor and council approval. The city will keep the state department of community affairs informed of enterprise zone designation and will maintain annual employment records to be filed with the department by qualifying companies by April 1 of each year. Additionally, the city will coordinate all marketing and communications regarding the enterprise zone. 
(b)  Description of the incentives and qualifying businesses. The city and the county, in agreeing to create the enterprise zones shown in section 36-9, agree to abate ad valorem property tax for qualifying businesses for ten years as outlined in this chapter and in accordance with the definitions of qualifying business as set forth in the State of Georgia Enterprise Zone Employment Act of 1997 as follows: 
(1)  The term "business enterprise" means any business which is engaged primarily in retail, manufacturing, warehousing and distribution, processing, telecommunications, tourism, research and development, new residential construction, and residential rehabilitation. 
(2)  The term "service enterprise" means an entity which is engaged primarily in finance, insurance and real estate listed under the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) Codes 60 through 67, according to the 1987 edition of the Federal Office of Management and Budget Standard Industrial Classification Manual. 
a.  A qualifying business or service enterprise which increases employment by five or more new full-time equivalents in an area designated as an enterprise zone and which provided additional economic stimulus in such zone. Whenever possible, ten percent of new employees shall be low-income or moderate-income individuals. Such qualifying business or service enterprise may be new, an expansion or reinvestment of an existing qualifying business or service enterprise, or a successor to such qualifying business or service business. 
b.  Any qualifying business or service business enterprise which employs at least 5,000 persons and which creates ten or more new full-time job equivalents that did not exist prior to July 1, 1997, and which provided additional economic stimulus in such zone. 
c.  Any business receiving tax abatements according to the schedule outlined above must maintain a minimum of five new full-time job equivalents to maintain eligibility for the tax exemption. A form for reporting annual employment must be filed with the city, for its review and records. 
d.  Any project that consists of the rehabilitation of an existing structure that results in the value of the improvement exceeding the value of the land by a ratio of 5:1 is eligible for the incentives offered whether or not the project is carried out by a qualifying business or service enterprise. 
(c)  Additional considerations. The Enterprise Zone Employment Act of 1997 (O.C.G.A. § 36-88-4(b)) empowers the local governing body to make a case-by-case determination of the eligibility of each business for enterprise zone tax abatements and other incentives. Among the considerations may be the following: 
(1)  The value of the business to the economic health and well-being of the city and the county and its citizens. 
(2)  Capital investment or reinvestment by the business equal to or greater than the amount of ad valorem tax abated over the first five years of the tax incentive. 
(3)  Consideration for meeting some or all of the following criteria: 
a.  Locating in a vacant building. 
b.  Demolishing a pre-existing or abandoned structure. (Note: Does not apply to historical structures.) 
c.  Assembling four or more tracts of land for one project. 
d.  Creating jobs above the state threshold. 
e.  Creating jobs for residents of the enterprise zone and surrounding area. 
f.  Incorporating aesthetic enhancements (i.e., landscaping, type of facade material used, exclusion of billboards). 
(Ord. No. 01279, exh. 2013-A(exh. B), 4-13-2013)  
Chapter 38 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 38-1. - Designation of city council posts. 
The five elected city council members shall be elected pursuant to a designation of posts. The city council positions shall be designated as post number 1, post number 2, post number 3, post number 4 and post number 5. Anyone seeking election to the city council shall designate the particular post for which that person is seeking election. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-1; Code 2005, § 38-1)  
Sec. 38-2. - Election officials. 
The mayor and city council shall, by resolution, appoint every two years a municipal election superintendent, election managers, registrars, absentee ballot clerk and any other officials as are necessary, all of whom shall exercise those powers and duties set forth in O.C.G.A. tit. 21, ch. 2 (O.C.G.A. § 21-2-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-2; Code 2005, § 38-2) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-52 et seq. 
State Law reference— Municipal powers, etc., O.C.G.A. § 21-2-70 et seq.  
Sec. 38-3. - Closing of voter registration. 
Voter registration for city elections shall be closed as of the close of business on the fifth Monday prior to the date of the election. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-3; Code 2005, § 38-3) 
State Law reference— Registration, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-224.  
Sec. 38-4. - Notice of opening and closing dates for qualifying. 
Notice of the opening and closing dates for candidates to qualify shall be published in the call for election, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 21-1-132. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-4; Code 2005, § 38-4) 
State Law reference— Filing notice of candidacy, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-132.  
Sec. 38-5. - Qualification fees. 
The qualification fee shall be three percent of the total gross salary of the office paid in the preceding calendar year, including all supplements authorized by law, if a salaried office. If not a salaried office, a reasonable fee shall be set by the mayor and city council, such fee not to exceed three percent of the income derived from such city office by the person holding the office for the preceding year or more than $35.00. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-5; Code 2005, § 38-5) 
State Law reference— Qualification fees, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-131.  
Sec. 38-6. - Polling place. 
The polling place for all city elections shall be as established from time to time by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 2-2-6; Code 2005, § 38-6) 
State Law reference— Polling places, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-260.  
Chapter 42 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 42-1—42-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Abatement of nuisances affecting health, § 10-129 et seq. 
State Law reference— Jurisdiction of municipal court over determination and abatement of nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 42-19. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Junk vehicle means a vehicle that is in an obvious inoperable condition (including those whose tires have been removed for more than 72 continuous hours, but are otherwise operational) or has no license plate or does not have a current state registration sticker affixed, or is not currently insured with the minimum state liability automobile insurance. Automobile liability insurance shall be required for all vehicles within the city, unless they have been "junked" and are currently stored in a licensed junkyard. 
Nuisance means anything which causes hurt, inconvenience, or damage to another, provided that the hurt, inconvenience, or damage complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but rather such as would affect an ordinary reasonable person; and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. 
Nuisance per se means an act, occupation, or structure which is a nuisance at all times and under any circumstances, regardless of location or surroundings. 
Private nuisance means a nuisance limited in its injurious effects to one of a few individuals. 
Public nuisance means a nuisance which damages all persons who come within the sphere of its operation, though it may vary in its effects on individuals. 
(Code 1990, § 11-2-1; Code 2005, § 42-31; Ord. No. 1239, § 1(11-1-9(a)), 3-10-2003) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Public and private nuisances, O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-2, 41-2-3.  
Sec. 42-20. - Abatement generally. 
Any nuisance existing within the corporate limits of the city, except a nuisance excepted in this article, shall be abated in the manner set forth in this article. 
(Code 1990, § 11-2-2; Code 2005, § 42-32)  
Sec. 42-21. - Declaration of nuisances; authority to abate. 
(a)  It is found and declared that there is the existence of property or occupancy of dwellings or other buildings or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business occupancy or use and which are not in compliance with the general nuisance law, applicable state minimum standard codes as adopted by ordinance or operation of law or any optional building, fire, life safety, or other codes relative to the safe use of real property and real property improvements adopted by ordinance in the city, and which constitute a hazard to the health, safety, and welfare of the people of the city, and that a public necessity exists for the clearing of the property to bring such property into compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances, and the repair, closing, or demolition of such dwellings, buildings, or structures. 
(1)  It is found and declared that, where there is in existence a condition or use of real estate which renders adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation, such use is dangerous and injurious to the health, safety, and welfare of the city and a public necessity exists for the repair of such condition or the cessation of such use which renders the adjacent real estate unsafe or inimical to safe human habitation. 
(2)  Whenever the chief of police or his designee finds that there exists in the city property not in compliance with general nuisance law, and not in compliance with applicable codes, dwellings, buildings, or structures which are unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use due to dilapidation and not in compliance with applicable codes, which have defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities, or which lack adequate ventilation, light or sanitation facilities, or where other conditions exist rendering such property, dwellings, buildings, or structures unsafe unsanitary or dangerous or detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare, or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city, or vacant, dilapidated dwellings, buildings, or structures in which drug crimes are being committed, power is conferred upon the city to exercise its police power to bring the property into full compliance with applicable codes and ordinances in the manner provided in this Code and under O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-8 through 41-2-17. 
(b)  All the provisions of this Code and O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-8 through 41-2-17, including method and procedure, may be applied to private property where there exists a public nuisance or an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions to those persons residing or working in the vicinity. A finding by the police chief or his designee, or the health officer, that such property is a health or safety hazard shall constitute prima facie evidence that the property is in violation of this Code and O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-8 through 41-2-17. 
(Code 2005, § 42-33) 
State Law reference— Property declared nuisance, authority of city to abate, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7.  
Sec. 42-22. - Enforcement officer. 
The chief of police or his designee is designated to exercise the powers prescribed by this article. 
(Code 2005, § 42-34) 
State Law reference— Designation of enforcement official, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.  
Sec. 42-23. - Duties of property owners. 
It is the duty of the owner of every dwelling, building, structure, or property within the city to construct and maintain such property, dwelling, building, or structure in conformance with applicable codes in force within the city or such ordinances which regulate and prohibit activities on property and which declare it to be a public nuisance to maintain such property or construct or maintain any dwelling, building, structure, or property in violation of such codes or ordinances. 
(Code 2005, § 42-35) 
State Law reference— Duty imposed on citizens of municipality to properly maintain property, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.  
Secs. 42-24—42-49. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADDITIONAL PROHIBITED CONDUCT 
 
Sec. 42-50. - Grass and weeds. 
(a)  Prohibited conditions. For the purpose of preventing the spread of diseases and the breeding of mosquitoes and other insects, and for the protection of the health of the citizens and residents of the city, it shall be unlawful for any owner and/or tenant in possession of any land to allow weeds, grass or other vegetation (except vegetation commonly classed as growing crops, trees, or ornamental or other shrubbery or nursery plants) to grow on such land at any time above the average height of six inches. Upon the weeds, grass, or other vegetation covered by this section reaching that average height, the owner and/or tenant in possession shall be required to cut the weeds, grass or other vegetation at his own expense. 
(b)  Failure to comply. Any owner and/or tenant failing or refusing to comply with this section after three days' notice from the chief of police or any police officer designated by him shall be subject to the nuisance abatement procedures of this article. 
(c)  Exemptions. Exemptions are provided on an automatic and permitted basis. 
(1)  Automatic exemptions. Automatic exemptions to this section shall be issued, and a comprehensive list maintained, by the department of planning, under the following conditions. Exemptions are perpetual unless the property owner or tenant in possession fails to maintain the city right-of-way if necessary or begins to develop the property. If the automatic designation is lost, then a permitted exemption must be obtained or the entire property must be maintained in accordance with this section: 
a.  All property zoned agriculture and maintained/operated for that purpose by the property owner or tenant in possession, provided that the owner maintains the city right-of-way abutting his land which is adjacent to city streets in accordance with this section. 
b.  All property over 1.1 acres of land and zoned either single-family residential and multifamily residential, provided that such parcels are completely surrounded by other undeveloped parcels, professional and institutional (P and I), all commercial, and all manufacturing zoning classes which are vacant and in a current state of being overgrown (trees and natural vegetation having created a visual screen to the interior of the property), provided that the owner maintains the city right-of-way abutting his land which is adjacent to city streets in accordance with this section. 
c.  All property over 2.0 acres of land in any zoning classification which is vacant and in a current state of being overgrown (trees and natural vegetation having created a visual screen to the interior of the property). 
d.  All property under or over 1.1 acres of land which does not have a public street abutting any of its perimeter. This category, as applied to specific parcels, is subject to change in the future as roads are installed over old city rights-of-way. 
e.  Developed property, regardless of acreage, which when constructed or as currently in existence has been developed such that tree removal was avoided, provided that the owner maintains the city right-of-way abutting his land which is adjacent to city streets in accordance with this section. 
(2)  Permitted exemptions. A permit shall be issued by the planning coordinator or the city manager or his designee. The permit shall have an annual fee of $25.00. The initial permit shall expire that upcoming December, and must be renewed annually prior to March 31, or a renewal fee of $25.00, in addition to the annual permit fee, shall be charged if renewed within the following two years after expiration, expiring thenceforth every December. To have a permit issued, the applicant must submit a plat of the applicable property and accompanying deed. The plat must be completed by a registered surveyor. The plat cannot alter the property from that which is described in the deed. The plat shall be applicable only to obtaining the permitted exemption, and shall not be utilized to comply with chapter 90, pertaining to subdivisions, unless the plat fully complies with the stipulations of chapter 90. The plat will display all property lines, names of adjacent property owners, abutting public rights-of-way, improvements and appurtenances added/made to the lot, and any and all easements, and indicate fairly precisely where the area which needs to be exempt lies. Failure to maintain the city right-of-way shall result in the loss of exemption status and require the property owner to comply with all aspects of this section. The following specific conditions must be present for a permit to be issued (under any one of these conditions): 
a.  All vacant, currently undeveloped property lying within any residentially (single-family, multifamily) classified zoning district in excess of 1.1 acres and which is in a current state of being overgrown (trees and natural vegetation having created a visual screen to the interior of the property), provided that the owner maintains the city right-of-way abutting his land which is adjacent to city streets in accordance with this section. 
b.  All vacant, currently undeveloped property lying within any residentially (single-family, multifamily) classified zoning district with less than 1.1 acres and which has undeveloped property abutting the specified parcel on all sides and which is in a current state of being overgrown (trees and natural vegetation having created a visual screen to the interior of the property), provided that the owner maintains the city right-of-way abutting his land which is adjacent to city streets in accordance with this section. 
c.  Automatic exemptions which were lost due to the failure to maintain city right-of-way. The property owner must place the city right-of-way into compliance with this section, and maintain the right-of-way in accordance with this section without city intervention, for the permitted exemption to continue. Failure to maintain the city right-of-way abutting his property which is adjacent to city streets shall result in the loss of exemption status and require the property owner to comply with all aspects of this section. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-3; Code 2005, § 42-61; Ord. No. 01236, 3-10-2003; Ord. No. 01258, exh. 2007-D, 10-8-2007)  
Sec. 42-51. - Accumulations of junk vehicles and vehicle parts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or resident and/or tenant of any property in the city, other than a person who is a licensed junk dealer, to permit to accumulate on such property any automobiles which are in a wholly or partially rusted, wrecked, junked, dismantled or inoperative condition, unless such automobiles are completely enclosed within a building. Citizens who have determined that a vehicle that they are the owner of, and which is in a bad state of repair or condition (such as an antique car), and needs to be rehabilitated and repaired, may, provided they comply with all aspects of this subsection, submit an application to the department of planning, upon a form so dedicated for this purpose and provided to the applicant by the department of planning. This form shall be known as a certificate of automotive rehabilitation. It shall be completed by the property owner and the owner of the vehicle to be rehabilitated, and shall be signed by both if the owners are different. The property owner/vehicle owner shall have two years from the date of issuance of the certificate to complete any and all repairs/renovations to the vehicle, which in a residential district is restricted to passenger cars, vans and pickup trucks (large commercial vehicles are prohibited from being stored/repaired/rehabilitated in residentially zoned land districts). No more than three vehicles may be listed on this certificate per property owner and per individual parcel. The certificate shall be issued and kept on file and a database of all such issued certificates maintained by the department of planning. The certificate shall be issued only if all the following requirements have been fulfilled: 
(1)  Vehicles must be properly registered with the state and have a license plate affixed to the vehicle, and the license plate must contain a current registration sticker. 
(2)  Vehicles must be currently and perpetually insured to standard state minimums for motor vehicle liability insurance. 
(3)  Vehicles must be stored within a completely enclosed building or under a carport or stored on the driveway of the vehicle's owner. If it is to be stored in the driveway, the vehicle must not be placed in the city right-of-way portion of the driveway. 
(4)  The rehabilitation of the automobile must take place in a workmanlike manner. Progress must be continual. A schedule of accomplishments, staged at either a monthly, quarterly or semiannual basis, shall be required. Failure to maintain this schedule of repair shall constitute a basis for revocation of the certificate. The certificate recipient shall be notified by mail that the certificate is to be revoked within 30 days. If the certificate recipient feels this revocation notice has been incorrectly sent, he may appeal to the mayor and city council for relief. If the certificate is revoked, then the vehicle owner shall be subject to the remaining elements of this section. 
(5)  A photograph of the vehicle listed on the certificate must be provided at the time of submitting the application. 
(6)  There is no fee associated with this certificate. However, the mayor and city council reserve the right to institute and amend a fee schedule for this certificate in the future, and to do so by resolution. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police or designee to notify, in writing, the owner or occupant of any premises upon which junk is permitted to accumulate in violation of this section that such material must be removed within ten days from the date of the notice. Any owner or resident and/or tenant failing or refusing to comply with this section shall be subject to the nuisance abatement procedure of this article. 
(c)  Upon the failure, neglect, or refusal of any owner or occupant so notified to remove such junk within the designated time period, the city manager is authorized and empowered to arrange for the removal of such material by the city or by a private individual or firm through contract with the city. 
(d)  The actual cost of such junk removal shall be assessed against the property owner from whose premises the junk is removed, and if the bill for such charges remains unpaid for 30 days after it has been rendered, the charges shall become a lien upon the premises enforceable in the same manner as provided for the collection of unpaid taxes. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-9; Code 2005, § 42-62; Ord. No. 01239, § 1(11-1-9), 3-10-2003) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide by ordinance for the removal and disposal of discarded, dismantled or junked motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4.  
Sec. 42-52. - Accumulations of solid waste. 
It shall be the duty of all persons owning, leasing, renting or otherwise controlling real property within the corporate limits of the city to keep their premises clean and clear of all litter, trash or other substances of like nature. Any person, whether owner, tenant or other party, in control of any real property in the city, who shall, within five days from the service of notice, fail or refuse to clear such premises of such litter, trash or other substance of like nature, shall be subject to the nuisance abatement procedures of this article. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-6; Code 2005, § 42-63) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 82.  
Secs. 42-53—42-77. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ABATEMENT PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 42-78. - Issuance of citations. 
The chief of police or his designee may issue citations for violations of state minimum standard codes and optional building, fire, life safety, and other codes adopted by ordinance, and conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance, and seek to enforce such citations in the municipal court prior to issuing a complaint in rem. 
(Code 2005, § 42-91) 
State Law reference— Authority to issue citation to abate nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.  
Sec. 42-79. - Investigation of violation. 
Whenever a request is filed with the chief of police or his designee by a public authority or by at least five residents of the city charging that any property, dwelling, building, or structure is not in compliance with applicable codes, is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes, is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the chief of police or his designee shall make an investigation or inspection of the specific property, dwelling, building, or structure. 
(Code 2005, § 42-92) 
State Law reference— Request and investigation of violation of code, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.  
Sec. 42-80. - Issuance of complaint; notice of hearing. 
(a)  If the chief of police or his designee's investigation or inspection of the specific property, dwelling, building, or structure identifies that any property, dwelling, building, or structure is not in compliance with applicable codes, is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes, is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the chief of police or his designee may issue a complaint in rem against the property, or against the lot, tract, or parcel of real property on which such dwelling, building, or structure is situated or where such public health hazard or general nuisance exists, and shall cause a summons and a copy of the complaint to be served on the owner and parties in interest in such property, dwelling, building, or structure. 
(b)  The complaint shall identify the subject property or real property by appropriate street address and official tax map reference, identify the owner and parties in interest, state with particularity the factual basis for the action, and contain a statement of the action sought by the chief of police or his designee to abate the alleged nuisance. 
(c)  The summons shall notify the owner and parties in interest that a hearing will be held before the municipal court of the city at a date and time certain. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days and not more than 45 days after the filing of such complaint with the court. 
(d)  The owner and parties in interest shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or by attorney and offer testimony at the time and place fixed for hearing. 
(Code 2005, § 42-93) 
State Law reference— Complaint and notice, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.  
Sec. 42-81. - Determination by court; issuance of order. 
(a)  If, after the notice and hearing provided for in section 42-80, the court determines that the property, dwelling, building, or structure in question is not in compliance with applicable codes, is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use and not in compliance with applicable codes, is vacant and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions, the court shall state in writing findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner and any parties in interest, or those that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing, an order: 
(1)  To bring the property's condition into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation; 
(2)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; or 
(3)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the such dwelling, building, or structure in order to bring it into full compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building, or structure and all debris from the property. 
(b)  For the purposes of this article, the court shall make its determination of "reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure" without consideration of the value of the land on which the structure is situated; provided, however, that costs of the preparation necessary to repair, alter, or improve a structure may be considered. Income and financial status of the owner shall not be factors in the court's determination. The present value of the structure and the costs of repair, alteration, or improvement may be established by affidavits of real estate appraisers with a state appraiser classification as provided in O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 39A (O.C.G.A. § 43-39A-1 et seq.), qualified building contractors, or qualified building inspectors without actual testimony being presented. Costs of repair, alteration, or improvement of the structure shall be the cost necessary to bring the structure into compliance with the applicable city codes relevant to the cited violations. 
(Code 2005, § 42-94) 
State Law reference— Court hearing and finding of nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.  
Sec. 42-82. - Failure to comply with order to bring property's condition into compliance. 
If the owner fails to comply with an order to bring the property's condition into compliance with all applicable codes, the chief of police or his designee may cause the property to brought into compliance with all applicable codes. 
(Code 2005, § 42-95) 
State Law reference— Authority of chief of police or designee to abate nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.  
Sec. 42-83. - Failure to comply with order to repair or demolish structure. 
If the owner fails to comply with an order to repair or demolish the dwelling, building, or structure, the chief of police or his designee may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished.
