Upon completion of the project, the developer is responsible for submitting the as-built data to FEMA in order to obtain the final LOMR. 
(Ord. No. 01259, art. 4, § E, 11-12-2007)  
Sec. 50-83. - Standards for critical facilities. 
(a)  Critical facilities shall not be located in the 100-year floodplain or the 500-year floodplain. 
(b)  All ingress and egress from any critical facility must be protected to the 500-year flood elevation. 
(Ord. No. 01259, art. 4, § F, 11-12-2007)  
Chapter 54 - FRANCHISES  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 54-1—54-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CABLE SERVICES AND OTHER TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 102; zoning, ch. 106. 
State Law reference— Regulations of cable television systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-18-1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 54-19. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cable and/or video franchise fee. The city hereby requires a franchise fee of five percent of gross revenues generated within the city for any cable or video state franchise issued in its corporate boundaries by the state. In the event the state authorized fee increases above five percent, then the city shall be entitled to charge the highest fee allowable by federal and/or state law. 
Cable services means "cable services," as defined in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 and the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, and as may be further amended from time to time (the Cable Act). If the term "cable services" is no longer defined in the Cable Act or the definition in the Cable Act otherwise becomes inapplicable, the term "cable services" shall mean "cable services," as defined in the Cable Act immediately prior to such term no longer being defined in the Cable Act or such definition otherwise becoming inapplicable. 
Cable system means any "cable system," as defined in the Cable Act. 
City council means the city council and its designee or any successor thereto. 
Franchise means an initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued by the city, whether such authorization is designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement or otherwise, which authorizes the occupation and use of the streets to provide telecommunications services. 
Grantee means the legal entity to which is granted the right, authority and responsibility to construct, install, operate and maintain a system of equipment as necessary to furnish, supply and distribute cable or telecommunications services, or both, to inhabitants within the franchise area. 
Person means any individual or any association, firm, partnership, joint venture, corporation or other legally recognized entity, whether for profit or not for profit, but shall not mean the city. 
Street means the surface of, as well as the spaces above and below, any and all streets, alleyways, avenues, highways, boulevards, driveways, bridges, tunnels, parks, parkways, public grounds or waters, and other public rights-of-way within or belonging to the city. 
Telecommunications services means the receipt and/or distribution, through any means, including, without limitation, coaxial cable, optical fiber, or satellite or microwave transmission, of one or more audio, voice or data signals. Telecommunications services includes both cable services and non-cable telecommunications services. 
(Code 2005, § 54-31; Ord. No. 01201, § 1.1, 1-11-1999; Ord. No. 01261, exh. 2008-C(54-31), 3-10-2008) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 54-20. - Delegation of authority by city council; advisory boards. 
Consistent with applicable law, the city council shall have the right to delegate and re-delegate any of its rights or obligations under this article to any body, organization or official, and to revoke any such delegation or re-delegation from time to time. Any such delegation, re-delegation or revocation, no matter how often made, shall not be deemed an amendment to this article or to require the consent of any applicant for a franchise or franchisee. The city council may also establish and appoint one or more advisory boards, with such duration and such number of members as the city council shall determine, to advise it on such of the matters which are the subject of this article. 
(Code 2005, § 54-32; Ord. No. 01201, § 3.2, 1-11-1999)  
Sec. 54-21. - Authorized designee. 
The city hereby authorizes the city manager, upon receipt of notice to the city, of its right to designate a franchise fee for an applicant for, or holder of, an existing state franchise, to provide written notice to the Secretary of State and each applicant for, or holder of, a state franchise within a service area that is wholly or partially located within the city limits, of the franchise fee rate applicable to such applicant or holder of a state franchise. 
(Ord. No. 01261, exh. 2008-C(54-33), 3-10-2008)  
Sec. 54-22. - Notification provided to the city and update of the serviced delivery area. 
The holder of a state franchise who is intending to provide cable service or video service within the city shall notify the city manager of its intention to commence services at least ten days before providing the service in the city. The holder of the state franchise shall update the description of the service area provided in the application for a state franchise, as is applicable to the city, each year not later than January 31 of the year; and shall provide to the city a point of contact that shall be available during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 01261, exh. 2008-C(54-34), 3-10-2008)  
Secs. 54-23—54-47. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - GRANTING AUTHORITY AND FRANCHISING PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 54-48. - Granting authority. 
(a)  No person shall provide cable services or operate a cable system without a franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of this article, and no person shall use or occupy the streets to provide any telecommunications service other than cable services without a franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The city council may grant one or more franchises in accordance with this article, provided that the city council reserves the right to modify any provision of this article by amendment hereof. 
(c)  The grant of any franchise shall be made by adoption of a separate ordinance by the city council and shall be on such terms and conditions as may be specified in the separate ordinance and/or a franchise agreement between the city and the franchisee. 
(d)  Any franchise granted shall be nonexclusive. The city specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, such additional franchises as it deems appropriate and/or itself engage in the provision of telecommunications services. 
(e)  A franchise may be granted for all or any defined portion of the city and for all or less than all telecommunications services, and for telecommunications services for all or less than all purposes. 
(f)  The grant of franchises by the city shall be subject to the provisions of applicable law, such as the provisions in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, governing cable television franchises and renewals thereof. 
(Code 2005, § 54-51; Ord. No. 01201, § 2.1, 1-11-1999)  
Sec. 54-49. - Application requirements. 
(a)  Generally. Applications for franchises shall be submitted in such form and franchises shall be issued on such terms and conditions as the city council may determine, subject to applicable law. 
(b)  Required information. Any application for a franchise shall contain and/or require the following information with respect to the proposed franchise and such other information as the city council shall deem necessary or appropriate: 
(1)  The applicant's name, address, telephone number, and federal employer identification number or social security number; copy of the applicant's corporate charter or partnership agreement, as applicable; and any trade names (and registrations) used by the applicant. 
(2)  A detailed statement of the corporation or business entity organization of the applicant, including, but not limited to, the following, and to whatever extent required by the city: 
a.  The names and the residence and business addresses of all officers and directors of the applicant; 
b.  The names, residence, and business addresses of all persons and entities having any share of the ownership of the applicant and the respective ownership share of each person or entity; 
c.  The names and address of any parent or subsidiary of the applicant, namely, any other business entity owning or controlling the applicant in whole or in part or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the applicant, and a statement describing the nature of any such parent or subsidiary business entity, including, but not limited to, telecommunications or cable systems owned or controlled by the applicant, its parent, and subsidiary, and the areas served thereby; 
d.  A detailed and complete financial statement of the applicant, certified by an independent certified public accountant, for the fiscal year immediately preceding the date of the application under this section, or a letter or other acceptable evidence in writing from a recognized lending institution or funding source, addressed to both the applicant and the city council, setting forth the basis for a study performed by such lending institution or funding source, and a clear statement of its intent as a lending institution or funding source to provide whatever capital shall be required by the applicant to construct and operate the proposed telecommunications or cable system in the city, or a statement from an independent certified public accountant certifying that the applicant has available sufficient free, net, and uncommitted cash resources to construct and operate the proposed cable or telecommunications system in the city; 
e.  A detailed financial plan (pro forma) describing, for each year of the franchise, projected number of subscribers, rates, all revenues, operating expenses, capital expenditures, depreciation schedules, income statements, and a sources and uses of funds statement; and 
f.  A statement identifying, by place and date, any other cable system or telecommunication franchises awarded to the applicant, its parent or subsidiary; the status of such franchises with respect to completion thereof; the total cost of completion of such franchised cable or telecommunication systems; and the amount of the applicant's and its parent's or subsidiary's resources committed to the completion thereof. 
(3)  A detailed description of the proposed plan of operation of the applicant, which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  A description of the cable services and any other telecommunications services proposed to be provided; 
b.  A detailed map indicating all areas proposed to be served, and a proposed time schedule for the installation of all equipment necessary to become operational throughout the entire area to be serviced; 
c.  A statement or schedule setting forth all proposed classifications or rates and charges to be made against subscribers and all rates and charges as to each of such classifications, including installation charges, cable service charges, and any other telecommunications service charges; 
d.  A detailed, informative, and referenced statement describing the actual equipment and operational standards proposed by the applicant; 
e.  A copy of the form of any agreement, undertaking, or other instrument proposed to be entered into between the applicant and any subscriber to cable or telecommunications services; and 
f.  A detailed statement setting forth in its entirety any and all agreements and undertakings, whether formal or informal, written, oral, or implied, existing or proposed to exist between the applicant and any person, which materially relate or pertain to or depend upon the application and the granting of the franchise. 
(4)  A copy of any agreement covering the franchise area, if existing, between the applicant and any utility providing for the use of any facilities of the utility, including, but not limited to, poles, lines, or conduits. 
(5)  Any other details, statements, supplementary information, or references pertinent to the subject matter of such application which shall be required or requested by the city council, or by any other provision of law. 
(c)  Payment of application fees; fees not refundable. No application for a new franchise shall be considered without payment by the applicant of application fees as provided in this section. If a franchise is granted, application fees will not be deemed a credit towards any other fees or sums due by the grantee. If an application is denied, the application fee will not be refunded. 
(1)  Purpose of application fees. The application fees provided by this section will serve to cover the direct and indirect costs incurred by the city in processing the application, evaluating the applicant, and granting a franchise, and shall include, but not be limited to, administrative, engineering, publication, legal, and consultant's expenses. 
(2)  Amount of application fee. The applicant will be expected to pay the reasonable costs of the city in evaluating the application. Notwithstanding any other requirement of this article, each applicant must furnish with its proposal a nonrefundable application fee in the amount of $2,000.00 by certified check or cashier's check made payable to the city. 
(Code 2005, § 54-52; Ord. No. 01201, § 2.2, 1-11-1999)  
Sec. 54-50. - Responsibilities of applicants. 
It shall be the responsibility of each applicant for a franchise to comply with all applicable laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules, regulations and other directives of the city and any federal, state or local governmental authority having jurisdiction. 
(Code 2005, § 54-53; Ord. No. 01201, § 2.3, 1-11-1999)  
Sec. 54-51. - Public availability of applications. 
To the extent determined by the city council, applications for franchises, including any additions, modifications or amendments thereto, shall be available for public inspection at a designated city office during normal business hours. 
(Code 2005, § 54-54; Ord. No. 01201, § 2.4, 1-11-1999)  
Sec. 54-52. - Criteria for evaluation of applications. 
In making any determination under this article as to any application for a franchise, the city council may consider such factors as it deems appropriate and in the public interest, including, without limitation: 
(1)  The adequacy of the proposed compensation to be paid to the city, including the value of any facilities and telecommunications services offered by the applicant to the city; 
(2)  The legal, financial, technical and other appropriate qualifications of the applicant; 
(3)  The ability of the applicant to maintain the property of the city in good condition throughout the term of the franchise; 
(4)  The value and efficiency to the city and its residents of the cable services and other telecommunications services to be provided, including the type of telecommunications services to be provided, as well as alternatives to those services and services that may be precluded by the grant of the franchise; 
(5)  The willingness and ability of the applicant to meet construction and physical requirements and to abide by all purpose and policy conditions, limitations and requirements with respect to the franchise; and 
(6)  Any other public interest factors or considerations deemed pertinent by the city for safeguarding the interests of the city and the public. 
(Code 2005, § 54-55; Ord. No. 01201, § 2.5, 1-11-1999)  
Sec. 54-53. - Procedure for consideration of and action on applications. 
(a)  The city may make such investigations and take or authorize the taking of such other steps as the city council deems necessary or appropriate to consider and act on applications for franchises and determine whether a franchise should be granted to an applicant, and may require the applicant to furnish additional information and data for this purpose. In considering applications, the city council may seek advice from other city officials or bodies, from such other advisory bodies as it may establish or determine appropriate, or from the public, and may request the preparation of one or more reports to be submitted to the city council, which may include recommendations with respect to such applications. 
(b)  If the city council, after considering such information as it determines to be appropriate, elects to further consider one or more applications, the city council shall set one or more public hearings for consideration of the application, fixing and setting forth a day, hour and place certain when and where any persons having any interest therein or objections thereto may file written comments and appear before the city council and be heard, and providing notice of such public hearings in accordance with applicable law. 
(c)  The city council may authorize negotiations between city officials and applicants to determine whether the city and such applicants are able to reach agreement on the terms of the proposed franchise. 
(d)  Upon completion of the steps deemed appropriate by the city council, the city council may grant the franchise, and may specify the conditions under which the franchise is granted. Alternatively, the city may reject any and all applications from whatever source and whenever received, except that a franchising authority may not grant an exclusive franchise and may not unreasonably refuse to award an additional competitive franchise. The city also reserves the right to waive any or all requirements when it determines that the best interests of the city may be served thereby and may, if it so desires, request new or additional proposals. 
(Code 2005, § 54-56; Ord. No. 01201, § 2.6, 1-11-1999)  
Sec. 54-54. - Terms and conditions of franchise. 
The terms and conditions applicable to any franchise granted pursuant to this article shall be set forth in the separate ordinance granting the franchise or in a separate written agreement. Such separate ordinance or written agreement, among other things, shall address the following subjects: 
(1)  The term of the franchise; 
(2)  The franchise area and the cable services and other telecommunications services and purposes of such other telecommunications services, if any, which are the subject of the franchise; 
(3)  The compensation to be paid to the city, which may include the payment of fees or the provision of facilities or services, or both; 
(4)  The circumstances upon which the franchise may be terminated or cancelled; 
(5)  The mechanisms, such as performance bonds, security funds or letters of credit, to be put in place to ensure the performance of the franchisee's obligations under the franchise; 
(6)  The city's right to inspect the facilities and records of the franchisee; 
(7)  Insurance and indemnification requirements applicable to the franchisee; 
(8)  The obligation of the franchisee to maintain complete and accurate books of account and records, and the city's inspection rights with respect thereto; 
(9)  Provisions to ensure quality workmanship and construction methods; 
(10)  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will comply with all applicable city, state and federal laws, regulations, rules and policies, including, without limitation, those related to employment, purchasing and investigations; 
(11)  Provisions to ensure adequate oversight and regulation of the franchisee by the city; 
(12)  Provisions to restrict the assignment or other transfer of the franchise without the prior written consent of the city; 
(13)  Remedies available to the city to protect the city's interest in the event of the franchisee's failure to comply with terms and conditions of the franchise; 
(14)  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will obtain all necessary licenses and permits from, and comply with, all laws, regulations, rules and policies of any governmental body having jurisdiction over the franchisee, including the Federal Communications Commission; 
(15)  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will protect the property of the city and the delivery of public services from damage or interruption of operations resulting from the construction, operation, maintenance, repair or removal of improvements related to the franchise; 
(16)  Provisions designed to minimize the extent to which the public use of the streets of the city is disrupted in connection with the construction of improvements relating to the franchise; and 
(17)  Such other provisions as the city determines are necessary or appropriate in furtherance of the public interest. 
(Code 2005, § 54-57; Ord. No. 01201, § 2.7, 1-11-1999;)  
Sec. 54-55. - Franchise extension. 
The authority, right, permission, and consent previously granted to the company and its successors, lessees, and assigns in the 1975 ordinance are hereby extended to January 9, 2031. 
(Ord. No. 01272, § I, 4-13-2009)  
Sec. 54-56. - Terms and conditions. 
In addition to the terms and conditions set forth in the 1975 ordinance, the company's occupancy and use of the streets, alleys, and public places of the city as authorized in the 1975 ordinance are subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  For the purposes of subsection (2) of this section, the term "distribution facilities" means poles, lines, wires, cables, conductors, insulators, transformers, appliances, equipment, connections, and other apparatus installed by or on behalf of the company (whether before or after the adoption of Ordinance No. 01272, Amending Franchise) in the streets, alleys, or public places of the city for the purpose of distributing electricity within the present and future limits of the city. Distribution facilities do not include any of the following: 
a.  Electric transmission lines with a design operating voltage of 46 kilovolts or greater (hereafter referred to as "transmission lines"); 
b.  Poles, towers, frames, or other supporting structures for transmission lines (hereafter referred to as "transmission structures"); 
c.  Transmission lines and related wires, cables, conductors, insulators, or other apparatus attached to transmission structures; 
d.  Lines, wires, cables, or conductors installed in concrete-encased ductwork; or 
e.  Network underground facilities. 
(2)  In the event that the city or any other entity acting on behalf of the city requests or demands that the company relocate any distribution facilities from their then-current locations within the streets, alleys, and public places of the city in connection with a public project or improvement, then the company shall relocate, at its expense, the distribution facilities affected by such project or improvement. The company's obligations under this subsection (2) shall apply without regard to whether the company has acquired, or claims to have acquired, an easement or other property right with respect to such distribution facilities and shall not affect the amounts paid or to be paid to the city under the provisions of the 1975 ordinance. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this subsection (2), the company shall not be obligated to relocate, at its expense, any of the following: 
a.  Distribution facilities that are located on private property at the time relocation is requested or demanded; 
b.  Distribution facilities that are relocated in connection with sidewalk improvements (unless such sidewalk improvements are related to or associated with road widenings, the creation of new turn lanes, or the addition of acceleration/deceleration lanes); 
c.  Streetscape projects or other projects undertaken primarily for aesthetic purposes; or 
d.  Distribution facilities that are converted from an overhead configuration or installation to an underground configuration or installation. 
(3)  The city and the company recognize that both parties benefit from economic development within the city. Accordingly, when it is necessary to relocate any of the company's facilities (whether distribution facilities, transmission lines, transmission structures, or other facilities) within the city, the city and the company shall work cooperatively to minimize costs, delays, and inconvenience to both parties while ensuring compliance with applicable laws and regulations. In addition, the city and the company shall communicate in a timely fashion to coordinate projects included in the city's five-year capital improvement plan, the city's short-term work program, or the city's annual budget in an effort to minimize relocation of the company's facilities. Such communication may include, but is not limited to: 
a.  Both parties' participation in the Georgia Utilities Coordinating Council, Inc. (or any successor organization), or a local utilities coordinating council (or any successor organization); and 
b.  Both parties' use of the National Joint Utility Notification System (or any successor to such system mutually acceptable to both parties). 
(4)  With regard to each streetscape project undertaken by or on behalf of the city, the city shall pay the company in advance for the company's estimated cost to relocate any of the company's facilities (whether distribution facilities, transmission lines, transmission structures, or other facilities) in connection with such project. For each streetscape project, the company shall estimate in good faith the amount of incremental base revenue, if any, that the company will realize as a result of new customer load or expansion of existing customer load attributable to such project; and such estimate shall be based on tariffs in effect at the time that construction of such project begins and shall not include fuel recovery charges, non-electric service billings, or taxes. If such estimate indicates that the company will realize incremental base revenue, the company shall do one of the following, whichever results in greater cost savings to the city: 
a.  Reduce the city's advance payment to the company for relocation costs by ten percent; or 
b.  Where the city has developed a bona fide marketing plan within 12 months after construction of such project begins, either refund the amount of the company's incremental base revenue during such 12-month period to the city or credit such amount against any future payment due from the city to the company. 
The city and the company acknowledge and agree that the amount of any refund or credit calculated pursuant to subsection (4)b of this section shall not exceed the amount of the city's advance payment to the company for relocation costs associated with such project. 
(Ord. No. 01272, § II, 4-13-2009)  
Sec. 54-57. - Right of customers. 
Nothing contained in Ordinance No. 01272, Amending Franchise, shall limit or restrict the right of customers within the corporate limits of the city to select an electric supplier as may hereafter be provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 01272, § III, 4-13-2009)  
Sec. 54-58. - Compliance. 
The company shall, within 90 days from the approval of Ordinance No. 01272, Amending Franchise, file the company's written acceptance of the same with the clerk of the city, so as to form an amendment to the franchise between the company and the city. 
(Ord. No. 01272, § IV, 4-13-2009)  
Sec. 54-59. - Repealer. 
Upon such acceptance all laws and ordinances, and all agreements between the company and the city with respect to the company's occupancy and use of the city's streets, alleys, and public places in actual conflict herewith are and the same shall thereupon stand repealed and terminated, respectively. 
(Ord. No. 01272, § V, 4-13-2009)  
Chapter 58 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 30; courts, ch. 34; offenses, ch. 62; personnel, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
State Law reference— Powers concerning police protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III; Georgia Peace Officers Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; compensation of officers restricted, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-9; liability for torts of police officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-3; obstructing or hindering law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24; subsistence allowance, O.C.G.A. § 35-1-3. 
 
Sec. 58-1. - Chief of police. 
The chief of police shall be answerable to the city manager. In addition to such other duties as provided from time to time by the mayor and city council, the chief shall: 
(1)  Enforce attendance of all police officers at state-mandated training courses, keeping accurate records of dates and hours of attendance. 
(2)  Keep an accurate record of the performance of each police officer, including the number of cases made by him. 
(3)  Keep an accurate record of the condition of all police equipment. 
(4)  Maintain the mechanical condition of police automobiles. 
(5)  Maintain such number of full-time police officers as required by the mayor and city council. 
(6)  Make such reports as the mayor and city council require. 
(Code 1990, § 4-1-1; Code 2005, § 58-1) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-52 et seq.  
Sec. 58-2. - Duty of police officers regarding persons violating city ordinances. 
Any police officer of the city shall arrest and confine in the county jail, when necessary, any offender against ordinances of the city, where such arrest and confinement is necessary to secure the offender's appearance before the municipal court to answer for his offense, or where it is necessary to preserve the peace and good order of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 4-1-2; Code 2005, § 58-2)  
Sec. 58-3. - Disposition of evidence, contraband, and unclaimed or abandoned articles. 
(a)  Evidence, contraband, and unclaimed or abandoned articles to be held by police for 90 days. It shall be the duty of any person, upon finding or coming into the possession of any personal property, to return such property to the owner if possible, and otherwise to deliver the property to the city police department. All evidence, contraband and unclaimed or abandoned articles coming into the possession of the chief of police or any police officer or other employee of the city, the disposition of which is not otherwise provided for by law, shall be held by the chief of police for a period of 90 days. 
(b)  Sale at auction authorized. At the expiration of the 90-day period, the chief of police may sell such articles at public auction, retaining out of the proceeds of the sale an amount sufficient to defray the costs of the sale. 
(c)  Notice of sale. No sale of unclaimed or abandoned articles shall be made until notice of the time and place of the sale shall have been mailed to the owner of any article to be offered for sale at least 30 days prior to the date thereof, when the address of the owner can be ascertained by the chief of police; nor shall such sale be made until notice of the time and place of such sale shall have been posted at the city hall for two weeks and published in the legal organ of the city once a week for two weeks prior to the sale. Such notice shall contain a description of the articles to be sold and the time and place of sale. 
(d)  Records of sale; disposition of proceeds. The chief of police shall keep a record of unclaimed or abandoned articles received by him, the date each was received, the amount received at such sale for each article sold, and the balance, if any, remaining after the expenses of the sale have been paid. The chief of police shall immediately pay to the city clerk the balance remaining after conduct of a sale. 
(e)  Disposal of unsold property. Any property which has not been bid on in two successive sales shall be considered as salvage and shall be disposed of as salvage or as other non-serviceable equipment is disposed of. 
(Code 1990, §§ 4-1-3—4-1-7; Code 2005, § 58-3)  
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Municipalities are prohibited by law from enacting ordinances covering matters which have been preempted by general law and are prevented from regulating conduct which has been made a violation of any criminal law of the state. See Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, ¶ IV; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2). 
Cross reference— Courts, ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 58; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
State Law reference— Controlled substances, O.C.G.A. § 16-13-1 et seq.; dangerous instrumentalities, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100 et seq.; abandonment of airtight containers, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100; fireworks, O.C.G.A. § 25-10-1 et seq.; disorderly houses, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-44; peeping Tom, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-61; gambling, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; criminal trespass, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-21; impersonating public officer or employee, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-23; obstruction or hindering of law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24; giving false name or address to law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-25. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 62-1. - Destruction of city property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy property belonging to the city. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-7; Code 2005, § 62-1) 
State Law reference— Damaging public property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25.  
Sec. 62-2. - Damaging trees on public property. 
No person shall injure or abuse any fruit, shade or ornamental tree that has been set, planted or preserved on public property. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-4; Code 2005, § 62-2)  
Sec. 62-3. - Interfering with fire department equipment. 
No person other than a regular member of the fire department shall ride upon the fire trucks of the city at any time, or use, borrow or interfere with any fire department equipment, or attempt to use the equipment at the scene of a fire, unless authorized to do so by the fire chief. 
(Code 1990, § 4-2-1; Code 2005, § 62-3) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46.  
Sec. 62-4. - Tampering with fire alarm system. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully, maliciously or mischievously interfere or tamper with any fire alarm box or any of the appliances or apparatus connected therewith located within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 4-2-3; Code 2005, § 62-4) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46. 
State Law reference— Interference with government property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-24.  
Sec. 62-5. - Turning on or turning off fire hydrant. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an authorized city officer or employee or a person holding a permit from the city clerk, to turn on or turn off a fire hydrant. 
(Code 1990, § 4-2-4; Code 2005, § 62-5) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46.  
Sec. 62-6. - Burning brush, trash, leaves or similar material. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any trash, leaves or other substance or to set any fire on the pavement of any street in the city, or to place any trash, leaves or other rubbish in ditches or gutters on any street that is paved and burn same in the ditches. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to burn leaves, brush, or any similar materials without first obtaining permission from the city fire department, within 50 feet of any structures, and without access to water. Permission to burn may be denied or withdrawn by the city fire department where there exists a potential for harm to persons or property. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-5; Code 2005, § 62-6) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46.  
Sec. 62-7. - Building fire near utility meter. 
It is unlawful for anyone to build fires close to or on water or gas meters. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-13; Code 2005, § 62-7) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 102.  
Sec. 62-8. - Vehicles with wheels damaging to pavement prohibited on paved streets. 
It shall be unlawful to operate or convey over pavement of the streets of the city any truck, tractor, automobile, car or other vehicle with lugs on the wheels of such vehicle, or to operate or convey over the pavement of any of the streets of the city any such vehicle on the rims of the wheels. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-6; Code 2005, § 62-8) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98.  
Sec. 62-9. - Littering. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, dump, discard, or otherwise deposit any trash, garbage, refuse, bottles, cans, or other debris on any property, public or private. 
(b)  The following penalties are imposed for littering: 
(1)  First offense: $10.00, plus one day of community service. 
(2)  Second offense: $25.00, plus three days of community service. 
(3)  Third offense: $50.00, plus five days of community service. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-8; Code 2005, § 62-9; Ord. of 7-11-1994) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 82. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to prohibit littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48.  
Sec. 62-10. - Drinking alcoholic beverages or possession of open container in public place. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any alcoholic beverage on any street, public property, or public place and to possess any open alcoholic beverage container on any such street, public property, or public place except as provided for by state statute or local ordinance. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-1; Code 2005, § 62-10; Ord. No. 01193, § 1, 10-13-1997) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86.  
Sec. 62-11. - Public drunkenness. 
Pursuant to state law, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41, Public Drunkenness, are adopted by reference as if stated in their entirety in this section. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-2; Code 2005, § 62-11) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
State Law reference— Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41.  
Sec. 62-12. - Disorderly conduct. 
It shall be unlawful and disorderly conduct for any person to: 
(1)  Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another, whereby a reasonable person would be placed in fear of safety for life or limb; 
(2)  Place the property of another in serious danger of being destroyed or damaged; 
(3)  Use fighting words directed toward another, who becomes outraged and thus creates a turmoil; 
(4)  Violently interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; or 
(5)  Congregate with others to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuse to clear the way when ordered by lawful authority to do so. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-11; Code 2005, § 62-12) 
State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39.  
Sec. 62-13. - Discharging firearm or other weapon. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than law enforcement officers in actual discharge of their duties as such, or persons in actual defense of life, limb, or property of themselves or others under their lawful protection, to discharge any sort of gun, pistol, rifle, or other firearm, or BB gun or air gun or spring gun, within the corporate limits of the city, whether the same is loaded with bullet, shot, shell, missile, or a mere explosive blank cartridge, shell, or other explosive device; provided it shall be lawful for any person to discharge any firearm (including air-powered firearms) in the corporate limits of the city and upon any lands now owned by the city, as aforesaid, if any such person shall first obtain permission to do so from the governing officials of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1-10; Code 2005, § 62-13)  
Sec. 62-14. - Nudity or sexual conduct in public place. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally, in a public place: 
(1)  Engage in sexual intercourse; 
(2)  Engage in deviant sexual conduct; 
(3)  Appear in a state of nudity; or 
(4)  Fondle the genitals of himself or another person. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the term "nudity" means the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, the showing of the female breasts below the top of the areola, or the showing of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. 
(Code 2005, § 62-14; Ord. No. 01168, § 1, 11-9-1992) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86.  
Sec. 62-15. - Sale of goods at mini-warehouses. 
It is unlawful for renters to conduct sales or sell goods from mini-warehouses. Owners of mini-warehouse facilities may conduct liquidation/cleanup sales from time to time. 
(Code 2005, § 62-15; Res. No. 5364, § 1, 3-10-1992)  
Secs. 62-16—62-33. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CURFEW FOR MINORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Juvenile proceedings, arrest, detention, O.C.G.A. § 15-11-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 62-34. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Curfew hours means: 
(1)  The hours from 11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and 
(2)  The hours from 12:00 midnight on any Friday or Saturday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day. 
Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term "emergency" includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
Establishment means any privately-owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment. 
Guardian means: 
(1)  A person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or 
(2)  A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court. 
Minor means any person under 18 years of age. 
Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term "operator" includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
Parent means a person who is: 
(1)  A natural parent, adoptive parent, or stepparent of another person; or 
(2)  At least 18 years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor. 
Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and, includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops. 
Remain means to: 
(1)  Linger or stay; or 
(2)  Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator, or other person in control of the premises. 
Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(Code 2005, § 62-41; Ord. No. 01187, § 1(a), 12-9-1996) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 62-35. - Offenses. 
(a)  A minor commits an offense if he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(b)  A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(c)  The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if he knowingly allows a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. 
(Code 2005, § 62-42; Ord. No. 01187, § 1(b), 12-9-1996)  
Sec. 62-36. - Defenses. 
(a)  It is a defense to prosecution under section 62-35 that the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian; 
(2)  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; 
(3)  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; 
(5)  Involved in an emergency; 
(6)  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police department about the minor's presence; 
(7)  Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
(8)  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or 
(9)  Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with state law. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under section 62-35(c) that the owner, operator, or employee of an establishment promptly notified the police department that a minor was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(Code 2005, § 62-43; Ord. No. 01187, § 1(c), 12-9-1996)  
Sec. 62-37. - Enforcement. 
Before taking any enforcement action under this article, a police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this article unless the officer reasonably believes that an officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no defense in section 62-36 is present. 
(Code 2005, § 62-44; Ord. No. 01187, § 1(d), 12-9-1996)  
Sec. 62-38. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person who violates a provision of this article is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable pursuant to section 1-7. 
(b)  When required by O.C.G.A. tit. 15, ch. 11, art. 1, pt. 3 (O.C.G.A. § 15-11-28 et seq.), the municipal court shall waive original jurisdiction over a minor who violates section 62-35(a) and shall refer the minor to juvenile court. 
(Code 2005, § 62-45; Ord. No. 01187, § 1(e), 12-9-1996)  
Secs. 62-39—62-64. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CONTROLLED SALE OF SELECT PRODUCTS USED IN THE PREPARATION OF METHAMPHETAMINE 
 
Sec. 62-65. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Select products used in the preparation of methamphetamine means any compound, mixture, preparation or drug product containing any dosage of 18 milligrams or more of ephedrine, pseudoephedrine or phenylpropanolamine, or any of the salts, isomers, or salts of isomers, alone or in a mixture. 
(Code 2005, § 62-71; Ord. No. 01243, § 1(11-4-1), 2-14-2005) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 62-66. - Display of products prohibited. 
Identified select products used in the preparation of methamphetamine may not be openly displayed for sale in the incorporated city limits, but must be maintained behind the counter, maintained in a locked cabinet or maintained in a location from which it may be distributed for sale only by a pharmacist, pharmacy technician, sales clerk or other retail distributor employee. 
(Code 2005, § 62-72; Ord. No. 01243, § 1(11-4-2), 2-14-2005)  
Sec. 62-67. - Specific list of prohibited products. 
The chief of police shall compile a complete and thorough list, updated annually or as needed, of specific, select products affected by this article as determined by the definition in section 62-65. Said list shall be submitted to the mayor and council for their acknowledgement and provided to all retail businesses/locations who sell those select products identified. 
(Code 2005, § 62-73; Ord. No. 01243, § 1(11-4-3), 2-14-2005)  
Sec. 62-68. - Specific list of retail businesses/locations affected. 
The chief of police shall determine any and all retail establishments within the city which are distributors of the select products identified in section 62-67. Said list shall be maintained by the chief of police, updated annually or as needed, and provided to the mayor and city council, initially when the list is created and then each time said list is updated. 
(Code 2005, § 62-74; Ord. No. 01243, § 1(11-4-4), 2-14-2005)  
Sec. 62-69. - Requirements for purchase/sale of products. 
The select products identified in section 62-67, used in the preparation of methamphetamine, may not be dispensed, sold, or distributed within the city limits without requiring the individual purchasing, receiving or otherwise acquiring such select identified products, as enumerated in section 62-67, to produce a photo identification showing his date of birth and sign a written log or receipt showing his signature and printed name, the date of transaction, the type and amount of product purchased, on a form created for this purpose by the chief of police. The amount purchased is hereby restricted. An individual shall not be permitted to purchase in excess of three units total (said unit in a form typically sold by the manufacturer/retailer) of the aforementioned identified select products in section 62-67, regardless of the variety of the manufacturers. In other words, of all the products identified in section 62-67, a total maximum quantity of three units, either arrived at by buying three units of a single product or a single unit of three different products listed in section 62-67, shall be permitted to be purchased by a consumer anywhere within the city limits, or sold by a retailer to a single consumer, in a single week. The week shall be measured starting on a Sunday and continuing until the following Saturday. A copy of the weekly/monthly sales log shall be kept on site and mailed to the department of police, attention chief of police, no later than the 15th of the following month. Records must be kept on the premises, and readily available for police review, for 18 months. The city police department reserves the right to directly pick up the monthly sales log between the first and fifth day of each month (if this is accomplished, mailing shall not be necessary). Additionally, the police department reserves the right to conduct unannounced inspections, concerning the proper storage of the select products and the proper maintaining of the sales log. 
(Code 2005, § 62-75; Ord. No. 01243, § 1(11-4-5), 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 01247, § 1, 3-14-2005)  
Sec. 62-70. - Violations and enforcement. 
Violations of this article shall be considered a misdemeanor and shall be punished in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq., and section 1-7 of this Code. The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the police department. 
(Code 2005, § 62-76; Ord. No. 01243, § 1(11-4-6), 2-14-2005)  
Chapter 66 - PARKS, RECREATION AND CULTURAL AFFAIRS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 66-1—66-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PARK REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 66-19. - Generally. 
The city manager shall have the authority to establish reasonable rules and regulations covering the operation of the city's recreation and park facilities. This authority shall include the establishment of the hours the facilities shall be open for use by authorized persons. All proposed regulations shall be transmitted to the mayor and city council for review two weeks before becoming effective, and shall be implemented unless a council vote disapproves such regulations. When the rules and regulations are posted or displayed on the facility involved, such rules and regulations shall have the force and effect of law, and any person committing any action in violation thereof shall be deemed to have violated this section and shall be punished as provided by section 1-7. 
(Code 2005, § 66-31; Ord. No. 01238, § 1(7-1-1), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 66-20. - Helton Howland City Park. 
(a)  Miscellaneous regulations. The following regulations are hereby formulated for the city park known as "Helton Howland." Once properly posted at all entrances and on the beach at the main entrance near the paved road, any person found to violate these regulations shall be punished as provided by section 1-7. The regulations are as follows: 
(1)  Swimmers swim at the beach at their own risk. No lifeguards are on duty. All swimmers must remain in the swim area, as marked off. 
(2)  All rafters, unless they stay within the marked swim area, must wear flotation devices. 
(3)  All boaters/canoeists must wear flotation devices. Boats and canoes are prohibited from entering the marked swim area. 
(4)  No one under the age of 16 is permitted without being accompanied by a parent or guardian. The guardian must be over the age of 18. 
(5)  Helton Howland Park closes at dusk. No overnight accommodations are provided unless the guest gains a special permit from the city. 
(6)  Motorists must comply with all traffic flow directional signs, park speed limit signs and no parking signs. Parking is limited to designated marked parking areas. The speed limit in the park is 15 miles per hour. 
(7)  Alcoholic beverages are prohibited. 
(8)  All vehicles are prohibited off the road. No all-terrain vehicles are permitted. 
(9)  No hunting is permitted. 
(10)  Fishing is permitted by permit only. Permits are available at the city police department, 6:00 a.m. through 6:00 p.m. No fishing is allowed in the swim area or from any point on the beach. 
(11)  Pets are allowed on a leash only. Pets are prohibited on the sand beach at all times. Pets must be under the owner's control at all times. 
(12)  No littering is permitted. See O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48 and section 62-9. 
(13)  No obscene language, gestures or actions are permitted. 
(b)  Parking fee. All citizens entering Helton Howland Park and intending to stay, visit, or utilize the park in any way (except for quick, drive-through, get-acquainted tours and passenger drop-offs) are hereby required to pay a parking fee. Such fee is established at $2.00 per vehicle and is adjustable from time to time by the mayor and city council by resolution. The revenue generated by this fee is to be used for the upkeep and improvement of Helton Howland Park only. Failure to pay this fee and obtain a daily ticket shall expose the driver of the vehicle to a fine in accordance with section 1-7. Annual passes may be obtained from the department of planning at city hall. The fee for an annual pass shall be $25.00 and the pass shall be provided to the purchaser and the purchaser's vehicle only. 
(c)  Exemptions and suspension of regulations. 
(1)  Periods of regulation suspension, and specific provisions which shall be suspended during that period, are as follows: 
a.  During the following scheduled, known and established community events, the mandatory parking fee and subsection (a)(8) of this section shall be suspended for that day only: 
1.  Annual July 4 celebrations. 
2.  Annual Haralson County Veterans Association's Car Show and Barbeque. 
3.  Annual Dogwood Arts and Crafts Fair sponsored by the Tallapoosa Historical Society. 
b.  If future annual civic city-wide events and/or festivals are proposed to be created and desire to be exempt from the daily parking fee and subsection (a)(8) of this section, then they must submit an application available from the department of planning to the mayor and city council, for their approval, at least 15 days prior to the regularly scheduled council meeting. Upon approval of the mayor and city council, such suspension shall remain in effect until the event has been cancelled for two consecutive years. 
(2)  The following types of activity are exempt from the requirement of having to purchase a daily or annual parking permit: 
a.  Any and all citizens and faculty associated with the GED program which occurs on a reoccurring, scheduled basis at the old nutrition building at Helton Howland Park are exempt. This exemption applies only to the persons who are operating the GED program or are attending the offered classes, during the period when the classes are being conducted or the graduation celebration occurs. All those who are attending the graduation celebration shall also be exempt from paying the parking fee during the celebration period. 
b.  Any individual reserving the pavilion or renting the old nutrition building shall not be charged an extra, separate fee for parking. Any and all parking fees shall be included in the rental fee charged. The fee for the rental and all associated parking shall be set and updated from time to time by the mayor and city council through resolution. 
(Code 2005, § 66-32; Ord. No. 01238, § 1(7-1-2), 3-10-2003)  
Secs. 66-21—66-43. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MUSEUM  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 66-44—66-74. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MUSEUM DEPARTMENT AND MUSEUM ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of city to administer department, § 3.10. 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, ch. 2, art. V. 
 
Sec. 66-75. - Museum department established. 
There is hereby created a department of the city to be known as the "museum department." 
(Code 2005, § 66-81; Res. No. 05422, § 1, 10-8-1990)  
Sec. 66-76. - Museum advisory board. 
(a)  The museum department shall be run and operated by the city with input and advice of a museum advisory board under the supervision of the mayor and city council. The members of the board shall serve without compensation at the pleasure of the mayor and city council. 
(b)  The members of the board shall consist of the mayor and seven members, who shall be residents of county and who shall be appointed by the mayor and city council. The mayor and city council shall initially appoint two members for a term of two years each, two members for terms of four years each, and three members for terms of six years each. After expiration of the initial terms, the terms of all members shall be six years. If, at the end of any term of office of any member, a successor to such member has not been appointed, the member whose term of office has expired shall continue to hold office until a successor is appointed. A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum. Any member of the board may be selected and appointed to succeed himself. Immediately after such appointments, the members of the board shall enter upon their duties. 
(c)  Any vacancy on the board shall be filled in the same manner as was the original appointment of the member whose termination of membership resulted in such vacancy, and the person so elected and appointed shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(d)  The board shall elect one of its members as chairperson, a member as vice-chairperson, a member as secretary, a member as treasurer and other subcommittees as needed. 
(e)  The members of the board shall be reimbursed for all actual expenses incurred in the performance of their duties out of the funds of the city. 
(f)  Any member of the board may be removed from office by a majority vote of the mayor and city council. Any board position so vacated shall be filled within 60 days by appointment of the mayor and city council. The new appointee shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term to which he is appointed. 
(g)  The chairperson of the museum advisory board shall be selected by a majority vote of the members sitting on the board. 
(h)  The responsibilities and duties of the board are as follows: to seek out, accept, evaluate and display appropriate exhibits for the museum in keeping with the purposes and goals of the museum; to adopt a name for the museum; to develop and maintain a schedule of hours during which the museum will be open to the public; to staff and operate the museum with volunteer, non-city-employee help during the hours it is open to the public for special festivals and events when the city museum staff needs additional help; to perform other necessary and appropriate administrative and curative work on a volunteer basis during appropriate times; and other such responsibilities and duties as the mayor and city council shall from time to time direct and require. 
(Code 2005, § 66-82; Res. No. 05422, §§ 2, 4, 5, 10-8-1990)  
Chapter 70 - PERSONNEL[1]
