State Law reference— Regional development centers, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-30 et seq. 
 
Sec. 74-60. - Participation by city. 
The city hereby participates in the establishment of the Coosa Valley Regional Development Center or its successor, and agrees to abide by the rules thereof. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-1; Code 2005, § 74-61) 
Editor's note— The Coosa Valley Regional Development Center is the successor of the Coosa Valley Area Planning and Development Commission, city participation in which was first authorized by Res. No. 5104, adopted December 6, 1960.  
Secs. 74-61—74-78. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-171 et seq. 
State Law reference— Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 74-79. - Declaration of need. 
There is hereby determined and declared to be a pressing, existing and future need for a development authority (as more fully described and defined in the Development Authorities Law) to function in the city for the purpose of developing and promoting for the public good and general welfare, trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in the city, thereby promoting the general welfare of its citizenry. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-21; Code 2005, § 74-91)  
Sec. 74-80. - Activation. 
There is hereby activated in the city the public body corporate and politic known as the "Development Authority of the City of Tallapoosa" which was created upon the adoption and approval of the Development Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-22; Code 2005, § 74-92)  
Sec. 74-81. - Membership of board of directors. 
The board of directors of the development authority shall consist of five members, serving six-year staggered terms of office. If, at the end of any term of office of any director, a successor thereto shall not have been elected, then the director whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until his successor shall be so elected. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-23; Code 2005, § 74-93)  
Sec. 74-82. - Organization, powers and duties of board of directors. 
The board of directors of the development authority shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Development Authorities Law as it now exists and as it might hereafter be amended or modified. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-24; Code 2005, § 74-94)  
Secs. 74-83—74-107. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-171 et seq. 
State Law reference— Downtown Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-42-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 74-108. - Declaration of need. 
There is hereby determined and declared to be an urgent, existing and future need for a downtown development authority, as more fully described and defined in the Downtown Development Authorities Law, 1981 Ga. Laws (O.C.G.A. § 36-42-1 et seq.), to function in the city for the purpose of developing and promoting for the public good and general welfare, trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in the city, thereby promoting the general welfare of its citizenry. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-31; Code 2005, § 74-121)  
Sec. 74-109. - Activation. 
There is hereby activated in the city the public body corporate and politic known as the "Downtown Development Authority of the City of Tallapoosa" which was created upon the adoption and approval of the Downtown Development Authorities Law and particularly section 2 thereof, which downtown development authority of the city shall have all the powers granted to downtown development authorities under the Downtown Development Authorities Law. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-32; Code 2005, § 74-122)  
Sec. 74-110. - Downtown development area. 
(a)  The following described geographical area constitutes the central business district of the city: 
All the tracts or parcels of land lying and being in the city, eighth land district of Haralson County, Georgia, being all property in the city within a radius of one mile from the city hall of the city, as it does currently exist on Alabama Street in the city; and all property fronting the following streets and highways within the city, as follows: Alewine Street (Georgia Highway 100 South); Bowdon Street (Georgia Highway 100 North); U.S. Highway 78 (Bankhead Highway); Stoffel Drive. 
(b)  Such area shall be and it hereby is designated as the downtown development area of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-33; Code 2005, § 74-123)  
Sec. 74-111. - Membership of board of directors. 
(a)  The downtown development authority shall consist of seven members, all taxpayers residing in the city, serving six-year staggered terms of office. 
(b)  If a director at any time ceases to be a resident or taxpayer of the city, his eligibility to serve as a director shall cease and his term of office shall end. 
(c)  No person shall receive any compensation for serving as a director, but a director may be entitled to actual expenses incurred in the performance of such person's duties as a director. 
(d)  If at the end of any term of office of any director a successor thereto shall not have been elected, then the director whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until his successor shall be so elected. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-34; Code 2005, § 74-124)  
Sec. 74-112. - Organization, powers and duties of board of directors. 
The board of directors elected pursuant to this article shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Downtown Development Authorities Law as it now exists and as it might hereafter be amended or modified. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1-35; Code 2005, § 74-125)  
Chapter 78 - SIGNS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 106. 
 
Sec. 78-1. - Placing advertisements on public property or right-of-way. 
(a)  No person, either for himself, or for or on behalf of some other person, shall place any advertisement, sign, placard, bill, flyer, leaflet, handbill, poster, circular, notice, or other indicia thereof concerning any subject, business, event, political candidate or issue on any public property or any right-of-way adjacent to any city street or railroad within the city or upon any utility pole, traffic control device and/or sign or other improvement situated thereon. 
(b)  Any person who places any such advertisement, sign, placard, bill, flyer, leaflet, handbill, poster, circular, notice, or other indicia thereof shall be guilty of violating provisions of this chapter and shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided by section 1-7. 
(Code 2005, § 78-1; Ord. No. 01237, § 1(8-7-1), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 78-2. - Prohibited signs. 
(a)  Signs imitating warning signals are prohibited. No sign shall display lights resembling the flashing lights customarily used in traffic signals or in police, fire, ambulance, or rescue vehicles; nor shall any signs use the dimensional shape or size of the governmental traffic signs. 
(b)  No signs, except traffic signs and signals and informational signs erected by a public agency, are permitted within any street or highway right-of-way. 
(c)  Signs painted on or attached to natural features, such as trees or rocks, telephone poles, utility poles or fence posts, are prohibited. 
(Code 2005, § 78-2; Ord. No. 01237, § 1(8-7-2), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 78-3. - Regulations for specific types of signs. 
(a)  Home occupation signs. One non-illuminated professional or business nameplate not exceeding two square feet in area is permitted for home occupations, provided that such sign complies with additional restrictions contained in chapter 106, pertaining to zoning. 
(b)  Temporary subdivision signs. Temporary signs, not exceeding 40 square feet in area, announcing a land subdivision development are permitted on the premises of the land subdivision. Such signs shall be spaced not less than 300 feet apart. They shall be removed when 75 percent of the lots are conveyed. 
(c)  Roof signs. Not more than one roof sign structure may be erected on the roof of any one building. No roof sign structure shall extend more than 25 feet above the elevation of the roof. 
(d)  Wall signs. Signs on the walls of a building (including signs attached flat against the wall, painted wall signs and projecting signs) shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Signs on front surface of building. The total area of signs on the exterior front surface of a building shall not exceed 25 percent of the front surface of the building. 
(2)  Signs on side and rear surface of building. The total area of signs on a side or rear surface of a building shall not exceed 50 percent of the exterior side or rear surface of the building, respectively. 
(3)  Non-projecting signs. Wall signs attached flat against a wall may extend not more than 24 inches from the wall, and must be a minimum of ten feet above the ground (measured from the lowest bottom portion of the sign frame). 
(4)  Projecting signs. Signs attached at an angle to a wall may extend outward from the wall of a building not more than five feet and may encroach upon the right-of-way no more than five feet (but not onto the travelway of the paved roadway), and must be a minimum of ten feet above the ground (measured from the lowest bottom portion of the sign frame). 
(e)  Illuminated signs. Illumination devices shall be so placed and so shielded that light from the sign itself will not be directly cast into any residential district, sleeping room in any district or the eyes of an automobile or vehicle driver. 
(Code 2005, § 78-3; Ord. No. 01237, § 1(8-7-3), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 78-4. - Outdoor advertising signs. 
Outdoor advertising signs shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Location; setback. The erection or construction of signs in areas of the city adjacent to and visible from the main traveled way of the primary highway system must be within an area zoned C-1, C-2 and/or M. Signs must be a minimum of the height of the sign, plus ten feet, away from all nearby surrounding structures and, whatever that height measurement plus ten feet, must be that far away from the right-of-way and all property lines, regardless of the standard setback for a specific zoning district. 
(2)  Size. The total area of any such signs facing in one direction shall not exceed 1,000 square feet, excluding any border and/or trim and excluding base, apron, supports and other structural members. 
(3)  Illumination. All illuminated signs shall use base-mounted halogen, fluorescent or mercury vapor lights, which shall be activated by photoelectric cell. 
(4)  Minimum height above highway grade. All signs shall be a minimum of ten feet above the adjacent highway pavement measuring from the lowest portion of the sign frame. 
(5)  Extrusions prohibited. Extrusions beyond the face of the sign, excluding aprons, are prohibited. 
(6)  Number of sign faces. No more than two sign faces may be visible from the same direction. Double-faced, back-to-back, and V-type constructed signs shall, for the purpose of determining compliance with size and spacing limitations, be considered as one sign. 
(7)  Spacing. Sign locations shall be no less than 500 feet apart measuring from the two closest points. 
(8)  On-premises signs. On-premises signs, indicating the business in operation at that site, are permitted, provided that the mounting base foundation is five feet from any property line, and that the message area may encroach upon the right-of-way five feet (but not onto the travelway of the paved roadway), and is a minimum of ten feet above the ground. "For Sale" and "For Lease" signs located on a property being advertised would not be prohibited. 
(9)  Conflicting regulations. Whichever regulation, in this chapter or another ordinance, in regards to setback is the strictest and/or provides the highest level of safety shall be controlling. 
(Code 2005, § 78-4; Ord. No. 01237, § 1(8-7-4), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 78-5. - Nonconforming signs. 
Any sign which would become nonconforming as a result of this chapter shall be allowed to remain until such sign is removed, damaged to such an extent that it is no longer safe, or destroyed. 
(Code 2005, § 78-5; Ord. No. 01237, § 1(8-7-5), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 78-6. - Signs permitted on city right-of-way. 
(a)  Signs are permitted on city public right-of-way in only one location. This location is the triangle of land located at the southeast corner of GA 100 and US 78, which is also abutting West Atlanta Street as it intersects with US 78. 
(b)  The only type of signs permitted at this location shall be advertisements for citywide noncommercial activity, such as parades and noncommercial festivals, fairs, concerts, charitable fundraisers, etc. Such activity can only be sponsored by noncommercial entities, such as nonprofit organizations, churches and civic groups. 
(c)  Any sign erected can be so erected for no longer than two weeks (14 days). 
(Code 2005, § 78-6; Ord. No. 01237, § 1(8-7-6), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 78-7. - Exemptions; suspension of regulations. 
(a)  Real estate signs, erected exactly on the property which is then for sale, shall be granted an automatic exemption from the prohibition of utilizing the city right-of-way which is contained in this chapter. This exemption applies only to real estate signs erected upon the exact piece of property which is for sale and which the sign is advertising the sale of. Such on-site, "For Sale" real estate signs may be installed in the city right-of-way, provided that they do not in any way create a hazardous sight line restriction related to the property (either at a street corner or any driveway onto the property). Any signs directing potential purchasers to this location must still comply with this chapter. 
(b)  The tenets of this chapter shall be suspended for 30 days prior to and one week after the citywide yard sale, which occurs in October. This suspension only applies to the citywide event which occurs in October and shall be terminated if that event date moves or a second similar event is created at another time of the year. 
(Code 2005, § 78-7; Ord. No. 01237, § 1(8-7-7), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 78-8. - Display of street numbers. 
(a)  Applicability; assignment of numbers. All parcels of land in existence now, subdivided in the past and proposed to be subdivided in the future must have a street number assigned. The city manager or his designee shall be responsible for assigning these numbers in a logical, unbiased manner such that emergency response and general delivery vehicles shall be assisted in the efficient discharge of their duties. 
(b)  Display required. Every house, mobile home, individual apartment, business or other building having a street number assigned to it under the system of numbering in the city shall display such number in a readily visible manner and in compliance with the requirements of this section. Mobile home parks and apartment complexes shall also be required to have each individual pad, lot number or apartment building numbered in a multi-building development displayed in a readily visible manner from the main street or thoroughfare through the apartment complex or mobile home park (same as a manufactured home park) and in compliance with the requirements of this section. Such lot, pad or apartment building numbers shall be in sequence unless directional signs are provided for numbers not in sequence. 
(c)  Method of display. Assigned street numbers shall be affixed to the house, apartment, business or other building itself, provided that such house, apartment, business or other building is not more than 50 feet from the curbline, pavement edge or edge of the travelway of the street in front of the house, apartment, business or other building and the number is readily visible from the street by persons traveling along the street in each direction. Numbers must be located under a night (porch, garage) light where such a light exists such that the number is visible at night when the light is lit. Street numbers shall also be placed on both sides of an individual's mailbox such that when the arm or flag is in the up or down position the number is not hidden or blocked; or may be placed on signs located on the premises in front of the house, apartment, business or other building (in the case that the house, apartment, business or other building exceeds the 50-foot maximum standard), provided such signs are of a durable type and are located not more than 50 feet from the curbline, pavement edge or edge of the travelway of the street in front of the property, and provided that the number on such a sign shall be readily visible from the street by a person traveling along the street in each direction. Such a sign must not exceed two square feet in size, may be illuminated in a manner that does not disturb neighbors and must not be placed in the city or state street right-of-way or block the line of sight from any egress/entry point and city street corner line of sight. 
(d)  Size and color of numbers; use of reflective material. Street numbers affixed to buildings shall be a minimum of four inches in height. The number itself may or may not be of highly reflective material. However, if no night (porch, garage) light is affixed to the building, then the numbers must be displayed with a background of highly reflective material (as typically sold at a hardware store). Those affixed to mailboxes in the manner specified in this section shall be a minimum of three inches in height and must be displayed on highly reflective material (as typically sold at a hardware store). Numbers displayed in the front yard on a sign must be four inches tall and may be of either contrasting color with the background or with a highly reflective material (as typically sold at a hardware store). All such numbers not designed with a reflective background shall be of a color contrasting to the background so as to be clearly visible. Street numbers on buildings and on signs and the signs to which they are affixed shall be maintained at all times in good condition. 
(e)  Duty of property owner; violations. The obligation of complying with the provisions of this section shall be upon the owner of the property. The property owner shall have until January 1, 2002, to comply with the provisions of this section. If the provisions of this section shall be found to have been violated, notice shall be given to the owner of the property, or his agent, specifying the manner in which this section is being violated, and giving the owner 30 days to bring the property into compliance. Each day a violation of this section continues after the expiration date of such 30-day period shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as provided by this section. 
(f)  Temporary exemption; grandfather clause. On the date of approval of the ordinance from which this section is derived, all homes that at that time have pre-existing street numbers prominently displayed and installed shall be exempt from the increased mandatory minimum standards required in this section up until the time that the home is remodeled or renovated (including installation of a variety of siding options or repainting of the home), or a portion of the street number becomes unreadable, or the numbering system for the street is permanently altered. Owners of mailboxes which have pre-existing numbers installed are also exempt from the size requirement of this section but must comply with the double side standard. However, in all instances, any time the street numbers are updated or replaced, the new numbers must comply with the mandatory minimum standards of this section. All homes, regardless of pre-existing street numbers, must come into complete compliance with the mandatory minimum standards of this section no later than January 1, 2010. 
(g)  Responsibility for enforcement. The responsibility for making the inspections provided for in this section, and for the enforcement of the provisions of this section, shall rest upon the city manager or his designated representative, who is hereby authorized and empowered to make cases and issue written warnings initiating the 30-day grace period. Any such warnings issued shall be forwarded to the chief of police. Upon expiration of this 30-day period, all law enforcement agencies providing services to the city are authorized to make cases and issue summonses for violations. 
(h)  Penalties. Violators determined to be in violation of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 per violation and any other penalties which may be imposed by law by the municipal court judge of the city. 
(Code 2005, § 78-8; Ord. No. 01237, § 1(8-7-8), 3-10-2003) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86.  
Sec. 78-9. - Murals. 
(a)  The term "mural" means an artistic rendering of an image located on an exterior wall of a commercial building within the city limits. It can be an image or word painted on the side of a building, in replace of, or an embellishment of, the typical mono-color painting of a building side. The mural will usually depict an historical place (landscape, national park or forest, etc.), event or person (either local or national); or a tourism attraction in the city and/or the county. The mural may or may not include the name of the business operating in the building where the mural is placed. A stylized rendering of the business name without any additional visual imagery shall not be construed to be a mural. A standalone billboard shall not constitute a mural. 
(b)  The Tallapoosa Downtown Development Authority (TDDA) is hereby authorized to approve or deny any and all proposed murals within the city. The TDDA has full discretion to approve or deny proposed murals, including color requirements. The TDDA decision regarding a proposed mural is final. 
(c)  The following application process must be followed prior to a mural being installed on the exterior of a building within the city limits: 
(1)  All applications shall be submitted at city hall, and will be reviewed by the TDDA. There will be no charge for the original review of the mural proposal. This may be altered by the mayor and council by resolution. 
(2)  Mural creators/painters must submit an application for approval. 
(3)  Application must include signatures by the building owner and the artist painting the mural, attesting to what is to be painted is accurately depicted on the application. 
(4)  A full color rendering/picture of the mural must be included in the application. 
(5)  Preferred imagery include: historically accurate to Tallapoosa scenes and people, images of national parks, national figures, etc. Images must place subjects in a positive light, and the overall mural image should be aesthetically pleasing. 
(6)  Political attacks, violence and/or obscenity will not be approved. 
(7)  Once application is approved and a permit issued, work must begin within six months or another approval will be required. Additional approvals will require a payment of $25.00 (or double the existing application fee, if one is adopted). Work must be accomplished within 90 days. It is not recommended to paint in winter/cold weather. 
(8)  Submitted application will be considered at the next regularly scheduled TDDA meeting, provided it is submitted at least ten days prior to this scheduled meeting (Friday prior to the Monday a week before the meeting). If after this date, it will be on the agenda of the following meeting. At this meeting, the mural proposal will be approved, approved with additional requirements, not approved due to needed additional information, or denied. The TDDA chairperson will provide the applicant with the TDDA's written decision. 
(9)  Oath of maintenance. Property owner, in addition to the business owner and/or artist must sign form affirming their promise to maintain the mural in good condition (bright paint, no flaking or loss of paint) in perpetuity (at least ten years) or, in the case a mural is not maintained, have it repainted a typical monochrome color within 90 days' notice from the city. 
(d)  Failure to obtain approval from the TDDA to install a mural will result in a stop work order and a citation being issued. 
(Ord. No. 01291, exh. 2018-D(78-9), 10-22-2018)  
Sec. 78-10. - Application for a mural permit. 
Mural permits require the completion of the following mural permit application: 
	Mural Permit Number: _____

The representation MUST be precisely accurate to what will be installed, including all colors and images. Chapter 82 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; deposit of waste in cemeteries, § 26-10; environment, ch. 42; accumulations of solid waste, § 42-52; littering, § 62-9; utilities, ch. 102. 
State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2). 
 
Sec. 82-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ashes means the waste products from coal, wood and other fuels used for cooking and heating from all public and private residences and establishments. 
Building rubbish means waste material resulting from construction, remodeling, repairs and demolition operations on houses, commercial buildings and other structures, including driveways and walks, and it comprises waste and rejected matter such as excavated earth, stones, bricks, plaster, wallpaper, sheetrock and lathes, lumber, shingles, tile, concrete and waste parts occasioned by the installation or replacement of plumbing, heating systems, electrical work and roofing. 
Garbage means waste accumulation of animal or vegetable matter used for or intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
Industrial waste means solid waste materials from factories, processing plants, wholesale establishments, or assembling, food processing wastes, cinders and ashes, lumber scraps, sawdust, excelsior, shavings, floor sweepings, metal scrap and shavings, glass and other waste products. 
Occupant means any person living on any premises. In the case of construction sites, the term "occupant" shall mean the contractor or foreman in charge of workers at the site. The term "occupant" also includes any person in charge of or responsible for a commercial or industrial operation. 
Rubbish means a variety of combustible and noncombustible waste not subject to rapid decomposition derived from places of residence, commercial areas and institutions and shall include paper, rags, plastics, cartons, boxes, cans, bottles, glass, crockery, excelsior, rubber, discarded clothing and similar materials. 
Scavenge means uncontrolled picking from discarded solid waste materials. 
Solid waste means putrescible and nonputrescible waste, except human body waste, and includes garbage, rubbish, paper, cartons, boxes, wood, tree branches, yard trimmings, furniture, appliances, metals, tin cans, glass, crockery, ashes, street refuse, dead animals, waste materials generated in industrial operations, residue from incineration, food processing wastes, demolition wastes, construction wastes and any other wastes in a solid or semisolid state, not otherwise defined in this section. 
Standard container means a durable, rust-resistant, non-absorbent, rodentproof, watertight plastic or metal container with handles or bails, having a tightfitting cover, and having no more than a 30-gallon capacity. 
Waste means unwanted or discarded material, except human body waste. 
Yard rubbish means tree branches, stumps, twigs, grass and shrub trimmings, bushes, weeds, leaves and general yard and garden waste materials and includes stone and dirt rakings and any waste materials resulting from landscaping. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-1; Code 2005, § 82-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 82-2. - Waste acceptable for collection by city. 
Garbage, rubbish and industrial waste constitute waste acceptable for collection by the city. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-2; Code 2005, § 82-2)  
Sec. 82-3. - Waste unacceptable for collection by city. 
(a)  The following items constitute waste unacceptable for collection by the city: 
(1)  Dangerous materials or substances such as poisons, acids, caustics and explosives; 
(2)  Building rubbish; 
(3)  Ashes; 
(4)  Yard rubbish, except as provided in this chapter; 
(5)  Furniture and appliances; 
(6)  Automobile and motor vehicle tires; and 
(7)  All other solid waste not specifically authorized in this chapter. 
(b)  Any person responsible for waste not acceptable for collection by the city shall make any arrangements as may be necessary for the collection and disposal of the unacceptable waste. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-3; Code 2005, § 82-3)  
Sec. 82-4. - Preparation and storage of waste. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of each residence, business, commercial establishment or industry, including markets and market stalls, shall store acceptable waste in standard containers which shall be provided by the owner or occupant and which shall at all times be maintained in a good state of repair. Sufficient numbers of containers shall be provided to contain all acceptable waste generated on the premises between city collections. Each owner or occupant shall prevent the continued, excessive and unsightly accumulation of waste upon the property occupied by him. 
(b)  Any acceptable waste that cannot be placed in standard containers shall be broken down and tied securely in bundles no larger than 36 inches square and placed alongside the standard containers for collection. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for such owner or occupant of any premises to have, maintain, or keep solid waste on any premises, except in such standard containers as are provided for in subsection (a) of this section. The owner or occupant shall also keep clean, free from rubbish and similar material, all premises whether improved or unimproved as well as all open lots and areas. 
(d)  Containers shall be kept tightly covered at all times, except when momentarily open to receive waste or to have the contents removed, as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-4; Code 2005, § 82-4)  
Sec. 82-5. - Place of collection; grass clippings, limbs and other yard rubbish. 
(a)  Containers shall be placed at the rear of the property or at such other location as designated by the director of public works for collection. 
(b)  Grass clippings, pine straw and leaves shall be placed in containers alongside the curb on pickup days. These items must be secured in disposable plastic bags of a type, size and material designed for solid waste storage and disposal. Disposable bags shall be unbroken and securely sealed and loaded in such a manner that normal handling will not cause the bag to open. No bag that cannot be loaded by one person shall be collected. 
(c)  Fallen limbs, trees, cut limbs, cut trees and trash of this category shall be cut by the property owner into lengths of not more than four feet. Other trash, which shall include yard wastes, weeds, grass, trimmings, leaves, brush and pine straw, must be bagged. All trash and cuttings shall be placed as near as possible to the collection point but not so as to get into the street or alley or onto another's property. At no time shall trash be placed in gutters, drains, walkways or alleys or streets of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-5; Code 2005, § 82-5)  
Sec. 82-6. - Scavenging. 
No person other than the owner thereof shall interfere with any container placed for the purpose of storing solid waste pending collection, or remove or take any of the contents thereof, or remove any container from the location where the container has been placed by the owner thereof. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-7; Code 2005, § 82-6)  
Sec. 82-7. - Burning waste. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises to burn, or cause to be burned, any solid waste required by the terms and provisions of this chapter to be kept and maintained in containers and/or other solid waste materials not specifically exempted by the terms and provisions of this chapter and/or items for which a permit for burning may be obtained from the city. 
(Code 1990, § 5-3-8; Code 2005, § 82-7) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46.  
Chapter 86 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Eminent domain, § 5.14. 
Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, sidewalk or alley saved from repeal, § 1-11(9); any ordinance establishing the grade of any street or sidewalk saved from repeal, § 1-11(12); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; cemeteries, ch. 26; environment, ch. 42; use of loudspeakers in streets, parks or other public places, § 42-133; soil erosion and sedimentation control, § 42-221 et seq.; floods, ch. 50; drinking alcoholic beverages or possession of open container in public place, § 62-10; nudity or sexual conduct in public place, § 62-14; parks, recreation and cultural affairs, ch. 66; planning and development, ch. 74; signs, ch. 78; display of street numbers, § 78-8; streets and other rights-of-way in subdivisions, § 90-211 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98; riding bicycles, skateboards, motorcycles or four wheelers on street or sidewalk, § 98-3; parades, § 98-131 et seq.; utilities, ch. 102; zoning, ch. 106; off-street automobile parking and storage, § 106-203; off-street loading and unloading space, § 106-204. 
State Law reference— Constitutional powers regarding streets, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); authority of municipalities to own, operate and maintain streets, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; street obstructions, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10; municipal street administration, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; assessments for improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 86-1. - Acceptance of streets. 
No new street shall be accepted by the city from a subdivision builder or individual unless it has been paved according to the state highway regulations. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-1; Code 2005, § 86-1)  
Sec. 86-2. - Obstructions in street or sidewalk. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall obstruct the free use of the streets of the city or the passage through and over the streets by the general public or cause any obstruction whatever to be placed in or kept in any of the streets of the city, except as provided in this section. 
(b)  Storage of building material or other material. No person shall occupy the streets of the city temporarily with building or other material without first obtaining permission in writing signed by the city manager, who may grant such permission provided not over one-third of the street is obstructed at any one time. 
(c)  Display or sale of merchandise. Where permitted, it shall be lawful to display or sell goods, wares or merchandise not restricted or prohibited by law on city sidewalks in the central business district zoned CH, within three linear feet of the building in which the licensed business resides, provided the display does not block or restrict egress of 36 inches along the adjacent sidewalk. No person shall place for display or sell any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind upon any of the sidewalks of the city not zoned CH. Vending machines and other goods, wares or merchandise too large to be removed from the sidewalk when the business is closed will not be allowed. Any business that displays goods, wares or merchandise on city sidewalks agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the city against claims or expenses, including attorneys' fees, for bodily injury or property damage for accidents or occurrences arising out of the business's operation. 
(d)  Obstruction of sidewalks. No person or business entity or nonprofit organization shall obstruct, in any manner, the concreted areas, which constitute the sidewalks of the city, throughout the city. This prohibition includes the parking of, or the extension onto and blocking the passageway of the sidewalk, by motorized vehicles. Also, vending machines, support posts of signs, awnings or overhangs, temporary signs, etc., or any other similar type of device, unless specifically permitted in this section. Temporary blockage of the sidewalk, for loading and unloading equipment, furniture, supplies, etc., shall be permitted; provided the obstruction does not exist for more than eight hours and does not continue overnight. 
(e)  Permit required for permanent improvement. No person or business entity or nonprofit organization shall construct or install any permanent improvement or obstruction in the right-of-way area (such as a tree, culvert or masonry mailbox) which is owned by the city, unless having received a specific permit for such purpose from the city. The city manager or his designee shall have the authority to issue a permit, including creating a form for said purpose and formulating any needed criteria for determining approval of such a request. The fee shall be set by the mayor and city council by resolution and shall be amended from time to time. If no fee has been formally adopted, all permits shall be issued at no charge. 
(f)  Awnings, canopies, marquees and business shingle signs. 
(1)  Permit. It shall be unlawful for any person or business to erect, construct or maintain any awning, canopy, marquee or business shingle sign attached to any building or structure, which shall extend over the public right-of-way or surface of any street, lane or alley, including the sidewalk area, in the city without first obtaining a building permit specifically authorizing said awning, canopy, marquee or business shingle sign improvement from the city manager or his designee. 
(2)  Permit application, plans and specifications. No permit shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter for erection, construction or maintenance of any awning, canopy, marquee or business shingle sign contemplated by this chapter, except upon compliance with the following conditions: 
a.  Written application for such building permit shall be made to the city manager or his designee, and shall contain the name and address of the applicant and the proposed location, dimensions and description of the awning, canopy, marquee or business shingle sign. 
b.  A copy of the plans and specifications of the awning, canopy, marquee or business shingle sign shall be furnished to the city manager or designee, and shall be attached to and filed with the building permit. 
(3)  Construction specifications. Regulations as to construction of awnings, canopies, marquee or business shingle sign extending over streets, lanes, alleys and other public places/rights-of-way, including sidewalks, shall be as follows: 
a.  Each fixed awning, canopy, marquee or business shingle sign shall be entirely supported from a building or structure. 
b.  No awning, canopy, marquee or business shingle sign shall project over the sidewalk or public right-of-way more than two-thirds the width of the sidewalk or five feet from the building face, whichever is greater. 
c.  Each fixed or movable awning, canopy, marquee shall have a minimum clearance of eight feet at the lowest part thereof above the surface of the sidewalk or other public property/right-of-way directly below. 
d.  Business shingle signs shall be attached directly to the awning, canopy or marquee frame, shall be considered part of the awning, canopy or marquee and shall have a minimum clearance of 7.5 feet at the lowest part thereof above the surface of the sidewalk or other public property/right-of-way directly below. 
(4)  Penalty. Failure to comply with the above regulation will result in an immediate stop work order issued. Failure to meet and apply for a building permit within 72 hours of the stop work order being issued shall result in a citation of violation of this section and section 106-206(i) being issued. Penalty shall be as authorized in section 1-7. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-2; Code 2005, § 86-2; Ord. No. 01203, § 1, 11-8-1999; Ord. No. 01244, § 1, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 01253, exh. 2005-E, 12-12-2005)  
Sec. 86-3. - Street improvements. 
(a)  This section shall govern the grading, macadamizing, paving, or otherwise improving of streets of the city. 
(b)  In assessing the cost to be charged (which cost shall constitute a lien against the property abutting on each side of any street or portion of a street to be graded, paved, macadamized, or otherwise improved), each lot or parcel of land abutting on the portion of the street to be so improved shall be charged at an equal rate per foot of such frontage abutting on such portion of the street with its just pro rata share of the entire cost of such improvement, including improvement of intersections and intersecting streets, under the following method: one-third of the cost of such improvement shall be assessed against the property abutting on each side of the street or portion of street to be improved, so that two-thirds of the entire cost of such improvement shall be assessed against the property abutting on the street or portion of street to be so improved. The amount of such cost to be assessed per foot of frontage against the property abutting on each side of the street or portion of street to be so improved shall be determined by first determining the entire cost of such improvement, including the improvement of intersecting streets, ascertaining one-third of such entire cost as the amount to be assessed against the entire property abutting on each side of such street or portion of street to be improved, and dividing the amount so ascertained by the number of linear feet frontage on each side of the street or portion of street to be improved. 
(c)  After publication of a notice of the filing and presentation of a petition for improvement of any street or portion of street in the city, and of proposed action of the mayor and city council thereon, and following passage of a resolution by the mayor and city council providing for such improvement, the city manager shall prepare an estimate of the entire cost of such work and shall determine the amount of assessment to be levied against each improved parcel under the method of computation described in subsection (b) of this section. The city manager shall report his findings to the mayor and city council, and a copy of such findings shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(d)  The city manager shall publish a notice of the filing of his report, with a statement of the estimated entire cost of such improvement, the amount stated therein as an amount per foot frontage to be assessed against abutting property, and the total amount stated therein to be assessed against each lot or parcel of land abutting on the street or portion of street to be improved, with a further statement of the time and place of the meeting of the mayor and city council to consider and take action on the report. This notice shall be published in two consecutive issues of a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least ten days prior to the date of meeting of the mayor and city council for consideration thereof. 
(e)  After the publication of the notice, the mayor and city council shall meet at the time and place stated in the notice, for the purpose of acting on the report and determining the entire cost of such improvement, the amount per foot frontage to be assessed against the property abutting on the street or portion of street to be improved, and the amount to be assessed against each lot or parcel of land abutting on such street or portion of street. The city manager's report may be accepted, corrected, amended, or rejected by the mayor and city council. At such meeting any owner of property abutting on the street or portion of street proposed to be improved shall have the right to appear in person or by agent or attorney and to be heard on the question of the correctness of the amount of the entire cost of such improvement proposed by the mayor and city council, or the apportionment thereof, and shall have the right to introduce any competent evidence in support of his contentions. 
(f)  After considering the report of the city manager and hearing from any person who desires to be heard in reference to the matters stated, the mayor and city council shall finally determine all such matters, and shall by ordinance or resolution fix the amount of the entire cost of such improvement, the amount per foot frontage chargeable or to be assessed against the property abutting on the street or portion of street to be so improved, and the total amount of such cost to be assessed against each lot or parcel of land abutting on the street or portion of street to be improved, the determination of which, when so made by the mayor and city council, shall be final and conclusive, except as provided for in subsection (g) of this section. 
(g)  If after such determination and assessment by the mayor and city council it appears that the costs of such improvements have been underestimated, then the mayor and city council shall have the authority, by following the procedure provided for in this section and by the law governing the city, to make any additional assessments necessary against the property liable to assessment for such improvement. If it shall appear, when completed, and assessments therefor have been paid, that the cost of such improvements, including all expenses incurred by the city in connection with making the improvements, other than the one-third of such cost to be paid by the city, has been overestimated, then the assessments against the abutting property and against abutting property owners shall be reduced and rebated to the actual cost of such improvement, including any expense incurred by the city in connection with the improvement other than the one-third of such cost to be paid by the city. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-3; Code 2005, § 86-3) 
Charter reference— Authority to assess all costs of improvements, § 4.18; authority to open, improve streets, § 5.10.  
Sec. 86-4. - Permit required for sidewalk construction. 
No sidewalk of any description shall be built by any individual, firm or corporation, of any brick, wood or other material, without a written permit from the city. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-9; Code 2005, § 86-4)  
Sec. 86-5. - Damaging street or sidewalk with harrows or other equipment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drag or run, or cause to be dragged or run, any harrow or other implement, engine, machine or tool upon any asphalt, bithulitic, warrenite or other type of permanently paved street or sidewalk of the city which shall be liable in any way to injure or cut the surface thereof. It shall also be unlawful to injure any dirt street in the same manner. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-10; Code 2005, § 86-5)  
Secs. 86-6—86-28. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 
 
Sec. 86-29. - Permit required; exception. 
No person shall make any excavations or openings or dig any ditch, trench, tunnel or hole in, along, across or under any street, sidewalk or other public place for the purpose of laying or placing therein any pipe, wires, or poles for any other purposes, unless a written permit therefor has been issued by the city manager. A permit shall not be required where the work is performed under a contract with the city, but if work requires a sidewalk or street to be wholly or partially obstructed, at least two hours before obstructing the sidewalk or street, the person shall notify the city manager and the police department during normal business hours and notify 911 after normal business hours, unless prevented by sudden emergency. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-4; Code 2005, § 86-31)  
Sec. 86-30. - Application for permit. 
All persons desiring a permit in order to make an opening in any street or sidewalk, as set forth in section 86-29, shall make written application therefor, which application shall show the location of the proposed opening, the purpose therefor and the approximate number of square yards of surface to be cut. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-5; Code 2005, § 86-32)  
Sec. 86-31. - Indemnification of city. 
Any person obtaining a permit as provided for in sections 86-29 and 86-30 agrees, as a condition of the issuance of the permit, to indemnify and hold harmless the city against any claims or expenses, including attorneys' fees, for bodily injury or property damage for accidents or occurrences arising out of the person's operations. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-6; Code 2005, § 86-33)  
Sec. 86-32. - Refilling and restoration of surface. 
When any part of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place of the city shall be torn or dug up for any purpose, the person making that excavation or opening shall have the duty of refilling the excavation or opening so as to restore it to essentially the same condition that existed prior to the excavation or opening. Any person neglecting, refusing or failing to comply with any provisions of this section shall be guilty of a violation thereof; and where any neglect, refusal or failure is continued, after notice from the city manager, every day's continuance thereafter shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-7; Code 2005, § 86-34)  
Sec. 86-33. - Guard rails, signal lights and other warnings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who obtains a permit under this article to do any excavation of any kind which may create or cause a dangerous condition in or near any street, alley, sidewalk or public place of the city without placing and maintaining proper guard rails and signal lights or other warnings at, in or around the work, sufficient to warn the public of any excavation or work, and to protect all persons using reasonable care from injuries on account of the work. 
(Code 1990, § 5-2-8; Code 2005, § 86-35)  
Secs. 86-34—86-54. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CLOSING A PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY 
 
Sec. 86-55. - Conditions for closure. 
A public right-of-way may be closed if it, through the determination of the city manager, final approval by the mayor and city council, and with the consent of all affected property owners associated with the public access that this public right-of-way provides, has been determined to have been reduced to obsolescence and is of absolutely no use to the city and those affected property owners associated with the public access that this public right-of-way provides. 
(Code 2005, § 86-61; Ord. No. 01246, § 1(3-5-1), 2-14-2005)  
Sec. 86-56. - Procedure for closure. 
Upon petition from the abutting property owners and consent from those property owners who would be potentially adversely affected by the closure and sale of this obsolete public right-of-way, the city shall concur with the sale of this absolutely obsolete public right-of-way to the abutting property owners, provided that the following procedures are strictly adhered to: 
(1)  Petitioning abutting property owners must consult with the city manager or his designee concerning city's agreement that the subject public right-of-way is obsolete and the city has no need, now or in the future, for the property. Additionally, letters of agreement from all potentially affected property owners must be supplied by the petitioners to the city. However, the concurrence of the city manager in no way guarantees that the final decision of the mayor and city council shall be in agreement with that of the city manager. This final determination can only be made at a public meeting, autonomously, by the mayor and city council itself. 
(2)  Upon receiving a preliminary evaluation from the city manager or his designee that the property is indeed absolutely obsolete, petitioning property owners shall contact the city attorney to have the necessary legal paperwork drawn up. The petitioners is responsible for all associated legal fees to have the proper legal paperwork drawn up. A plat of the abutting property completed by a state certified land surveyor, showing the right-of-way, any and all public infrastructure running through the public right-of-way (or along property of the petitioners; and which shall require a dedicated easement shown upon such submitted plat), all abutting property and all affected property owners shall be provided by the petitioner, the cost to be borne by the petitioner, to the city manager for review. The city attorney or a designated representative from the city shall contact all potentially affected property owners and verify that they are aware of the petition to close the public right away, and they concur that this action shall not be a detriment to their use of the potentially affected property now and for perpetuity. 
(3)  The department of planning and public works, or a designated representative from the city designated so by the city manager, shall review the submitted plat and verify its accuracy. Specific elements to be reviewed shall be accuracy of property lines and dimensions, location and dimensions of public right-of-way and the square footage contained therein, and whether any city public infrastructure exists in the public right-of-way (such as water, sewer or gas lines). If such infrastructure exists, an easement of 40 feet for sewer and gas and a 20-foot easement for water lines shall be provided on the submitted plat of the public right-of-way to be closed. If all information appears to be in order, the city representative shall make such a recommendation to the city manager. If not, the reasons for the denial shall be relayed to the city manager. Upon all elements of the process being completed, the city manager shall schedule the public meeting on the road closure, which is normally a portion of the regular monthly mayor and city council meeting. 
(4)  It is hereby declared that the value of public property comprising public right-of-way shall be, at the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived and until this value amount is updated or amended by the mayor and city council of the city through resolution, $5,000.00 per acre. For the purposes of applying this value to the public right-of-way which is to be sold to private parties, an acre of land shall be defined as containing exactly 44,000 square feet (a Tallapoosa acre). To calculate the value of the affected public right-of-way, the total square footage contained in the affected section of public right-of-way shall be ascertained. That figure shall be divided by 44,000 square feet to give a percentage of one Tallapoosa acre. This percentage shall be multiplied by the $5,000.00 figure, and that figure shall be the amount of money to be paid to the city by the recipient petitioners. 
Example: 300 feet of a 60-foot-wide public right-of-way is petitioned to be closed. The total square footage of this area is 18,000. 18,000 square feet is 40.9 percent of one 44,000 square foot Tallapoosa acre; this figure shall be rounded down to the lowest whole number, or 40 percent, in this example. Multiplying $5,000.00 by this percentage results in a figure of $2,000.00. This sales cost, in addition to all legal fees paid to the city attorney, must be paid to the city prior to the city deeding the land to the private property owners. 
(5)  At the discretion of a sole petitioner where two individuals would receive a portion of the right-of-way (generally, 50 percent of the right-of-way goes to the property owner abutting either side of the right-of-way), the sole petitioner may pay for the entire sales cost, but 50 percent of the right-of-way would still be deeded to the other abutting right-of-way land owner. 
(Code 2005, § 86-62; Ord. No. 01246, § 1(3-5-2), 2-14-2005)  
Sec. 86-57. - Refund of purchase fee. 
In the case where a property developer needs to close a public right-of-way to improve the quality of their development, due to the location of the old public right-of-way interfering with the best and highest use development practice, a property developer shall be provided with the ability to have the purchase price of the closed city right-of-way refunded, provided that the following stipulations are fulfilled: 
(1)  The property developer follows the procedures contained in section 106-206(i), submitting a preliminary and final plat. The final plat must be submitted to the city and ready for approval by the mayor and city council within six months of the public right-of-way being closed by the mayor and city council. 
(2)  The newly submitted property subdivision includes newly dedicated public right-of-way for the construction of new roads and other public infrastructure. Such newly dedicated public right-of-way must be at least 75 percent of the acreage quantity of the closed right-of-way, for a full 100 percent refund. If less than 75 percent, purchase fees paid to have the old city right-of-way closed shall be refunded based on a comparison between closed old right-of-way acreage and newly created right-of-way acreage; whatever that percentage (one percent to 74 percent), that percentage shall be multiplied by the purchase fee and that quantity refunded to the fee payee or petitioner, if those are different. 
(Code 2005, § 86-63; Ord. No. 01246, § 1(3-5-3), 2-14-2005)  
Chapter 90 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat or subdivision saved from repeal, § 1-11(10); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 42; floods, ch. 50; planning and development. ch. 74; utilities, ch. 102; zoning, ch. 106. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 90-1. - Purpose and intent. 
The ordinance from which this chapter is derived is enacted for the following purposes: 
(1)  Encourage economically sound and stable land development; 
(2)  Ensure the provision of required streets, utilities, and other facilities and services to land developments; 
(3)  Ensure adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in land developments; 
(4)  Ensure the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in land developments through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational and other public purposes; and 
(5)  Ensure that land is developed in conformity with the comprehensive plan of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-2; Code 2005, § 90-1)  
Sec. 90-2. - Conflicting regulations. 
Whenever the provisions of this chapter and those of some other ordinance or statute apply to the same subject matter, the provisions requiring the highest, or more strict, standard shall govern. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-3; Code 2005, § 90-2)  
Sec. 90-3. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Terms not defined in this section shall have their customary dictionary definitions where not inconsistent with the context. 
Building line means the line parallel to the street right-of-way which indicates the minimum required front yard setback at which building construction may begin. Such setback shall be measured from the specific public street's right-of-way or, in the case of flag developments, shall be measured from the rear or side lot line of the lot between the proposed lot and the public street right-of-way; and in accordance with the front yard setback for that specific zoning district. At this line or point of intersection, the minimum lot width shall be measured. 
Lot means a portion or parcel of land separated from other portions or parcels by description as on a subdivision plat or record of survey map or as described by metes and bounds, and intended for transfer or for building development. For the purpose of this chapter, the term "lot" does not include any portion of a dedicated right-of-way. 
Setback, front yard, means mandated minimum open space free of buildings. Such space exists between the public street right-of-way and the location of a building. Such setback shall be measured from the right-of-way of the individual street (whereby the right-of-way shall vary) and comply with the setback requirements of the specific zoning district. In the case of flag developments, the front yard setback shall be measured from the rear or side lot line of the lot immediately facing the proposed front yard of the residential building (generally determined by the front door or main entrance of the building). 
Street means a public right-of-way, for vehicular traffic, whether designated as an avenue, boulevard, road, highway, expressway, etc., which is intended to provide the principal means of access to abutting property. A street shall attain the status of a public right-of-way or public street through dedication, design and construction in accordance with article IV, division 2, subdivision II of this chapter and final acceptance by the mayor and city council. For the purpose of this chapter, streets are divided into the following categories: 
Alley means a minor way used for service access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
Collector street means a street within a subdivision used to carry traffic from the minor streets to the major streets, and includes the principal entrance and circulation streets of a subdivision. 
Cul-de-sac means a minor street with only one outlet, sometimes called a dead-end street. 
Major roads means those roads designated as such on the major thoroughfare plan of the city. 
Marginal access street means a minor street parallel and adjacent to major streets and which provides access to abutting properties with protection from through traffic. 
Minor street means a street used primarily for access to the abutting properties. 
Subdivider means the person having such a proprietary interest in the land to be subdivided as will authorize the maintenance of proceedings to subdivide such land under this chapter, or the authorized agent of such person for the purpose of proceeding under this chapter. 
Subdivision means all divisions of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites, or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy, or building development, and includes all division of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included within this definition: 
(1)  The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to the standards of the city; and/or 
(2)  The division of land into parcels of five acres or more where no new street is involved. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-4; Code 2005, § 90-3; Ord. No. 01227, § 1, 3-11-2002) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2.  
Secs. 90-4—90-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PLATTING JURISDICTION; ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 90-25. - Platting authority. 
The mayor and city council, or their designee, shall be the official platting authority, and no plat of a land subdivision shall be entitled to record in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county unless it shall have the approval of the mayor and city council, or their designee, inscribed thereon. The filing or recording of a plat of a subdivision without the approval of the mayor and city council, or their designee, as required by this chapter, is declared to be an offense. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-11; Code 2005, § 90-31)  
Sec. 90-26. - Use of unrecorded plat. 
The transfer of, sale of, agreement to sell, or negotiation to sell land by reference to or exhibition of or other use of a plat of a subdivision that has not been given final approval by the mayor and city council, or their designee, and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county is prohibited, and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-12; Code 2005, § 90-32)  
Sec. 90-27. - Acceptance of streets. 
The mayor and city council shall not accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave, or light any street or lay any utility lines in any street, which had not attained the status of a public street prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, unless such street corresponds to the street location shown on an approved subdivision plat or on an official street map adopted by the city, provided that the mayor and city council may accept, lay out, open and improve any street not so platted if they first determine such proposed street to be in harmony with city plans. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-13; Code 2005, § 90-33)  
Sec. 90-28. - Access to public street required. 
No building permit shall be issued and no building shall be erected on any lot in the city unless the street giving access thereto has been accepted as a public street in accordance with this chapter, or unless such street had attained the status of a public street prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, or is a street accepted by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-14; Code 2005, § 90-34)  
Secs. 90-29—90-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PLAT REQUIREMENTS AND PROCEDURES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 90-60. - Pre-application review. 
Whenever the subdivision of a tract of land within the city is proposed, the subdivider is urged to consult informally with the mayor and city council or its designee. The subdivider may submit sketch plans and data showing existing conditions within the site and in its vicinity and the proposed layout and development of the subdivision. No fee shall be charged for the pre-application review and no formal application shall be required. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-21; Code 2005, § 90-61)  
Secs. 90-61—90-78. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - TENTATIVE APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT 
 
Sec. 90-79. - Application for preliminary plat approval. 
Following the pre-application review of a proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall submit to the mayor and city council, at least 15 days prior to the next regular meeting of the mayor and city council, the following: 
(1)  A letter requesting review and approval of a preliminary plat and giving the name and address of a person to whom the notice of the hearing by the mayor and city council on the preliminary plat shall be sent. 
(2)  Five copies of the preliminary plat and other documents as specified in division 3 of this article. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-31; Code 2005, § 90-81)  
Sec. 90-80. - Review of preliminary plat. 
(a)  The mayor and city council or their designee shall check the plat for conformance to the rules and regulations of this chapter and shall afford a hearing on the preliminary plat, notice of the time and place of which shall be sent by the mayor and city council by registered or certified mail to the person designated in the letter requesting preliminary plat review and approval, not less than five days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(b)  Thereafter, the mayor and city council shall give tentative approval or disapproval to the preliminary plat. A notation of the action shall be made on two copies of the preliminary plat, including a statement of the reasons for disapproval if the preliminary plat is disapproved. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider or his agent and one copy added to the records of the mayor and city council. 
(c)  Tentative approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat. It indicates only approval of the layout as a guide to the preparation of the final plat. Tentative approval shall expire and be null and void after a period of one year unless an extension of time is approved by the mayor and city council. 
(d)  If action on a preliminary plat is not taken by the mayor and city council within 30 days of the date of submittal, the preliminary plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-32; Code 2005, § 90-82)  
Secs. 90-81—90-103. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PRELIMINARY PLAT SPECIFICATIONS 
 
Sec. 90-104. - Scale. 
The preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at a scale not smaller than 100 feet to one inch. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-41; Code 2005, § 90-101)  
Sec. 90-105. - Sheet size. 
Sheet size for the preliminary plat shall be 17 by 21 inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet of this size, it may be shown on more than one sheet with an index map on a separate sheet of the same size. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-42; Code 2005, § 90-102)  
Sec. 90-106. - Ground elevations; benchmarks. 
(a)  The preliminary plat shall show ground elevations, based on the datum plane of the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey (or a datum plane approved by the county engineer), as follows: 
(1)  For land that slopes less than approximately two percent, show spot elevations at all breaks in grade, along all drainage channels or swales, and at selected points not more than 100 feet apart in all directions. 
(2)  For land that slopes more than approximately two percent: 
a.  If the ground slope is regular, show contours with an interval of not more than five feet. 
b.  If the ground slope is irregular, show contours with an interval of not more than two feet. 
(b)  A tie to one or more benchmarks shall be shown. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-43; Code 2005, § 90-103)  
Sec. 90-107. - Required information. 
The preliminary plat shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the owner of record and of the subdivider. 
(2)  Proposed name of the subdivision and its acreage. 
(3)  North point, graphic scale, and date. 
(4)  Vicinity map showing the location of the subdivision. 
(5)  Exact boundary lines of the tract by bearings and distances. 
(6)  Names of owners of record of adjoining land. 
(7)  Existing streets, utilities and easements on and adjacent to the tract. 
(8)  Proposed layout, including streets and alleys, with proposed street names, lot lines with approximate dimensions, easements, land to be reserved or dedicated for public uses, and any land to be used for the purposes other than single-family dwellings. 
(9)  Lots numbered in numerical order and blocks lettered alphabetically. 
(10)  Provisions for water supply, sewerage, and drainage. Drainage shall include the control and direction of stormwater runoff. Preliminary plans must address and conspicuously display how stormwater runoff shall be directed and controlled such that erosion off-site is eliminated and stormwater does not negatively affect neighboring property. Such plans shall conform with federal national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) standards. 
(11)  Minimum building front yard setback lines. The building line shall generally duplicate the front yard setback line and comply with the front yard setback standard. At this line, the minimum lot width shall be established according to the zoning district. The building line must be parallel to the public street right-of-way. In the instance of flag developments, the front yard setback may apply to two lines of the lot if the residential building does not face the street right-of-way. In the case of curves and cul-de-sacs, the minimum lot width shall be measured in a straight line where the side lot lines and the building lines intersect. The front yard setback and the building line shall be measured from the public street right-of-way. The measured length of this building line shall be indicated. 
(12)  Such street cross sections and centerline profiles as may be required by the city engineer. The following minimum standards shall be displayed for verification and affirmation: cross section of the proposed roadway displaying both shoulders, curbs and pavement, with dimensions both horizontal and vertical. If a drainage swale is to be constructed, it must be displayed on the preliminary plat. All planned roadway improvements must comply with article IV, division 2, and article V of this chapter. 
(13)  Each lot shall be served by a separate, single, dedicated driveway. No driveway shall serve more than one residential building. The driveway's location and dimensions (including curve radius from the public street into the driveway) shall be depicted for each lot. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-44; Code 2005, § 90-104; Ord. No. 01220, § 1, 12-10-2001; Ord. No. 01227, § 1, 3-11-2002)  
Sec. 90-108. - Certificate of tentative approval. 
A certificate of tentative approval of the preliminary plat shall be inscribed on the plat as follows: 
Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Regulations of Tallapoosa, Georgia, all the requirements of Tentative Approval having been fulfilled, this Preliminary Plat was given Tentative Approval by the Mayor and City Council on ________, 20___. 
This Tentative Approval does not constitute approval of a Final Plat. This Certificate of Tentative Approval shall expire and be null and void on: 
_____
(Date) 
_____
(Date) 	_____
Mayor 
 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-45; Code 2005, § 90-105)  
Secs. 90-109—90-129. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - FINAL PLAT PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 90-130. - Application for final plat approval. 
After the preliminary plat of a proposed land subdivision has been given tentative approval by the mayor and city council, the subdivider may, within one year from tentative approval, submit to the mayor and city council: 
(1)  A letter requesting review and approval of a final plat and giving the name and address of the person to whom the notice of the hearing by the mayor and city council on the final plat shall be sent. 
(2)  Five copies of the final plat and other documents, as specified in division 5 of this article, the original and at least one copy of which shall be drawn in permanent ink on cloth. 
(3)  A final plat filing fee as fixed from time to time by the mayor and city council and a recording fee as established for the superior court of the county. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-51; Code 2005, § 90-131)  
Sec. 90-131. - Review of final plat. 
(a)  The mayor and city council or their designee shall check the final plat for conformance with the tentatively approved preliminary plat, and with the rules and regulations of this chapter, and shall afford a hearing on the final plat, notice of the time and place of which shall be sent by the mayor and city council by registered or certified mail to the person designated in the letter requesting final plat review and approval, not less than five days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(b)  Thereafter, the planning commission shall approve or disapprove the final plat. A notation of the action shall be made on the original tracing and two prints of the final plat, including a statement of the reasons therefor if the final plat is disapproved. If action on a final plat is not taken by the mayor and city council within 30 days of the date of the submittal, the final plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-52; Code 2005, § 90-132)  
Sec. 90-132. - Recording of final plat. 
(a)  Upon approval of a final plat, the mayor shall have the final plat recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county. The subdivider shall be responsible for the payment of the recording fee at the time of submitting the final plat as provided in section 90-131. 
(b)  Upon recording of the approved final plat, the original tracing or a reproducible linen print of the final plat with all certificates endorsed thereon shall be provided by the subdivider for the records of the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-53; Code 2005, § 90-133)  
Secs. 90-133—90-162. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - FINAL PLAT SPECIFICATIONS 
 
Sec. 90-163. - Required information and certifications. 
(a)  The final plat shall conform to and meet the specifications of the preliminary plat, with the additions specified in this section. 
(b)  The final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn in permanent ink on an acceptable tracing material. Sheet size shall be 17 by 21 inches, and where more than one sheet is required an index map shall be required on the same size sheet. The plat shall show: 
(1)  Bearings and distances to the nearest existing street lines or benchmarks or other permanent monuments (not less than three), which shall be accurately described on the plat. 
(2)  Municipal, county and land lot lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distance and angles when such lines traverse or are reasonably close to the subdivision. 
(3)  Exact boundary lines of the tract, determined by a field survey, giving distances to the nearest one-tenth foot and angles to the nearest minute, which shall be balanced and closed with an error of closure not to exceed one to 5,000. 
(4)  Name of subdivision, and exact locations, widths, and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the plat. 
(5)  Street centerlines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii, and lengths of tangents. 
(6)  Lot lines with dimensions to the nearest one-tenth foot and bearings. 
(7)  Lots numbered in numerical order and blocks lettered alphabetically. 
(8)  Location, dimensions, and purposes of any easements and any areas to be reserved or dedicated for public use. 
(9)  Accurate location, material, and description of monuments and markers. 
(10)  A statement, either directly on the plat or in an identified attached document, of any private covenants. 
(11)  The following certifications: 
a.  Engineer's or surveyor's certification. An engineer's or surveyor's certification, directly on the final plat, is required as follows: 
It is hereby certified that this plat is true and correct and was prepared from an actual survey of the property by me or under my supervision; that all monuments shown hereon actually exist or are marked as "Future," and their location, size, type and material are correctly shown; and that all engineering requirements of the Land Subdivision Ordinance of Tallapoosa, Georgia, have been fully complied with. 
By _____ 	Registered C.E. No. _____ 
_____	Registered Georgia Land Surveyor No. _____ 
 
b.  Owner's certification. An owner's certification, directly on the final plat, is required as follows: 
Owner's Certification: 
;adv05;State of Georgia, County of Haralson
