The owner of the land shown on this plat and whose name is subscribed hereto, in person or through a duly authorized agent, certifies that this Plat was made from an actual survey, that all state, city, and county taxes or other assessments now due on this land have been paid. 
Agent _____ 	Owner _____ 
Date _____ 	Date _____ 
 
c.  Certificate of dedication. A certification by the owner setting forth the description of the areas and improvements he dedicates to the public and the extent of the title which he is dedicating should be attached to the final plat. Because of the legal considerations here, this certificate should be approved as to form by the city attorney. 
d.  Copy of official action of mayor and city council. A copy of the ordinance adopted by the mayor and city council accepting the streets, improvements, easements and any other property dedicated by the owner for public use, as indicated on the final plat, shall be attached to the final plat before recording. 
e.  Certificate of approval by mayor and city council. A certificate of approval of the final plat by the mayor and city council, directly on the plat, is required as follows: 
Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Ordinance of Tallapoosa, Georgia, all the requirements of approval having been fulfilled, this Final Plat was given Final Approval by the Mayor and City Council on ________, 20___. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-61; Code 2005, § 90-151)  
Secs. 90-164—90-194. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN REQUIREMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 90-195. - Suitability of land. 
Land subject to flooding, improper drainage, or erosion or that is topographically or for other reasons unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for residential use or for any other use that will continue or increase the danger to health, safety, or property destruction, unless the hazards can be and are corrected. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-71; Code 2005, § 90-181)  
Sec. 90-196. - Name of subdivision. 
The name of the subdivision must have the approval of the mayor and city council. The name shall not duplicate or closely approximate the name of an existing subdivision. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-72; Code 2005, § 90-182)  
Sec. 90-197. - Access. 
Access to every subdivision shall be provided over a public street. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-73; Code 2005, § 90-183)  
Sec. 90-198. - Conformance to major thoroughfare plan and other plans. 
(a)  All streets and other features of the major thoroughfare plan of the city shall be platted by the subdivider in the location and to the dimension indicated on the major thoroughfare plan adopted by the mayor and city council. 
(b)  When features of other plans adopted by the mayor and city council (such as schools or other public building sites, parks, or other land for public uses) are located in whole or in part in a land subdivision, such features shall be either dedicated or reserved by the subdivider for acquisition within a reasonable time by the appropriate public agency. 
(c)  Whenever a plat proposes the dedication of land to public use that the mayor and city council find not required or suitable for such public use, the mayor and city council may refuse to approve the plat. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-74; Code 2005, § 90-184)  
Sec. 90-199. - Large-scale developments. 
The requirements of this article may be modified in the case of a large-scale community or neighborhood unit, such as a housing project or shopping center which is not subdivided into customary lots, blocks, and streets, if the development is approved by the mayor and city council and if it is in conformity with the purpose and intent of this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-75; Code 2005, § 90-185)  
Secs. 90-200—90-221. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - STREETS AND OTHER RIGHTS-OF-WAY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 
 
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 90-222. - Continuation of existing streets. 
Existing streets shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-81; Code 2005, § 90-211)  
Sec. 90-223. - Street names. 
Street names shall require the approval of the mayor and city council. Streets that are obviously in alignment with streets already existing and named shall be given the name of the existing street. Names of new streets shall not duplicate or closely approximate those of existing streets. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-82; Code 2005, § 90-212)  
Sec. 90-224. - Street jogs. 
Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-83; Code 2005, § 90-213)  
Sec. 90-225. - Cul-de-sacs. 
Except where topographic or other conditions make a greater length unavoidable, cul-de-sacs or dead-end streets shall not be greater in length than 500 feet. They shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having a property line radius of at least 100 feet with an outside pavement radius of at least 80 feet. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-84; Code 2005, § 90-214)  
Sec. 90-226. - Development along major thoroughfare, limited access highway or railroad right-of-way. 
Where a subdivision abuts or contains a major thoroughfare, a limited access highway, or a railroad right-of-way, the mayor and city council may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way either as a marginal access street or at a distance suitable for an appropriate use of the intervening land, with a non-access reservation suitably planted. Due regard should be given requirements for approach grades and future separations in determining distances. Lots shall have no access to major thoroughfares (or limited access highways), but only to access streets. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-85; Code 2005, § 90-215)  
Sec. 90-227. - Alleys. 
Alleys may be required at the rear of all lots used for multifamily, commercial, or industrial developments. Alleys will not be permitted in other type subdivisions unless the subdivider provides evidence satisfactory to the mayor and city council of the need for alleys. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-86; Code 2005, § 90-216)  
Sec. 90-228. - Reserve strips. 
Reserve strips controlling access to streets, alleys, and public grounds shall not be permitted unless their control is placed in the hands of the mayor and city council, under conditions approved by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-87; Code 2005, § 90-217)  
Sec. 90-229. - Easements. 
(a)  Utility easements. Easements having a minimum width of ten feet and located along the side or rear lot lines shall be provided as required for utility lines and underground mains and cables. 
(b)  Drainage easements. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater or drainage right-of-way of adequate width. Parallel streets may be required by the mayor and city council in connection therewith. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-88; Code 2005, § 90-218)  
Secs. 90-230—90-251. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Street Design 
 
Sec. 90-252. - Right-of-way width. 
The right-of-way width shall be the distance across a street from property line to property line. Minimum street right-of-way widths shall be as follows: 
(1)  Major street widths: As required by the major street plan. 
(2)  Collector streets: 60 feet. 
(3)  Minor streets and dead-end streets: 50 feet. 
(4)  Alleys: 20 feet. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-101; Code 2005, § 90-241)  
Sec. 90-253. - Pavement width. 
Street pavement widths shall be as follows: 
(1)  Collector streets: 36 feet. 
(2)  Minor streets and dead-end streets: 20 feet. 
(3)  Alleys: 16 feet. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-102; Code 2005, § 90-242; Ord. No. 01220, § 1, 12-10-2001)  
Sec. 90-254. - Grade. 
Maximum and minimum street grades shall be as follows: 
(1)  Grades of major streets shall not be in excess of seven percent. 
(2)  Grades of collector streets shall not be in excess of ten percent. 
(3)  Grades of minor streets and dead-end streets and alleys shall not be in excess of 14 percent. 
(4)  No street grade shall be less than one-half of one percent. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-103; Code 2005, § 90-243)  
Sec. 90-255. - Horizontal curvature. 
The minimum radii of centerline curvature shall be as follows: 
(1)  Major streets: As indicated on the major street plan, but in no case less than 800 feet. 
(2)  Collector streets: 200 feet. 
(3)  Minor streets and dead-end streets and alleys: 100 feet. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-104; Code 2005, § 90-244)  
Sec. 90-256. - Tangents. 
Between reverse curves, there shall be a tangent having a length not less than the following: 
(1)  Major streets: 200 feet. 
(2)  Collector streets: 100 feet. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-105; Code 2005, § 90-245)  
Sec. 90-257. - Vertical alignment. 
Vertical alignment shall be such that the following requirements are met: 
(1)  Major streets shall have a sight distance of at least 500 feet at six feet above ground level. 
(2)  Collector streets shall have a sight distance of at least 200 feet at six feet above ground level. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-106; Code 2005, § 90-246)  
Sec. 90-258. - Angle of intersections. 
Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersections shall be at an angle of less than 60 degrees. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-107; Code 2005, § 90-247)  
Sec. 90-259. - Curbline radius at intersections. 
The curbline radius at street intersections shall be at least 15 feet. Where the angle of street intersection is less than 90 degrees, a longer radius may be required. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-108; Code 2005, § 90-248)  
Sec. 90-260. - Curbs, pavement, shoulders and drainage swales. 
(a)  Curbs. Curbs may be either vertical "L" type or rollover type. 
(b)  Pavement. Road travelways shall be designed to the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Minimum of six inches of crushed stone base. 
(2)  Minimum of two inches of pavement, type B modified binder. 
(3)  Minimum of one inch of finish pavement, type F top course, to be installed at the point 75 percent of the planned homes in the development have been completed. 
A defined timeline for installation must be indicated in the plans submitted. 
(c)  Shoulders. Shoulders shall be graded a minimum of eight feet on both sides of the proposed road. This eight-foot shoulder zone shall begin at the edge of the back of the installed curb. The shoulder grade shall have a maximum slope of 1:3 (rise/run) and may be either rise or fall. 
(d)  Drainage swales. All drainage swales if installed shall begin at the outer edge of the graded shoulder zone. Slope of the swale wall shall be 1:2 (fall/rise to run) with a minimum depth of two feet. The swale channel shall be a minimum of four feet in width and be flat. 
(Code 2005, § 90-249; Ord. No. 1220, § 1(8-6-109), 12-10-2001)  
Sec. 90-261. - Compaction and depth tests. 
The following compaction verification and depth tests shall be provided to the city. The cost of these tests shall be the responsibility of the subdivision developer. The compaction standard shall be the same as that for state department of transportation road projects. These tests are as follows: 
(1)  Compaction test for crushed stone base (98 percent on all graded aggregate base). 
(2)  Compaction test for type B modified binder (95 percent Standard Proctor on asphalt); depth test on type B modified binder (minimum of two inches). 
(Code 2005, § 90-250; Ord. No. 01220, § 1(8-6-110), 12-10-2001)  
Secs. 90-262—90-285. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - BLOCKS AND LOTS 
 
Sec. 90-286. - Block length and width. 
Block lengths and widths shall be as follows: 
(1)  Blocks shall be not greater than 1,800 feet or less than 600 feet in length, except in unusual circumstances. 
(2)  Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where abutting upon major streets, limited access highways, or railroads or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-121; Code 2005, § 90-271)  
Sec. 90-287. - Lot size. 
(a)  Residential lots shall meet the lot width and lot area requirements of chapter 106, pertaining to zoning. 
(b)  Where individual septic tanks are used, the health officer shall prescribe minimum lot sizes to conform to health standards. 
(c)  Commercial and industrial lots shall be adequate to provide service areas and off-street parking suitable to the use intended. 
(d)  Residential corner lots shall have adequate width to meet building setback requirements from both abutting streets. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-122; Code 2005, § 90-272)  
Sec. 90-288. - Lot lines. 
All lot lines shall be perpendicular or radial to street lines, unless not practicable because of topographic or other features. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-123; Code 2005, § 90-273)  
Sec. 90-289. - Building lines. 
A building line meeting the front yard setback requirements of chapter 106, pertaining to zoning, shall be established on all lots. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-124; Code 2005, § 90-274)  
Sec. 90-290. - Lots to abut on public street. 
Each lot shall abut upon a dedicated public street. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-125; Code 2005, § 90-275)  
Sec. 90-291. - Double frontage and reverse frontage lots. 
Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement of at least ten feet, across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other disadvantageous use. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-126; Code 2005, § 90-276)  
Secs. 90-292—90-315. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - IMPROVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 90-316. - Required improvements. 
(a)  Every subdivider shall be required to have installed by the appropriate city agency at his expense, or with approval of the agency concerned, to install, the following street improvements and utilities: 
(1)  Except on major or limited access streets, street grading, curbs and gutters, and street paving. 
(2)  Sanitary sewer lines and manholes, storm drainage facilities where needed, sidewalks (when determined by the mayor and city council to be essential for the safety of pedestrians), and monuments and markers. 
(3)  If the required sewer line cannot be connected to a trunk line sewer at the time of the development of the subdivision, septic tanks, which shall be installed by and at the expense of the subdivider or lot purchaser for interim use, in conformity with the requirements of the county health department. 
(4)  Water mains within the subdivision with connections to each lot. 
(b)  All required street improvements, utilities and monuments shall be built to standards specified by the agency responsible for each. All utilities to be installed in the streets shall be placed and compacted prior to paving. 
(Code 1990, § 8-6-131; Code 2005, § 90-311)  
[1] 
Footnotes: 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 94-1—94-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PROPERTY TAXES 
 
Sec. 94-19. - Tax rate. 
An annual ad valorem tax upon all real and personal property within the city is hereby levied. The millage rate therefor shall be established each year by resolution of the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-1; Code 2005, § 94-31) 
Charter reference— Taxation, § 4.10 et seq. 
State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.  
Sec. 94-20. - Billing; payment. 
(a)  All ad valorem taxes due the city shall be billed and paid in one payment. 
(b)  Ad valorem tax bills, as adjusted to conform to the tax digest of the county, shall be payable on or before December 20, but in the event of adjustment by the state revenue commissioner, the city shall, within a reasonable time thereafter as may be determined by resolution of the mayor and city council, after receipt from the county of the adjustment information, refund any overpayments or bill for any underpayments. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-2; Code 2005, § 94-32) 
State Law reference— Installments, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-23.  
Sec. 94-21. - Collection of delinquent taxes; interest and penalty on delinquent taxes. 
(a)  For the collection of delinquent taxes, a fi. fa. shall be issued by the city clerk and executed by the sheriff or deputy sheriff of the county under the procedure provided by the laws of the state governing execution of process from the superior court, or by use of any other available process and remedies. Sales under execution shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements of O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 4, art. 1 (O.C.G.A. § 48-4-1 et seq.). 
(b)  A lien shall exist against all property on which city property taxes are levied, as of the assessment day of January 1 of each year, which shall be superior to all other liens except that it shall have equal dignity with those for federal, state or county taxes. 
(c)  The amount due on all delinquent fi. fa. issued under subsection (a) of this section, as well as any interest or penalty thereon, shall be listed as a part of and in addition to the annual ad valorem tax bill. 
(d)  Any license, privilege or permit granted by the city shall be revoked by the city clerk for the failure to pay any money due the city for taxes, fees, penalties, interests, fines or other revenue, within three calendar months and ten days after any payment is due, provided that any person aggrieved by the order may, within ten days thereof, appeal to the mayor and city council, who, after a hearing thereon, may approve or modify the order or restore the license, privilege or permit by adopting a motion to that effect, but only upon finding that the city clerk's action was not factually or legally correct. 
(e)  Unless otherwise provided in this Code, all fi. fa. issued under this section shall earn interest at the maximum rate allowed by state law in addition to a ten percent delinquent penalty. 
(Code 1990, § 3-2-3; Code 2005, § 94-33) 
Charter reference— Collection of tax, § 4.10 et seq. 
State Law reference— Interest on past due tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-2-40; executions, O.C.G.A. §§ 9-13-1 et seq., 48-3-2 et seq.; tax sales, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-4-1 et seq., 48-4-75 et seq.  
Secs. 94-22—94-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - BUSINESS AND OCCUPATION TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Occupational taxes, § 4.15. 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Occupational and business tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-2 et seq. 
 
Sec. 94-46. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
Dominant line means the type of business within a multiple-line business from which the greatest amount of income is derived. 
Employee. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (2) of this definition, the term "employee" means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax, or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for the purposes of documenting compensation a form IRS W-2 but not a form IRS 1099. 
(2)  An individual who performs work under the direction and supervision of one business or practitioner in accordance with the terms of a contract or agreement with another business which recruits such individual is an employee of the business or practitioner which issues to such individual for the purposes of documenting compensation a form IRS W-2. 
Location and office mean and include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. The renter's or lessee's location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner or lessor or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner or lessor or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner or lessor or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing the real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession, or occupation at such site. 
Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business and enacted by a local government as a revenue-raising ordinance or resolution. 
Person means and includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, or any other form of business organization. 
Practitioner of profession or occupation means one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, as permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or as an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the local government. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee or registration fee. Regulatory fees do not include development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development. 
(Code 2005, § 94-61; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-2, 12-11-1995) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions applied to occupational taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5.  
Sec. 94-47. - Business license required. 
Each person engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation from a location in the city (whether the main office or main place of business, or residence, is within or without the city or the state) shall take out a license for such business, trade, profession, or occupation, which license shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business. 
(Code 2005, § 94-62; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-1, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-48. - Assessment of tax by number of employees; restrictions; application fee. 
(a)  Tax schedule. The method of assessment of tax by number of employees allows assessment of an amount for each employee as the basis for taxation. For the purposes of this section, an employee is defined as an individual who works 40 hours per week and receives a W-2 from an employer. Part-time employees' total hours will be divided by 40 to determine the number of full-time equivalents. 
Tax Assessment by Number of Employees 
Employees 	Tax Liability 
2 or less 	$0.00 per employee (plus $125.00 fee) 
3 or more 	$10.00 per employee (plus $125.00 fee) 
 
(b)  Restrictions; application fee. 
(1)  The city shall not require the payment of more than one occupational tax for each location that a business or practitioner shall have, nor shall the city require that a business pay occupational tax for more than 100 percent of the gross receipts. 
(2)  The city shall not require an occupation tax on those receipts that were taxed by occupation tax in other localities or states. 
(3)  The city shall not require a business license from those real estate brokers, agents, or companies whose offices are located outside the city and sell property inside the limits of the city. 
(4)  An occupation tax shall not be levied in any manner except as described in this section. 
(5)  No tax in excess of $1,200.00 shall be due from any taxpayer, it being the express finding of the mayor and city council that significant erosion of the tax base has occurred, that retention of existing businesses and attraction of new businesses is essential to the community and that the establishment of a ceiling on occupation tax rates will serve as an incentive to further the city's goals of attracting and keeping quality development in the city. 
(6)  The city shall impose a $125.00, per business, application fee that is nonrefundable. The application fee shall be used to administer the occupation tax system. 
(Code 2005, § 94-63; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-4, 12-11-1995; Ord. No. 01198, 4-13-1998; Ord. No. 01225, 12-17-2001) 
Charter reference— Occupational tax authorized, § 4.15. 
State Law reference— Levy of occupational tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-6.  
Sec. 94-49. - Each line of business to be identified on license. 
The business license of each business licensed by the city shall identify the lines of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the revenue collection division and that line of business being imprinted by the revenue collection division upon the business license. 
(Code 2005, § 94-64; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-6, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-50. - Each place of business considered separate business. 
Where a person conducts business at more than one store or place, each store or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of the business license and occupation tax. 
(Code 2005, § 94-65; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-7, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-51. - Tax on practitioners and professionals. 
Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  A fee of $300.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner electing to pay $300.00 per practitioner shall not be required to provide information to the city relating to the gross receipts of the practitioner. The following is a list of such practitioners or professionals subject to these conditions: 
a.  Lawyers. 
b.  Physicians licensed under O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 34, art. 2 (O.C.G.A. § 43-34-20 et seq.). 
c.  Osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 34, art. 2 (O.C.G.A. § 43-34-20 et seq.). 
d.  Chiropractors. 
e.  Podiatrists. 
f.  Dentists. 
g.  Optometrists. 
h.  Psychologists. 
i.  Veterinarians. 
j.  Landscape surveyors. 
k.  Practitioners of physiotherapy. 
l.  Public accountants. 
m.  Embalmers. 
n.  Funeral directors. 
o.  Civil, mechanical, hydraulic, or electrical engineers. 
p.  Architects. 
q.  Marriage and family therapists, social workers, and professional counselors. 
r.  Pharmacists. 
(2)  Election to pay in accordance with the tax table by number of employees assigned to each location of business. 
(Code 2005, § 94-66; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-8, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Limitation on regulatory fees, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-9.  
Sec. 94-52. - Exemption for practitioners exclusively practicing for government. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state, or instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state, shall not be required to obtain a license for that purpose. 
(Code 2005, § 94-67; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-9, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Prohibited taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-13.  
Sec. 94-53. - Purpose of tax. 
The tax levied in this article is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade or calling. 
(Code 2005, § 94-68; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-10, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-54. - Payment of tax by current businesses. 
(a)  Each occupation tax levied by this article shall be for the calendar year unless otherwise specifically provided. Such registration and occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by February 1 of each year, be delinquent and subject to an interest charge of 1.5 percent per month until paid. 
(b)  Should such occupation tax not be paid before April 1, an additional penalty of ten percent of the tax or fee shall also be due. 
(Code 2005, § 94-69; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-11, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Penalty for failure to pay tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21; issuance of execution against delinquent taxpayer, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26; amount of tax due from business commencing business on or after July 1, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21.  
Sec. 94-55. - Payment of tax and regulatory fees by new businesses; proration of tax. 
(a)  On any new profession, trade, or calling begun in the city: 
(1)  The occupation tax is due within 30 days of January 1 of each year or within 30 days following commencement of a new business, whichever first occurs. 
(2)  Registration and regulatory fees shall be delinquent if not paid to the city immediately upon beginning business. 
(3)  However, the regulatory fees may be paid after commencing business or the practice of a profession when: 
a.  The work done or service provided is necessary for the health or safety of one or more individuals; 
b.  The work done or service provided has no adverse effect on any other person; and 
c.  Regulatory fees are tendered within two business days after commencing business or the practice of a profession. 
(b)  If the occupation tax or license fee is not paid, it shall be subject to an interest charge of 1.5 percent per month until paid. Additionally, should such occupation tax not be paid within 90 days of the first date the business transacted business in the city, an additional penalty of ten percent of the tax shall also be due. 
(c)  Any new profession, trade or calling beginning business in the city on or after July 1 shall be taxed at 50 percent of the annual rate pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-22. 
(Code 2005, § 94-70)  
Sec. 94-56. - Engaging in business without registration. 
The tax registration provided for in this article shall be issued by the tax clerk. If any person whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after such registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the city, any kind of profession, trade, or calling subject to this article without having first obtained such registration, such offender shall, upon conviction by the city, be punished pursuant to section 1-7. 
(Code 2005, § 94-71) 
State Law reference— Penalty for failure to pay tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21; amount of tax due from business commencing business on or after July 1, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21.  
Sec. 94-57. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. 
No business on which a business license or occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from such license or tax on the grounds that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless 80 percent or more of the entire proceeds from such business are devoted to such purpose. 
(Code 2005, § 94-72; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-13, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Charitable contribution, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5.  
Sec. 94-58. - Evidence of state license; display of state license. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed under O.C.G.A. tit. 43 (O.C.G.A. § 43-1-1 et seq.) by a state license examining board shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city license is issued. 
(b)  Each person who is subject to a city license and also is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Code 2005, § 94-73; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-14, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Duty to post, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-23.  
Sec. 94-59. - Evidence of qualification. 
(a)  Any business that is required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business license, shall show evidence of qualification. 
(b)  Any business that is required to submit an annual application for continuance of that business shall do so before the license is issued. 
(Code 2005, § 94-74; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-15, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-60. - Failure to obtain license; liability of officers and agents. 
All persons subject to the occupation taxes provided in this article shall be required to take out the necessary license for the business as prescribed in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a license. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the license provided for in this article before commencing the business, and any person transacting or offering to transact in city any kind of business, trade, profession or occupation without first having so obtained such license shall be subject to the penalties provided therefor. 
(Code 2005, § 94-75; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-16, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Time of payment, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-20.  
Sec. 94-61. - Powers of revenue collection division. 
The revenue collection division and its duly designated officers and inspectors or its successors shall be classified as deputy marshal-license inspectors with full subpoena and arresting powers in conjunction with any violation pertaining to this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-76; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-19, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-62. - Tax inapplicable where prohibited by law. 
The occupation tax is not levied upon the gross receipts of any part of a business where such levy is prohibited by the laws of the state or of the United States. 
(Code 2005, § 94-77; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-20, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-63. - Estimation of tax for new business. 
In the case of a business subject to occupation tax for a calendar year, which was not conducted for any period of time in the corporate limits of the city in the preceding year, the owner, proprietor, manager or executive officer of the business liable for occupation tax shall estimate the gross volume of revenue from the commencing date to the end of the calendar year. 
(Code 2005, § 94-78; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-23, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Estimation of tax due, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-22.  
Sec. 94-64. - Returns for businesses having more than one place or line of business. 
Where a business is operated at more than one place or where the business includes more than one line, the gross receipts of each location will be entered on a separate occupation tax return and each different line of business will have the gross receipts of that line of business identified on a form to be furnished by the revenue collection officer. 
(Code 2005, § 94-79; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-24, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Allocation of receipts for taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-14; classification rules, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-12.  
Sec. 94-65. - Inspection of books and records; interest on deficiencies. 
In any case, the revenue collection officer of the city, through his officers, agents, employees or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which returns are made. The revenue collection officer shall have the right to inspect the books or records for the business of which the return was made in the city, and upon demand of the revenue collection officer such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within 30 days. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall be grounds for revocation of the license currently existing to do business in the city. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the revenue collection officer at his discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of under-reporting, a penalty of 125 percent of the prime interest rate will be assessed for the period audited. For the purposes of this section, the prime interest rate shall be that which is published by The Wall Street Journal on the first business day of the year in which the under-reporting is identified. 
(Code 2005, § 94-80; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-27, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Records, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-14; confidentiality, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-15.  
Sec. 94-66. - Revocation of license for failure to pay tax, file returns, or permit inspection of books. 
Upon the failure of any business to pay the occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of such returns within the time required in this article, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as provided in section 94-65, any business license in the city for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business license shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax provided for in this article is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, firm or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the revenue collection officer in accordance with the provisions of section 94-65. 
(Code 2005, § 94-81; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-28, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-67. - Violations. 
Any person, and his managers, agents or employees, shall be subject to the penalties provided in this article if they: 
(1)  Do business in the city after their license for the business has been revoked as provided in this article; 
(2)  Are required to make returns showing the amount of gross receipts and fail to make such returns within the time and in the manner provided in this article; 
(3)  Refuse to amend such returns so as to set forth the truth; 
(4)  Make false returns; or 
(5)  Refuse to permit an inspection of books in their charge when representatives of the city request such inspection during the business hours for the purposes of determining the accuracy of the returns provided for in this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-82; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-29, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Penalty for failure to pay tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21.  
Sec. 94-68. - Execution for delinquent tax; civil fine. 
(a)  In addition to the other remedies available to the city for the collection of occupation taxes and regulatory fees due from persons subject to the tax or fee who fail or refuse to pay the tax or fee, the tax clerk shall issue executions against the delinquent taxpayers for any or all of the following: 
(1)  The amount of the taxes or fees due when the taxes or fees become due; 
(2)  Any penalty imposed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21(a); and 
(3)  Any interest imposed by the local ordinance in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21(b). 
(b)  The lien shall cover the property of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for the tax, all as provided by the law. The lien for the occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof become delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the revenue collection officer upon the property of the defendant located in the city, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of the execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as provided by law and the defendant in such execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by law in regard to tax executions. 
(c)  A court of competent jurisdiction for the enforcement of ordinances of the city may impose a civil fine for failure to pay the occupation tax or regulatory fee. Such a civil fine shall not exceed $500.00 and may be enforced by the contempt power of the court. 
(Code 2005, § 94-83; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-30, 12-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Issue of execution against delinquent taxpayers, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26; rights of defaulting taxpayer, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-25; delinquent tax liens established, O.C.G.A. § 44-14-320; priority of liens, O.C.G.A. § 48-2-56.  
Sec. 94-69. - Effect of entry of nulla bona. 
When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the revenue collection officer against any person defaulting on the license tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him as though he had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. 
(Code 2005, § 94-84) 
State Law reference— Effect of issuance of nulla bona, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-25.  
Sec. 94-70. - Amendment or repeal of provisions. 
This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the city council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the city of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. 
(Code 2005, § 94-85; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-31, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-71. - Taxes assessed under previous ordinances. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinances have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to take out the license provided for in such ordinance, or failure to comply with any other provisions thereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Code 2005, § 94-86; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-32, 12-11-1995)  
Sec. 94-72. - Enforcement. 
It is hereby made the duty of the revenue collection officer and police department to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed, and to summon all violators of this article to appear before the municipal court. It is hereby made the further duty of the revenue collection officer, the chief of police, members of the police department, and their assistants to inspect all licenses issued by the city, as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the license held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Code 2005, § 94-87; Ord. No. 01183, § 3-3-33, 12-11-1995)  
Secs. 94-73—94-102. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE EXCISE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverages Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 94-103. - Tax levied. 
Licensed wholesale dealers in malt beverages and wine shall pay to the city an excise tax in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  Five cents per 12-ounce container of malt beverages sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers as specified in subsection (2) of this section, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. 
(2)  Six dollars for each container of malt beverages containing not more than 15½ gallons, and at a like rate for fractional parts, where the beverage is sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, that beverage being commonly known as tap or draft beer. 
(3)  Twenty-two cents per liter of vinous beverages, and a proportionate amount in like rates on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(Code 1990, § 3-4-1; Code 2005, § 94-111) 
State Law reference— Local excise tax on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-5-80, 3-5-81; tax on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60.  
Sec. 94-104. - Payment. 
The payment of those taxes as set out in this article shall be made as follows: 
(1)  Each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages or wine within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of each month showing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of malt beverages and wine, by size and type of container, constituting a beginning and ending inventory for the month, sold within the city. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the city, on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made, the amount of excise tax due in accordance with this article. 
(2)  No decal, stamp, or other identifying marking shall be required on malt beverages or wine sold within the city. 
(3)  The excise tax provided for in this article shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages or wine at retail or wholesale within the corporate limits of the city. 
(4)  The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount due. 
(5)  A copy of each invoice or record of sale where malt beverages or wine are delivered in the city shall be provided to the city. 
(Code 1990, § 3-4-2; Code 2005, § 94-112)  
Secs. 94-105—94-121. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - MOTEL TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Excise tax on rooms, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.; tourist courts, O.C.G.A. § 31-28-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 94-122. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Due date means the 20th day after the end of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. 
Guestroom means a room occupied, or intended, arranged or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
Monthly period means a calendar month. 
Motel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including any motel, lodginghouse, roominghouse, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, hotel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, bed and breakfast inn, public club or private club containing guestrooms, which is occupied or is intended or designed for occupancy by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. The term "motel" does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention center or other building in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or apartment in a motel, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
Occupant and guest mean any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses or has the right to use or possess any room in a motel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. 
Operator means any person operating a motel in the city, including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises and the lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee, or any other person otherwise operating such motel. 
Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, and includes the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the state and any political subdivision of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax provided in this article. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Return means any return filed or required to be filed as provided in this article. 
Tax means the tax imposed by this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-141; Ord. No. 01197, art. 1, 12-8-1997) 
Cross reference— Definitions, generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50.2.  
Sec. 94-123. - Tax levied. 
There is hereby levied and imposed, and there shall be paid, a tax of three percent of the rent for every occupancy of a guestroom in a motel in the city. 
(Code 2005, § 94-142; Ord. No. 01197, art. 2, 12-8-1997) 
State Law reference— Tax imposed, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51; procedures, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-53.  
Sec. 94-124. - Collection of tax by operator. 
It shall be the duty of every operator of a motel located within the city to collect from the occupants the tax levied and imposed upon the occupancy of guestrooms by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-143; Ord. No. 01197, art. 3, 12-8-1997)  
Sec. 94-125. - Exemptions. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no tax shall be levied as provided in this article upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations: 
(1)  Furnished for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business; or 
(2)  Furnished for a period of more than ten consecutive days or for use as meeting rooms. 
(Code 2005, § 94-144; Ord. No. 01197, art. 4, 12-8-1997) 
State Law reference— Exemption to tax imposed, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51.  
Sec. 94-126. - Registration of operators. 
(a)  Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a motel in the city shall immediately register with the city clerk on a form provided by the clerk. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than 15 days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, but such privilege of registration after the imposition of such tax shall not relieve any person from the obligation of payment or collection of tax on and after the date of imposition thereof. The registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place of business and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the clerk may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person, by a member or partner in case of ownership by an association or partnership, and by an executive officer in the case of ownership by a corporation. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. 
(b)  Should the clerk deem it necessary in order to facilitate registration, he may prescribe administrative provisions therefor other than those provided in this section. Such provisions shall be made to effect the purposes of this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-145; Ord. No. 01197, art. 5, 12-8-1997)  
Sec. 94-127. - Certificate of taxing authority. 
Upon the registration of an operator as provided in section 94-126, the city clerk shall issue to such operator without charge a certificate of authority to collect the tax from the occupants, stating the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. The certificates shall be nonassignable and nontransferable, and shall be returned immediately to the clerk upon the cessation of business by the registered operator at the location named, or upon sale or transfer of the business at that location. 
(Code 2005, § 94-146; Ord. No. 01197, art. 6, 12-8-1997)  
Sec. 94-128. - Due date. 
All taxes levied and imposed by this article shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period in which the taxes are collected. 
(Code 2005, § 94-147; Ord. No. 01197, art. 7, 12-8-1997) 
State Law reference— Tax due date, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-53.2.  
Sec. 94-129. - Returns; remittance of tax. 
On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the clerk in such form as the clerk may prescribe, by every operator liable for the payment of tax under this article. All returns shall show the gross rent, exempt rent, taxable rent, and amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the monthly period for which filed, and such other information as may be required by the clerk, and shall be accompanied when filed by remittance of the net amount of tax due. 
(Code 2005, § 94-148; Ord. No. 01197, art. 8, 12-8-1997)  
Sec. 94-130. - Collection fee allowed operators. 
Operators collecting the tax levied under this article shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and payment of the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50. 
(Code 2005, § 94-149; Ord. No. 01197, art. 9, 12-8-1997) 
State Law reference— Allowable deduction from tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-52.  
Sec. 94-131. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax. If the clerk is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information in his possession or which may come into his possession. One or more than one deficiency determination may be made of the amount due for one or more than one monthly period. 
(b)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the unpaid tax found to be due shall bear interest at the rate of three-fourths of one percent per month from and after the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount should have been returned until the date of payment of such tax and interest. 
(c)  Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination, the clerk may offset overpayments for a period, or periods, against unpaid tax found to be due for another period or periods, against penalties, and against the interest on the unpaid tax. 
(d)  Service of notice of determination. The clerk, or his designated representative, shall give to the operator written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If by mail, the service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the clerk. 
(e)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall last expire. 
(Code 2005, § 94-150; Ord. No. 01197, art. 10, 12-8-1997)  
Sec. 94-132. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any operator fails to make a return, the clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the operator or, as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the periods in respect to which the person failed to make the return, and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the clerk. Upon the basis of this estimate the clerk shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made of the amount due for one or for more than one monthly period. 
(b)  Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination the clerk may offset overpayments for a period, or periods, against unpaid tax found to be due for another period or periods, against penalties, and against interest on unpaid tax found to be due. The interest on such unpaid tax shall be computed in the manner set forth in section 94-131(b). 
(c)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the unpaid tax found to be due shall bear interest at the rate of three-fourths of one percent per month from and after the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount should have been returned until the date of payment of such tax, penalties and interest. 
(d)  Service of notice of determination. Promptly after making his determination, the clerk shall give to the operator written notice of his determination, which notice may be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. 
(Code 2005, § 94-151; Ord. No. 01197, art. 11, 12-8-1997)  
Sec. 94-133. - Collection of unpaid tax; withholding of tax upon sale or transfer of business. 
(a)  Action to collect unpaid tax. When it is determined by a return filed, or by the clerk having made a determination under the provisions of section 94-131 or 94-132, that tax is due and payable to the city under the provisions of this article, the city manager may, at any time within three years after determination that such tax is due and payable, bring an action in the courts of this state, of any other state, or of the United States, in the name of the city to collect the amount of tax payable to the city together with interest thereon and penalties, court costs, attorneys' fees and other legal fees incident thereto. The bringing of such an action shall not be a prerequisite for the issuance of a fi. fa. under the provisions of subsection (d) of this section. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount of tax under this article sells or transfers his business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price of the business to cover the amount of tax, interest thereon and penalties, and pay such sum over to the city, unless the operator liable for the tax delivers to the purchaser or transferee, as the case may be, at the time of the sale or transfer, a certificate from the clerk showing that all tax returns required of such operator have been filed and all taxes shown as being payable on the returns have been paid in full. 
(c)  Liability for failure to withhold tax; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser or transferee of a business fails to withhold the required amount of the purchase price, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall start to run at the time the operator sells or transfers his business, or at the time that the determination against the operator becomes final, whichever event occurs the later. 
(d)  Issuance of fi. fa. The clerk is hereby authorized to issue a fi. fa. for execution and levy to satisfy the amount of any tax, penalty or interest due but not paid under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-152; Ord. No. 01197, art. 12, 12-8-1997) 
State Law reference— Innkeeper selling or quitting businesses, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-53.1.  
Sec. 94-134. - Administration. 
(a)  Authority of clerk. The clerk, under supervision of the city manager, shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this article. 
(b)  Additional rules and regulations. The clerk shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other ordinances of the city, or the laws of the state, or the constitution of this state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the taxes under this article. 
(c)  Records required from operators. Every operator shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the clerk may require. 
(d)  Examination of records; audits. The clerk, or any person authorized in writing by him, may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or, if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount of tax required to be paid. 
(e)  Authority to require reports. In the administration of the provisions of this article, the clerk may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such person's possession or custody information relating to rentals of guestrooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the clerk when required by the clerk and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the dates of occupancy, and such other information as the clerk may require. 
(f)  Limitation on disclosure of business of operators. The clerk or any person having administrative duty under this article shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operations or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures or any particular thereof set forth or disclosed in any return, or permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this article, except in case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax levied and assessed by this article. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees and guarantors, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax, interest and penalties required to be collected. 
(Code 2005, § 94-153; Ord. No. 01197, art. 13, 12-8-1997) 
Cross reference— Administrations, ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Records and books, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-53.4.  
Sec. 94-135. - Designation of agent for receiving notices. 
When registering pursuant to section 94-126, each operator shall appoint, in writing, an agent to receive for the operator any notice required to be given to the operator under the provisions of this article, stating the full name, street address, mailing address and telephone number of the agent. The agent shall be either an individual resident of the city or an employee of the operator who regularly works at the operator's place of business on a daily basis, and the appointment of the agent must be accompanied by the written consent of the agent to serve as agent for the operator. The agent may be changed from time to time by written appointment of and consent of a successor agent. The operator is required to have such an agent at all times, and should an agent cease to be a resident of the city or an employee regularly working at the operator's place of business in the city, as the case may be, the operator shall immediately file a written appointment of a new agent and such agent's consent to serve as such with the clerk. Any agent so appointed by an operator shall be authorized to receive for and on behalf of the operator any notice required to be given to the operator by the provisions of this article. Delivery of any such notice to the agent, in person or by mail, shall be sufficient to meet the requirements of this article and such notice shall be binding on the operator. This method of giving notice to operators is supplementary and cumulative of the other methods of giving notice set forth in this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-154; Ord. No. 01197, art. 14, 12-8-1997)  
Sec. 94-136. - Violations; penalty. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided for in section 1-7. 
(b)  Any operator or other person who fails to register as required in this article, or to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the clerk, or who renders a false or fraudulent return, shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided for in section 1-7. Any person required to make, render, sign or verify any report who makes any false or fraudulent report with intent to defeat or evade the determination of an amount due required by this article to be made shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided for in section 1-7. 
(Code 2005, § 94-155; Ord. No. 01197, art. 15, 12-8-1997)  
Secs. 94-137—94-155. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - STREETLIGHT TAX DISTRICTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
 
Sec. 94-156. - Declaration of policy; purpose. 
The mayor and city council do hereby declare that it shall promote the health, safety, and general public welfare of the citizens of the city to provide for the erection of streetlights in the public rights-of-way in the city. To that end, therefore, the ordinance from which this article is derived is adopted in order to effect the creation of streetlight tax districts and to provide for construction of streetlights in the public rights-of-way in the city. This article shall not be deemed to apply to property in the city other than in the public rights-of-way. 
(Code 2005, § 94-181; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-1), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-157. - Creation of districts; register; assessment of costs. 
(a)  There are created hereby special tax districts which shall be known as streetlight tax districts, which shall be identified by a number assigned by the department of planning. Each such streetlight tax district identified by a streetlight tax district number shall contain and include the tax parcel number of each lot within the tax district. Existing streetlight districts shall become streetlight tax districts upon the enactment of the legislation from which this article is derived, and new streetlight tax districts shall be created upon application or proper petition and approval of the mayor and city council as provided in this article. Each new streetlight tax district so created shall be assigned a number and shall contain the tax parcel numbers of each lot contained therein. 
(b)  A register of streetlight tax districts shall be maintained in the office of the department of planning and the city clerk. Such registers shall be available to the public for inspection upon reasonable notice to either of these offices. 
(c)  The cost of providing and maintaining streetlight services as provided by this article shall be borne by owners of the property receiving that service. The charge therefor shall be such as is determined by resolution of the mayor and city council, giving consideration for the streetlights, electrical service-charges, and the size and number of the lots serviced by the streetlights. In the event of excessive vandalism to streetlights within a district which results in the city being billed for repairs, the city may prorate these repair bills and add a pro-rata share of these bills to the charge. Charges shall be assessed against all lots within the streetlight tax district whether or not the lot is located within the boundaries of a particular subdivision, so long as the lot is located within the boundaries of the streetlight tax district. 
(1)  Residential lots. Residential lots shall be assessed for the annual cost of the streetlights in the following fashion: If all lots in the streetlight tax district are the same size (up to 25 percent variance off average lot size in district), then total cost of streetlight operation for a year as determined by the electrical utility shall be divided equally by the number of lots in the streetlight tax district. If the lots in the proposed district are not similar in size, then the total cost of the streetlight operation for a year shall be divided in two. Half of this figure shall be assessed as provided in the previous sentence. The other half shall be assigned based on total acreage divided by the 50 percent cost, then multiplied by the acreage of the specific lot (for the purposes of this mathematical equation, one acre shall be defined as 44,000 square feet). 
(2)  Commercial lots. Commercial lots shall be assessed by taking the total value of the lots within the proposed streetlight tax district, determining the needed millage rate to pay for the total cost of streetlight operation for a year as determined by the electrical utility, and then multiplying the needed millage rate by the specific lot's value. This calculation shall be required to be done annually unless, from one year to another, there is no increase in value of any of the properties within the proposed streetlight tax district. 
(Code 2005, § 94-182; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-2), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-158. - Collection of charges; administration. 
(a)  The charges for street lighting in each streetlight tax district shall be paid as a streetlight district tax, and shall be collected concurrently with the ad valorem tax billed to each lot or lot resident within each streetlight tax district. 
(b)  The administration of the services provided for in this article and all billing and accounting shall be the responsibility of the city clerk and department of planning. The department of planning shall be responsible for accepting applications for streetlight tax districts, evaluating applications for proper design, and assigning a designation number to each approved streetlight tax district, as well as other possible necessities in this area of administration. The city clerk shall be responsible for all billing and accounting, and other administrative necessities of this nature. 
(c)  The office of the city clerk shall be responsible for the timely collection of the tax assessed to each streetlight tax district, but it shall not be responsible for accounting beyond its internal accounting procedures in order to provide an adequate record of the collection and the transmittal of the funds collected. 
(d)  The mayor and city council shall have the authority to levy reasonable administrative fees for the application process, evaluation, establishment, and operation of each streetlight taxing district. Such a fee shall be a flat charge to each parcel within the designated streetlight tax district. Such a fee shall be set, and adjusted periodically, as determined by the mayor and city council through resolution. 
(Code 2005, § 94-183; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-3), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-159. - Lien for unpaid charges. 
In addition to any other rights of collection for late or unpaid charges, the city shall have the rights available to it under the laws of the state for assessment and the creation of a lien upon the property of the owner receiving the service provided, together with all rights of execution, levy, foreclosure and sale. 
(Code 2005, § 94-184; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-4), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-160. - Deposit required; forfeiture. 
In addition to the other charges authorized in this article, the city shall have the right to require deposits from the lot owners receiving the streetlight service in such amount as shall be determined by the mayor and city council. This deposit shall be held by the city as security for payment of services rendered pursuant to this article, and the city shall have the authority to set off against the deposit for nonpayment for services at such times and on such occasions as shall be determined by the city. Notice of such set-off shall be given to the lot owner by mail at the address of the property serviced by the streetlights, although advance notice of such set-off shall not be required. In the event of a reduction in the deposit of a property owner because of failure to pay charges assessed pursuant to this article, the lot owner shall be required to restore the deposit to its required level upon request by the city. 
(Code 2005, § 94-185; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-5), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-161. - Streetlight construction by developers. 
(a)  All developers of residential subdivisions in the city with lots less than five acres in size and which shall require plat approval by the mayor and city council in accordance with chapter 90, pertaining to subdivisions, and all developers of shopping centers, industrial parks and similar such developments, shall be required, at their own expense, to provide streetlight services in the public rights-of-way in such developments in conformity with this article. 
(b)  Such developers, real estate agents or home/property owners attempting to sell or resell such property which resides within an approved or proposed streetlight tax district must inform prospective buyers of the existence, and the financial burden (or potential burden), of the streetlight tax district prior to closing on the property. 
(c)  Such developers, at the time of the submission of the preliminary plat or drawings of the development, or at the time of application for a building permit, whichever shall first occur, shall present a proposed streetlight layout which details the proposed streetlight service for the development. The proposal presented by the developer must be evaluated and approved by the department of planning, city manager or other designated city official prior to obtaining any building permit for that development. The proposal must comply with the following standards: 
(1)  All fixtures and standards/poles installed or to be used shall be approved not only by the city, but also by the utility company which will provide electricity to the streetlights and which will be responsible for the maintenance of the facilities. 
(2)  Each corner or entrance (not to include the driveways of single-family residential districts) shall have two fixtures installed, one on each side of the corner or entrance. The fixtures at these locations may be less powerful than others in the district due to their relatively close proximity; however, they must still provide minimum footcandle requirements. 
(3)  All fixtures shall meet Illumination Engineering Society (IES) standards. Each fixture shall be identified and the manufacturer's stated illuminative capacity detailed in the plan. Based upon these standards, the fixtures shall be properly distributed to attain minimum illumination standards as established by the American National Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting of the IES. The space between each displayed fixture must be measured and depicted in feet. 
(d)  Should the department of planning disapprove the streetlight layout, the grounds for disapproval shall be communicated in writing to the developer. Any such disapproval by the department of planning may be appealed to the mayor and city council by filing a request for review with the city manager within 30 days from the date of the written notice of disapproval. The department of planning shall, at that point, transmit to the mayor and city council all papers and related documents pertaining to the action taken by the department of planning, and the mayor and city council shall review the matter at the next regularly scheduled public meeting. The mayor and city council may reverse or affirm, entirely or in part, the decision of the department of planning. If the streetlight tax district is approved without trouble or with requested corrections, this approval shall be conveyed to the developer by the department of planning, city manager or other city official in writing and delivered by regular means. 
(e)  At the time of submission of the final plat for the subdivisions, shopping centers, industrial parks, office parks or other such development on which streetlights have been constructed at the expense of the developer in the city right-of-way, the developer shall pay to the city in advance a sum equal to the customary streetlight rates charged by the electrical utility for similar developments for a period of one year, or the developer may have the electrical utility direct bill him for all associated costs to install and operate the proposed streetlights for one year, such one-year period starting upon the complete installation of the streetlights within the designated district. Completion is to be ascertained by the department of planning and the electrical utility. 
(f)  The department of planning shall not issue any certificates of occupancy until such time as all the provisions of this section have been satisfied, and until the developers further submit to the department of planning proof of payment for construction and installation of the streetlights in the areas sought to be dedicated, together with a copy of an executed agreement with the appropriate utility company for complete maintenance of all streetlights and related structures, wires and installations. 
(g)  Upon the recommendation of the department of planning, city manager or other designated city official, the mayor and city council shall approve or deny the final plat by resolution at a regularly scheduled mayor and city council meeting not later than 30 days following the submission of the recommendation of the review staff. The streetlight tax district is created upon the approval by the mayor and city council of the final plat. The date of creation for the streetlight tax district shall be the date of the approval of the final plat. 
(h)  Notwithstanding all other provisions of the subdivision laws, rules and regulations of planning and zoning of the city and other ordinances, any developer, contractor or other person securing approval in accordance with this section may be required to post a bond equal to the installation cost and one year's electrical power for the street lighting. This bond, if required, must be given at the time of written approval of the design as specified in subsection (c) of this section.
