The bond shall be payable to the city and will provide that it shall remain in full force and effect until such time as the city or its designated representative shall have indicated that the work required for the construction and installation of the street lighting in a subdivision or other multifamily residential, commercial or industrial development has been satisfactorily completed. 
(Code 2005, § 94-186; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-6), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-162. - Creation of district upon petition of property owner. 
(a)  Any lot owner in any area of the city may present a request for the creation of a streetlight tax district to the department of planning, city manager or other designated city official. Upon receipt of the request, the department of planning, city manager or other designated city official shall determine the appropriate boundaries for a streetlight tax district which will serve the lot owner presenting the request and neighboring lot owners. The lot owner presenting the request shall then prepare a plat, or an adequate depiction of the proposed district, such as that which is shown on the city tax maps (if all lots within the proposed residential district are the same size), showing this proposed street lighting district, and a petition for the creation of the proposed lighting district shall then be circulated among the lot owners in the proposed district, by the lot owner presenting the request. If 60 percent of the lot owners in the proposed district sign the petition for the creation of a streetlight tax district, or if those signing the petition compose 60 percent of the total assessed tax value within the designated streetlight tax district, the petition shall be presented to the mayor and city council. The mayor and city council shall conduct a public hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not to create the proposed streetlight tax district, giving consideration to safety and economic factors in making such determination. Unless 100 percent of the lot owners have signed the petition, the public hearing shall be advertised one time in the official organ of the city, and signs shall be posted in the proposed streetlight tax district giving notice of the hearing at least 15 but no more than 45 days before the public hearing. The number and size of the signs shall be such as is required by chapter 106, pertaining to zoning, for a request to rezone property. 
(b)  The petition for creation of the proposed streetlight tax district must be returned to the department of planning, city manager or other designated city official within 90 days after it is obtained from such city official's office. The department of planning, city manager or city clerk, at their sole discretion, will verify the signatures on the petition prior to advertising the public hearing. 
(c)  All other provisions of this article with respect to payment for street lighting, including provisions for required deposits, shall apply equally to the services created and provided. 
(Code 2005, § 94-187; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-7), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-163. - Creation of districts upon recommendation of department of planning. 
Streetlight tax districts in any areas in the city other than as provided in section 98-162 shall be authorized upon recommendation by the department of planning, approval by the mayor and city council, and compliance with the rules and regulations established by this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-188; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-8), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-164. - Creation of districts under special conditions. 
In areas where special conditions as to safety, land topography, or economic and other factors may be involved, the mayor and city council may create special streetlight tax districts and provide for special street lighting under such terms and conditions as may be determined by the mayor and city council, any other provisions of this article to the contrary notwithstanding; provided, however, that in such instances a public hearing shall be held by the mayor and city council after advertisement in the official organ of the city one time at least 15 but no more than 45 days before conducting such public hearing. 
(Code 2005, § 94-189; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-9), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-165. - Authority to contract with public utilities. 
The mayor and city council may contract with public utilities for the purpose of carrying out the terms of this article. 
(Code 2005, § 94-190; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-10), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-166. - Restrictions on other lighting fixtures in or near public right-of-way. 
The approval of the department of planning, city manager or other designated city official shall be necessary before any person shall be authorized to install a security light or other such lighting fixture within the public right-of-way. All lighting fixtures within or near the public right-of-way shall be installed and operated in such a manner so as to prevent interference with the normal use of the public right-of-way in any manner, including glare, location of blinds, and other such means of potential interference. 
(Code 2005, § 94-191; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-11), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-167. - Minimum illumination standards. 
The department of planning, in conjunction with the appropriate local utility companies, and in consideration of the American National Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting of the Illumination Engineering Society, as approved by the American National Standards Institute (1973), as amended, shall seek to ensure adequate illumination of the public rights-of-way, and to that end shall be authorized to require lighting fixtures to be installed which comply with certain minimum footcandle illumination standards. 
(Code 2005, § 94-192; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-12), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-168. - Granting of exceptions. 
The mayor and city council may grant exceptions to the literal terms of this article where special conditions or hardships exist. 
(Code 2005, § 94-193; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-13), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-169. - Conflicts with state or federal regulations. 
If any provision of this article is in conflict with any state or federal law, or with any rule, regulation or order of any agency of this state or federal agency having jurisdiction of the subject matter of this article, it is hereby deemed to be the intention of the mayor and city council that the remaining portion of this article shall be deemed to be of full force and effect. 
(Code 2005, § 94-194; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-14), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-170. - Public availability of provisions. 
A copy of this article shall be spread upon the official minutes of the city. 
(Code 2005, § 94-195; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-15), 1-13-2003)  
Sec. 94-171. - Rate schedule. 
The mayor and city council are authorized to adopt a rate schedule pursuant to this article, which schedule may be amended or modified upon properly adopted resolution of the mayor and city council. 
(Code 2005, § 94-196; Ord. No. 01233, § 1(3-5-16), 1-13-2003)  
Secs. 94-172—94-197. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - ENERGY EXCISE TAX 
 
Sec. 94-198. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "City of Tallapoosa Energy Excise Tax Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-198), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-199. - Findings and intent. 
The ordinance from which this article is derived is being adopted to address the interest of public finance. State law authorizes counties, or municipalities under certain circumstances, to impose an excise tax on the sale or use of energy, not otherwise exempt per the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. The imposition of the excise tax on the sale or use of energy county wide is contingent upon the enactment of an ordinance by the governing authority of the county. After a properly called meeting between the county and its respective municipalities, the county has elected not to participate in an intergovernmental agreement with its municipalities and has decided not to call for passage of an ordinance to impose and levy an excise tax on sale and use of energy within the county. When a county determines that it will not participate in the imposition of the excise tax on energy, one or more municipalities within the non-participating county may elect to pass an ordinance for the imposition, levy and collection of an excise tax on the sale and use of energy within its municipal boundaries, in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-8-115. In order for the city to properly impose such excise tax within its municipal boundaries, the city must follow all of the applicable provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 13, art. 6, one provision of which is the enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-199), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-200. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dealer shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
Energy shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
Local sale and use tax shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
Purchaser shall have the same meaning as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-200), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-201. - Energy excise tax imposed. 
(a)  In accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 13, art. 6, and specifically the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115, after the holding of a properly called meeting between the respective governing bodies of the county and its respective municipalities at which the county declined to participate in a county-wide ordinance for the imposition of an excise tax on the sale or use of energy, there is hereby imposed within the city an excise tax on the sale or use of energy which sale or use would otherwise constitute a taxable event for the purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8, art. 1 but for the exemptions found in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(b)  The sale or use of energy when such sale or use would have constituted a taxable event for the purposes of sales and use under O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8, art. 1 but for the exemptions found in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2, includes, but is not limited to, the sales and use of energy that is necessary and integral to the manufacture of tangible personal property, such as: 
(1)  Machinery or equipment used to convey or transport industrial materials, work in process, consumable supplies, or packaging materials at or among manufacturing plants or to convey and transport finished goods to a distribution or storage point at the manufacturing plant. Specific examples may include, but are not limited to, forklifts, conveyors, cranes, hoists, and pallet jacks; 
(2)  Machinery or equipment used to gather, arrange, sort, mix, measure, blend, heat, cool, clean, or otherwise treat, prepare, or store industrial materials for further manufacturing; 
(3)  Machinery or equipment used to control, regulate, heat, cool, or produce energy for other manufacture of tangible personal property. Specific examples may include, but are not limited to, boilers, chillers, condensers, water towers, dehumidifiers, humidifiers, heat exchangers, generators, transformers, motor control centers, solar panels, air dryers, and air compressors; 
(4)  Testing and quality control machinery or equipment located at a manufacturing plant used to test the quality of industrial materials, work in process, or finished goods; 
(5)  Starters, switches, circuit breakers, transformers, wiring, piping, and other electrical components, including associated cable trays, conduit, and insulation, located between a motor control center and exempt machinery or equipment or between separate units of exempt machinery or equipment; 
(6)  Machinery or equipment used to maintain, clean, or repair exempt machinery or equipment; 
(7)  Machinery or equipment used to condition air or water to produce conditions necessary for the manufacture of tangible personal property, including pollution control machinery or equipment and water treatment systems; 
(8)  Pollution control, sanitizing, sterilizing, or recycling machinery or equipment; 
(9)  Industrial material bought for further processing in the manufacture of tangible personal property for sale or further processing or any part of the industrial material or byproduct thereof which becomes a wasteful product contributing to pollution problems and which is used up in a recycling or burning process; 
(10)  Machinery or equipment used in quarrying and mining activities, including blasting, extraction, and crushing; and 
(11)  Energy used at a manufacturing plant. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-201), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-202. - Energy excise tax rate and phase-in. 
(a)  The rate of the excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall be phased in over a four-year period as directed by O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-112(a)(3) and 48-8-112(b) and as set forth below: 
(1)  For the period commencing January 1, 2013, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2013, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 25 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(2)  For the period commencing January 1, 2014, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2014, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 50 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(3)  For the period commencing January 1, 2015, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2015, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 75 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; and 
(4)  For the period commencing January 1, 2016, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2016, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 100 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(b)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2(c)(4), if a project of regional significance under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3(92) is started in the special district, it shall not be subject to the phase-in period contained in subsections (a)(1) through (3) of this section, and the sale, use, storage or consumption of energy in connection therewith shall be subject to the rate specified in subsection (a)(4) of this section notwithstanding the January 1, 2016, limitation in subsection (a)(4) of this section. 
(c)  Following such initial imposition during the phase-in time period, on or after January 1, 2016, the rate of the excise tax levied and collected by the governing authority of the county shall be directed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(d). Such rate shall be controlled by the maximum amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the special district, but in no event more than two percent. 
(d)  In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the city limits decreases from two percent to one percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be reduced at the same time such local sales and use tax rate reduction becomes effective. 
(e)  In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the city limits increases from one percent to two percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be increased at the same time such local sales and use tax rate increase becomes effective. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-202), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-203. - Energy excise tax imposition, remittance and recovery. 
(a)  The excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall be imposed at the time and be recoverable as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). 
(b)  The excise tax shall be a debt of the purchaser of energy until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). 
(c)  The dealer collecting the excise tax shall remit the excise tax to the city as the governing authority imposing the excise tax as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). 
(d)  Every dealer subject to an excise tax under this article shall be liable for the excise tax at an applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of the excise taxes collected from the purchasers, whichever is greater, as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-203), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-204. - Exemption certificates. 
(a)  The governing authority of the city, or the collecting officer appointed under this article, shall make diligent efforts to identify all energy providers and purchasers in the city and to ascertain whether such purchasers have completed a uniform exemption certificate provided by the state department of revenue seeking to qualify such purchaser under the exemption found in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. Such certificate shall be utilized by such governing authority or collecting officer for the purpose of determining the applicability of the excise tax under this article. 
(b)  An energy provider shall be authorized to rely upon such uniform exemption certificates provided by the state department of revenue. The energy provider shall not be liable for failing to collect and remit the excise tax imposed under this article if a purchaser has failed to submit the uniform exemption certificate provided by the state department of revenue to such energy provider. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-204), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-205. - Commencement of collections and due date. 
(a)  The excise tax imposed pursuant to this article shall become effective on January 1, 2013. 
(b)  The excise tax levied pursuant to this article shall be imposed only at the time that sales and use tax on the sale and use of such energy would have been due and payable under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(c)  The excise tax shall be due and payable in the same manner as would otherwise be required under O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8, art. 1. 
(d)  All sales and purchases taxable under this article during the proceeding calendar month shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the 20th day of every month and each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross sales and purchases arising from all sales and purchases taxable under this article during the preceding calendar month. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-205), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-206. - Expenditure of proceeds. 
The proceeds of the excise tax levied and collected pursuant to this article shall not be subject to any use or expenditure requirements provided for under any of the local sales and use taxes but shall be authorized to be expended in the same manner as otherwise would have been required under such local sales and use taxes or may be expended for any lawful purpose as governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c). Any proceeds received by the city pursuant to this article shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-206), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-207. - Termination in the event the county elects to impose county excise tax. 
(a)  If a city within the special district has levied and collected an excise tax within their corporate limits under this article because the county in which the city is located has refused or failed to enter into an intergovernmental agreement with each municipality wishing to participate in such excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(a)(1) and then the county determines to commence proceedings for the imposition of the excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-134-115(b)(2), then the excise tax levied and collected by the city shall cease to the extent as provided for by O.C.G.A. § 48-134-115(b)(2). 
(b)  If the county has commenced proceedings for the imposition of the excise tax as allowed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-115(b)(2) and the excise tax levied and collected by the municipality has terminated and the municipality has chosen to participate in the county excise tax and an intergovernmental agreement to that effect has been entered into between the county and the city, then this article shall remain effective for the purposes of O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 3, art. 6 and particularly for the rates required by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-207), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-208. - Administrative provisions and audit. 
(a)  The mayor and city council shall be authorized to designate a collecting officer for collection and administration of the excise tax under this article. 
(b)  The collecting officer shall be authorized to provide for procedures necessary to the proper implementation of this article, including, but not limited to, periodic auditing of dealers collecting and remitting the excise tax. 
(c)  The collecting officer, or designee, may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of and locations within the county of any purchaser which is required to remit the excise tax to the energy dealer under this article. 
(d)  As part by the audit report required by O.C.G.A. § 36-81-7, the auditor shall include, in a separate schedule, a report of the revenues pertaining to the excise tax under this article. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-208), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-209. - Conflicts with existing regulations. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-209), 12-10-2012)  
Sec. 94-210. - Severability. 
If any section, clause, sentence or phrase of this article is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then said holding shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining portions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 01278, exh. 2012-B(94-210), 12-10-2012)  
Chapter 98 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance providing traffic or parking regulations for specific locations saved from repeal, § 1-11(13); wrecker and towing services, § 22-51 et seq.; taxicabs, § 22-88 et seq.; vehicles in cemeteries, § 26-9; courts, ch. 34; accumulations of junk vehicles and vehicle parts, § 42-51; law enforcement, ch. 58; offenses, ch. 62; vehicles with wheels damaging to pavement prohibited on paved streets, § 62-8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; streetlight tax district, § 94-156 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 98-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-395 (except for O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-245, 40-6-393 and 40-6-394) of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this city with like effect as if recited in this section. 
(b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished as provided by section 1-7. 
(Code 1990, § 10-1-1; Code 2005, § 98-1) 
State Law reference— Adoption of uniform rules, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370 et seq.  
Sec. 98-2. - Traffic zones and traffic control devices. 
(a)  The police chief or a designee thereof, upon approval by ordinance of the mayor and city council, is authorized to designate and maintain with appropriate traffic control signs, markings and devices after engineering and traffic investigations: 
(1)  Speed zones; 
(2)  Truck routes and streets to be designated specifically to prohibit various classes of trucks; 
(3)  One-way streets and other directional control devices; 
(4)  Freight loading zones and regulations; 
(5)  Parking and no parking zones and regulations thereon; 
(6)  Stop, yield and other right-of-way signs; and 
(7)  Stop signals and other traffic signals. 
(8)  Dynamic braking devices prohibited zone. Dynamic braking devices means a motor vehicle brake which is activated or worked by the compression of the engine of a motor vehicle. 
(b)  The police chief or a designee thereof is authorized to issue written orders designating by appropriate traffic control signs, markings and devices after engineering and traffic investigations: 
(1)  Pedestrian crosswalks; 
(2)  Other safety zones for pedestrians; 
(3)  Traffic lanes; and 
(4)  Any other sign, marking or zone necessary for orderly and safe conditions on the streets of the city. 
(c)  The police chief shall maintain or cause to be recorded a current schedule of all traffic rules, regulations and orders under this section, which record shall be available for inspection by the public. For items listed in subsection (a) of this section, this schedule, and any amendments thereto, shall become effective only upon approval thereof by ordinance of the mayor and city council. This schedule is hereby incorporated in this section, and copies thereof shall be available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
(d)  All traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings shall conform to specifications in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices adopted by the state transportation board. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic control devices of the city. 
(e)  Any violation of any traffic zone, marking, sign or other traffic control device established under this section shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 10-1-2; Code 2005, § 98-2; Ord. No. 01265, exh. 2008-F(98-2), 8-11-2008) 
State Law reference— Authority to alter speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183; authority to set speed limit, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371.  
Sec. 98-3. - Riding bicycles, skateboards, motorcycles or four-wheelers on street or sidewalk. 
No person shall ride any bicycle, skateboard, motorcycle, four-wheeler or other such device on any public street or sidewalk within the corporate limits of the city except as provided by law. 
(Code 1990, § 10-1-3; Code 2005, § 98-3) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86.  
Sec. 98-4. - Speed detection devices. 
The city police department is hereby authorized to utilize speed detection devices within its lawful jurisdiction in a manner consistent with the laws and regulations of the state. 
(Code 2005, § 98-4; Res. No. 05493, 3-8-2004)  
Sec. 98-5. - Through truck traffic mandatory truck route regulations. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Designated truck route means specific streets authorized for truck/trailer traffic within the corporate limits of the city. Those streets or roads are designated as US 78, GA 100 (except that portion north of the intersection of GA 100 and GA 100 Truck Spur to the intersection of US 78 and GA 100 across from either Head Avenue or Alewine Avenue), including the GA 100 Truck Spur, and GA 120. 
Truck/trailers means a motorized vehicle having ten wheels or more and/or tandem axles which generally has attached thereto a trailer for the purposes of hauling. 
(b)  Prohibited truck trailer travel; exceptions. Through truck trailers not stopping for pick-up or deliveries in the city are prohibited from traveling along any streets within the city limits, except along the designated routes as set forth in this chapter. Truck/trailer deliveries or pick-ups within the corporate boundaries of the city are permitted. 
(c)  Designated through truck route, east and west, mandatory route. 
(1)  US 78, from city limit to city limit. 
(2)  GA 120, from mile marker 0.0, east, to the city limits. 
(d)  Designated through truck route, north and south, mandatory route. 
(1)  North starting point: GA 100, beginning at the intersection with the northerly city limit, continuing south until GA 100 intersects with US 78 (these streets are known locally as Bowdon Street and Robertson Avenue). Upon intersecting with US 78, the designated through truck route for north and south bound through truck traffic must remain on US 78 until US 78 intersects with the northern terminus of the GA 100 Truck Spur. The north/south through truck route then proceeds south along the GA 100 Truck Spur. Upon arriving at the southern terminus of the GA 100 Truck Spur at GA 100, all through truck traffic must turn left, south, such that the progress of the truck is in a southerly direction, towards I-20. From this point, the through truck traffic route continues south until the southerly city limits is arrived upon. 
(2)  South starting point: GA 100, beginning at the intersection of the southerly city limit, or the exit ramps of 1-20, continuing north along GA 100 under I-20 until GA 100 intersects with the southern terminus of the GA 100 Truck Spur, all through trucks must turn right at this intersection, and follow the GA 100 Truck Spur for its complete route until arriving at the northern terminus of the GA 100 Truck Spur at US 78. Upon intersection with US 78, the designated through truck route, all through truck traffic must remain on US 78 until US 78 intersects with GA 100 going north, at this intersection GA 100 is also known locally as Robertson Avenue. From this intersection, in a northerly direction, GA 100 travels north along Robertson Avenue to a signalized intersection with Taliaferro Street. At this intersection, GA 100 turns approximately 45 degrees west, and becomes locally known as Bowdon Street. Bowdon Street/GA 100 continues in a generally northerly direction until passing out of the city limits near Sheryl Ann Bridges Road, where the city designated through truck traffic route ends. 
Designated Through Truck Route Map 
 
(e)  All laws and parts of law in conflict herewith are specifically repealed. In the event that any portion of this section is found to be invalid or otherwise unenforceable, this shall not affect all other portions hereof. 
(f)  Violation and penalty. Any person firm or corporation violating any of the provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable pursuant to the provisions of section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 01260, exh. 2008-A, 1-14-2008)  
Sec. 98-6. - Un-muffled dynamic braking devices prohibited zone. 
Due to the heavy truck traffic that operates within the city limits, and the frequency with which those trucks utilize dynamic braking devices, to decelerate, and the tremendous noise generated by the use of said dynamic braking systems, improperly muffled, the mayor and council of the city hereby authorize the city chief of police to determine the location and routes of truck use throughout the city which course through predominantly residential areas of the city and, upon determining that route, to declare the use of un-muffled dynamic braking systems in those predominantly residential areas prohibited. Additionally, upon the creation and publication of a map depicting this un-muffled dynamic braking system prohibition zone/route, to cause to be erected at the start and termination, and at appropriate points in between, signage, informing truckers of the un-muffled dynamic braking devices prohibited zone/route. Such signs shall indicate the start and end of such prohibited zone/route. Such a route shall be along portions of the truck routes where residential structures abut, and which are being affected by the noise such use of un-muffled dynamic braking systems generates. 
(Ord. No. 01265, exh. 2008-F(98-6), 8-11-2008)  
Secs. 98-7—98-30. - Reserved.

Sec. 98-32. - Speed limit within housing authority properties. 
The posted speed limit within the city housing authority properties, specifically Alda Place, Dogwood Circle, Dogwood Court, H.B. Johnson Circle, J. Hugh Street, Liner Street, and Windom Street, shall be 20 miles per hour. 
(Code 2005, § 98-32; Ord. No. 01229, § 1, 6-10-2002)  
Secs. 98-33—98-52. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 98-53. - Adoption of state law regarding stopping, standing and parking. 
The city hereby adopts O.C.G.A. tit. 40, ch. 6, art. 10, pt. 1 (O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.), Stopping, Standing and Parking, by reference, as if completely stated in this section. 
(Code 2005, § 98-61) 
State Law reference— Uniform rules of the road, local authority, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371.  
Sec. 98-54. - Adoption of state law regarding parking for persons with disabilities. 
The city hereby adopts O.C.G.A. tit. 40, ch. 6, art. 10, pt. 2 (O.C.G.A. § 40-6-220 et seq.), Parking for Persons with Disabilities, by reference, as if completely stated in this section. 
(Code 2005, § 98-62) 
State Law reference— Uniform rules of the road, local authority, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371.  
Sec. 98-55. - Parking in fire zone. 
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to park or stand in a properly marked fire zone. For the purpose of this section, the term "properly marked fire zone" means one which abuts the facade of any business and is marked by horizontal slash marks. Fire apparatus, police vehicles, and emergency medical vehicles are excluded from the provisions of this section during an actual emergency. 
(Code 2005, § 98-63) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 46.  
Sec. 98-56. - Vehicles to be parked within marked spaces. 
Whenever a space is marked off on any street for the parking of an individual vehicle, every vehicle there parked shall be parked within the lines bounding that space. 
(Code 2005, § 98-64; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-1), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 98-57. - Parking prohibited at all times in certain locations. 
It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle or other vehicle to park the vehicle in any of the places on the streets or alleys of the city specifically designated by posted signs indicating the prohibited parking. 
(Code 2005, § 98-65; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-2), 3-10-2003) 
State Law reference— Parking in designated spaces, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-203.  
Sec. 98-58. - Parking on left side of street. 
To prevent motorists from driving on the wrong side of the road, against the flow of traffic, and to prevent vehicles from crossing the traffic lane of oncoming traffic to park and unpark, it is hereby declared unlawful for any person to park his vehicle on the left-hand side of any street or highway. Any vehicle parked in this position shall be deemed to have violated this section. 
(Code 2005, § 98-66; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-2A), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 98-59. - Parking prohibited in certain locations during certain hours. 
It is unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle or other vehicle to park his vehicle in any of the places on the days and between the hours indicated and specified by posted signs indicating the prohibited parking. 
(Code 2005, § 98-67; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-3), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 98-60. - Overnight parking. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator or owner of a vehicle to leave such vehicle parked in a public street for a continuous period of more than 24 hours. 
(Code 2005, § 98-68; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-4), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 98-61. - Parking districts. 
There are hereby declared parking districts, with distinct parking restrictions for specific districts. The districts shall be depicted upon a parking district map created by the department of planning and duly approved by the mayor and city council, which shall be updated and amended from time to time through resolution of the mayor and city council. The parking districts shall take effect upon approval of the map and the proper demarcation through street sign erection within the designated parking district. 
(1)  District 1 (blue zone on map). Parking is restricted to two hours or less. No overnight parking is permitted. Any vehicle being parked in this district zone between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(2)  District 2 (green zone on map). Parking is restricted to ten-hour parking (employee parking), between the hours of 5:00 a.m. and 3:00 a.m. No overnight parking is permitted. Any vehicle found parked in this district zone between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(3)  District 3 (purple zone on map). Parking hours are unrestricted. No overnight parking is permitted. Any vehicle found parked in this district zone between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(4)  District 4 (brown zone on map). Use of parking is restricted. Due to the nature of the design of the parking spaces, only cars 20 feet or less in length are permitted to park in this zone. Any vehicle which is parked and any portion of which vehicle extends past the painted line of the marked parking space, out into the travelway of the road, shall be deemed guilty of violating this section in addition to causing an obstruction of a public street without a permit. Parking is restricted to two hours or less. No overnight parking is permitted. Any vehicle being parked in this district zone between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. shall be deemed in violation of this section. 
(5)  District 5 (yellow zone on map). Parking is prohibited. Parking at all intersections, within a minimum of ten feet from the intersection, as measured from the intersection of right-of-way lines, or longer distances as required by site distance/topographical impacts at specific intersections, which shall be determined by the department of planning and police (such distance shall be annotated upon the official map), shall be prohibited. 
(6)  District 6 (red zone on map). Parking is prohibited at all times; this is a fire zone. No parking shall be permitted within 15 feet on either side of a fire hydrant and in other designated locations within the city as determined by the fire department and the department of planning. 
(Code 2005, § 98-69; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-4A), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 98-62. - Parking in areas not in parking district. 
All areas of the city not specifically addressed on the city parking district map, as approved by the mayor and city council and amended/updated from time to time by resolution, shall have parking on public streets controlled by the remaining portions of this article. 
(Code 2005, § 98-70; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-4B), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 98-63. - Permanent resident parking permit. 
(a)  In the historic downtown central business district, or commercial-historic zoning district, where upstairs loft apartments are desired and possible, a permanent resident parking permit is hereby authorized. Such permit shall have an annual fee of $25.00 per year, expiring each December 31, and is required to be renewed prior to February 1 of the following year. Failure to renew the permit within this time period shall require a renewal fee of $25.00, in addition to the regular permit fee, if the permit is renewed during the immediate proceeding calendar year. The permit fee shall be prorated during the first year if the permit is applied for after August 1. The prorated fee shall be $12.00, no less. The mayor and city council may amend the fee amount from time to time as they see fit through a duly considered and passed resolution. 
(b)  The permanent resident parking permit shall be issued to a single person or pair of people and to one single automobile. Residents with multiple vehicles must purchase one permit per vehicle. The permit shall exempt the permit holder's vehicle from sections 98-60 and 98-61(2). Through this exemption, overnight parking in District 2 parking zones of the city is allowed. Additionally, extended parking over 24 hours which is essentially unlimited is permitted with the acquisition of this permit in District 2, provided that the vehicle so permitted is perpetually licensed, registered, insured and in an operable condition. 
(c)  Permanent resident parking permits for visitors shall also be available for an annual fee of $10.00, up to two per residence. This permit can be purchased at any time, but it too expires each December 31, and the fee shall not be prorated. The individual who purchases this permit must contact the police department and identify the vehicle that the resident has provided the visitor permit to. Included in this information shall be make, model, color, license plate and arrival and departure date of this vehicle. Permits provided to visitors shall be given for no more than ten consecutive days and for no more than two weeks during any given calendar month. Such permits are available from the department of planning, which shall provide an application form for such permit and maintain adequate records concerning what permits were issued, which shall be transmitted to the police department on a monthly or as-needed basis. 
(Code 2005, § 98-71; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-4C), 3-10-2003)  
Sec. 98-64. - Parking of vehicles without current license plates. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator or owner of a vehicle to leave such vehicle parked in a public street without the vehicle having affixed, or prominently displayed thereon, a current state license plate. 
(Code 2005, § 98-72; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-5), 3-10-2003) 
State Law reference— Display of current license plates, O.C.G.A. § 40-2-41.  
Secs. 98-65—98-86. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 98-87. - Authorized. 
(a)  Whenever a police officer or other officer acting under authority or direction of the city shall find any vehicle parked on any street or other place in violation of the ordinances of the city, or abandoned on any street or other public place, and such officer is unable to find the owner, operator, or other person responsible for the vehicle in the immediate vicinity after making a reasonable search and investigation, he shall take possession of such vehicle and tow it to a place of storage and keep it in possession of the city until claimed by the person entitled to its possession if claimed within the time fixed in this division; provided, however, that the person claiming the vehicle shall pay all lawful costs as fixed in this division. If deemed necessary by such officer, he shall call upon a garage operator or other person equipped for towing and storing such vehicles to remove the vehicle and store it. 
(b)  Whenever any officer shall find upon any street, or at any other place within the city, any vehicle broken down, wrecked, disabled, stalled, or in any condition or situation as to render the vehicle likely to endanger life, limb or property, and the owner, operator or person in charge is unable or unwilling to take the proper steps or unreasonably neglects to take the proper steps to remove the danger or to make the necessary correction with reasonable promptness, the officer shall cause the vehicle to be removed, impounded and kept in the manner specified in subsection (a) of this section, to be released upon compliance with the requirements of section 98-89 as to payment of costs and expenses. 
(c)  In all cases where the operator of a vehicle is found upon the public streets or public places of the city, ill, injured, intoxicated, or for any reason in a condition rendering him unfit to operate the vehicle, and no other able person is available to remove the vehicle, the officer may tow away and store such vehicle in the manner provided in this section, until released by compliance with the requirements of section 98-89. 
(Code 2005, § 98-101; Ord. No. 01235, § 1(10-2-6), 3-10-2003) 
State Law reference— Abandoned Motor Vehicles Act, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.  
Sec. 98-88. - When police officers may remove vehicles; notification of owner. 
(a)  Removal of unattended vehicle after five days. Any peace officer who finds a motor vehicle which has been left unattended on a public street, road, or highway or other public property for a period of at least five days shall be authorized to cause such motor vehicle to be removed to a garage or other place of safety, if such peace officer reasonably believes that the person who left such motor vehicle unattended does not intend to return and remove such motor vehicle. 
(b)  Immediate removal if threat to public safety. Any peace officer who finds a motor vehicle which has been left unattended on a public street, road, or highway or other public property, other than the state highway system, shall be authorized immediately to cause such motor vehicle to be removed immediately to a garage or other place of safety when such motor vehicle poses a threat to public health or safety or to mitigate congestion. 
(c)  Officer liability limited. Any peace officer who, under this section, causes any motor vehicle to be removed to a garage or other place of safety shall be liable for gross negligence only. 
(d)  Notice to storage garage and authority for lien. 
(1)  Any peace officer or the law enforcement agency which causes a motor vehicle to be removed to a garage or other place of safety or which is notified of the removal of a motor vehicle from private property shall, within 72 hours from the time of removal or notice and, if the owner is unknown, attempt to determine vehicle ownership through official inquiries to the state department of motor vehicle safety vehicle registration and vehicle title files. These inquiries shall be made from authorized criminal justice information system network terminals. 
(2)  If the name and address of the last-known registered owner of the motor vehicle is obtained from the state crime information center, the peace officer who causes the motor vehicle to be removed shall, within three calendar days, make available to the person removing such motor vehicle the name and address of the last-known registered owner of such motor vehicle, the owner of the motor vehicle as recorded on the title of such vehicle, and all security interest holders or lienholders. If such information is not available, the peace officer shall, within three calendar days, notify the person removing or storing such vehicle of such fact. 
(3)  Law enforcement agencies shall make record entries in state criminal justice information system files through authorized criminal justice information system network terminals after an unsuccessful attempt to obtain vehicle ownership information and shall remove the record entries when ownership is determined. 
(Code 2005, § 98-102) 
State Law reference— When peace officer may remove vehicles from public property, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-14.  
Sec. 98-89. - Redemption of impounded vehicle. 
The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle impounded pursuant to this division may redeem the vehicle at any time within 30 days of the date of impoundment by paying the actual costs of impounding, towing and storing the vehicle, plus any penalty that may be assessed for violation of this chapter or other city ordinance. 
(Code 1990, § 10-2-7; Code 2005, § 98-103) 
State Law reference— Lien on impounded vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-19.  
Sec. 98-90. - Sale of unredeemed vehicles. 
If the owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle impounded under this division fails to redeem the vehicle as provided in section 98-89, the city may sell the vehicle after advertising the sale in the official city newspaper once. The sale shall be for cash, provided that sales of vehicles impounded as abandoned vehicles shall be made in accordance with O.C.G.A. tit. 40, ch. 11, art. 1 (O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1990, § 10-2-8; Code 2005, § 98-104)  
Secs. 98-91—98-108. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 
 
Sec. 98-109. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in, conduct or accompany any organized parade or procession, other than a funeral procession, on the public streets, sidewalks or other public property in the city unless an application has been previously filed and a permit granted to conduct such parade or procession within the city. 
(Code 1990, § 10-1-4; Code 2005, § 98-131) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(3).  
Sec. 98-110. - Application for permit. 
An application for permit to conduct or sponsor a parade or procession shall be filed with the chief of police in writing and shall contain the following information furnished by the person in official charge of the proposed parade or procession: 
(1)  The name of all organizations or persons organizing or sponsoring the parade or procession; 
(2)  The purpose of the parade or procession; 
(3)  The date and hours of the parade or procession; 
(4)  The proposed route of the parade or procession, and its beginning and termination points; 
(5)  The number and types of vehicles, marching units and floats to be used in the parade or procession; 
(6)  The number of persons participating in the parade or procession; and 
(7)  The name of the person to be responsible for cleanup of the parade area as prescribed in section 98-112. 
(Code 1990, § 10-1-5; Code 2005, § 98-132)  
Sec. 98-111. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  Upon proper registration with the chief of police, and provided the parade or procession is otherwise lawful and complies with the standards of this section, a written permit shall be issued, to be valid for a certain date to be named by the city within 30 days from the date of issuance. In addition, such permit shall designate a particular route to be followed by the paraders and marchers, and no other route shall be permitted. 
(b)  In deciding whether to issue a permit under the provisions of this section, the chief of police shall consider, in addition to all other considerations, the following: 
(1)  The number of persons to participate; 
(2)  The anticipated traffic conditions at the time and date proposed for the activity; 
(3)  The schedule of other similar activities for which permits may have been issued; 
(4)  The adequacy of adult supervision for any minor scheduled to participate; 
(5)  The availability of city personnel whose presence on duty may be required by the activity and by the necessity to protect the general public; 
(6)  The adequacy of public facilities in the location proposed for the activity to accommodate the proposed activity and the normal public use of public facilities in the proposed location; and 
(7)  A reasonable limitation on the nature of floats, vehicles, and animals which may be included in a parade. 
(Code 1990, § 10-1-6; Code 2005, § 98-133)  
Sec. 98-112. - Cleanup of litter and debris. 
(a)  The permit holder under this article shall be responsible for the cleanup of any litter or debris on public property caused by the parade. Such litter shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Any paper or other waste or debris left on the streets by floats or units of parade; or 
(2)  Any paper wrappings, flyers or other items discarded by members of the public after being received from participants in the parade. 
(b)  Failure to clean up litter or debris following a parade, as specified in subsection (a) of this section shall constitute a violation of this Code, and shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided in section 1-7. 
(c)  Permit holders may, at the time of obtaining a permit, pay an additional cleanup fee in such amount as fixed from time to time by the mayor and city council. Payment of such cleanup fee shall relieve the permit holder of responsibility for cleaning of public property as required by subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1990, § 10-1-7; Code 2005, § 98-134)  
Secs. 98-113—98-137. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - COMMUNITY TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 98-138. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "Tallapoosa Community Transportation Vehicle Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1 (98-140), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-139. - Findings and intent. 
The ordinance from which this article is derived is adopted to address the interest of public safety. Motorized carts, personal transportation vehicles, electric personal assistive mobility devices and other similar vehicles are not designed or manufactured to be used on public highways, streets and roads, (hereafter "public roads") and the city in no way advocates their operation on the public roads within its jurisdiction. Adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived is not to be relied upon as a determination by the city that operation of motorized carts, personal transportation vehicles, electric personal assistive mobility devices, low-speed vehicles, and other similar vehicles on public roads is safe or advisable if done in accordance with this article. By regulating such operation, the city is merely addressing safety issues. All persons who operate or ride in motorized carts, personal transportation vehicles, electric personal assistive mobility devices, low-speed vehicles, and other similar vehicles on public roads do so with their own judgment and at their own risk, and must be observant of, and attentive to the safety of themselves and others, including their passengers, other motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians. Notwithstanding any law to the contrary, the city has no liability in negligence, nuisance or under any other cause of action for losses resulting from the use of motorized carts, personal transportation vehicles, electric personal assistive mobility devices, low-speed vehicles, and other similar vehicles on roads, sidewalks, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property under this article. Any person who operates motorized carts, personal transportation vehicles, electric personal assistive mobility devices, low-speed vehicles, and other similar vehicles is responsible for procuring appropriate insurance as may be required by any state law or this chapter as a condition of operating motorized carts, personal transportation vehicles, electric personal assistive mobility devices, low-speed vehicles, and other similar vehicles on the roads of the city. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1 (98-141), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-140. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
All-terrain vehicle means any motorized vehicle designed for off-road use which is equipped with three or more low-pressure tires and with a seat to be straddled by the operator and with handlebars for steering control. 
Bicycle means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having only two wheels which are in tandem and either of which is more than 13 inches in diameter. 
Dealer means a person engaged in the business of buying, selling, or exchanging vehicles who has an established place of business in the state. 
Electric personal assistive mobility device (EPAMD) means a self-balancing, two-non-tandem-wheeled device designed to transport only one person and having an electric propulsion system with average power of 750 watts (one horsepower) and a maximum speed of less than 20 miles per hour on a paved level surface when powered solely by such propulsion system and ridden by an operator who weighs 170 pounds. 
Gross weight means the unladen weight of the vehicle plus the weight of any load thereon. 
Low-speed vehicle (LSV) means any four-wheeled electric vehicle whose top speed attainable in one mile is greater than 20 miles per hour but not greater than 25 miles per hour on a paved level surface and which is manufactured in compliance with those federal motor vehicle safety standards for low-speed vehicles set forth in 49 CFR 571.500 and in effect on January 1, 2001. 
Moped means a motor-driven cycle equipped with two or three wheels, with or without foot pedals to permit muscular propulsion, and an independent power source providing a maximum of two-brake horsepower. If a combustion engine is used, the maximum piston or rotor displacement shall be 3.05 cubic inches (50 cubic centimeters) regardless of the number of chambers in such power source. The power source shall be capable of propelling the vehicle, unassisted, at a speed not to exceed 30 miles per hour (48.28 kilometers per hour) on level road surface and shall be equipped with a power drive system that functions directly or automatically only, not requiring clutching or shifting by the operator after the drive system is engaged. 
Motorized cart means every motor vehicle having no less than three wheels and an unladen weight on 1,300 pounds or less and which cannot operate at more than 20 miles per hour. 
Motor vehicle shall have the same definition as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1(33). 
Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
Personal transportation vehicle means any motor vehicle with a minimum of four wheels, capable of a maximum level ground speed of less than 20 miles per hour with a maximum gross vehicle unladen or empty weight of 1,375 pounds and capable of transporting not more than eight persons. The term "personal transportation vehicle" does not include mobility aids, including power wheelchairs and scooters, which can be used indoors and outdoors for the express purpose of enabling mobility for a person with a disability. The term "personal transportation vehicle" also does not include any all-terrain vehicle. 
Public road means the entire width between the boundary lines of every right-of-way or place open to the use of the public for the purposes of vehicular travel within the boundaries of the city, including streets and alleys. 
Recreation path means a right-of-way adjacent to motor vehicle travel lanes or other portion of public property of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a railway, and the adjacent property lines, or in any other designated public right-of-way or public property designated by signs for shared use by motorized carts, personal transportation vehicles, EPAMD vehicles, bicycles, and pedestrians. Such paths may be designated by resolution of the city council. 
Sidewalk means that portion of public property of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a railway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for use only by pedestrians. 
Unladen weight means the weight of a vehicle without load as per the manufacturer's specifications for such vehicle. 
Valid motor vehicle driver license means any current and valid certificate issued by this state, other state of the United States of America, or an international agency which permits persons to operate motor vehicles on the public roads of the state. 
Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, excepting devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-142), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-141. - Nomenclature. 
Any personal transportation vehicle, as defined by this chapter, which also qualifies as a motorized cart, as defined by this article, shall only be considered a motorized cart under this article and be subject only to the requirements, including registration, equipment, and inspections for motorized carts under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-143), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-142. - Motorized cart registration. 
(a)  A fee of $15.00 (not to exceed $15.00 per O.C.G.A. § 40-6-331(b)) to register each and every motorized cart for use on public roads will be charged by the city to cover the costs of implementing and maintaining this article. It shall be the duty of every owner of a motorized cart that is operated on public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property in the jurisdiction of the city to register the motorized cart with the city within ten business days of the date of purchase. Notwithstanding, all carts must be registered prior to use on public roads, sidewalks or recreation paths. Any transfer of ownership shall require the cart to be re-registered by the new owner. 
(b)  Registration with the city shall include a record of the model, make, any vehicle identification number or serial number on such motorized cart, the name and address of the owner, a contact phone number, and any other such information as the city shall require, all of which shall be maintained by the police department of the city. 
(c)  Upon registration with the city, each motorized cart shall be issued a license decal from the city signifying such registration. The decals must be affixed to the driver's side of the motorized cart in such a manner as to be visible at all times and shall remain permanently with such motorized cart unless the motorized cart is sold or the license is destroyed. 
(d)  The failure to have a current registration license decal affixed to a motorized cart for use on public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property in the city shall be a violation of this article and subject the owner of such motorized cart to the penalties set forth in section 1-7. 
(e)  If the motorized cart for use on public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property is not registered with the city within ten business days of purchase it shall be considered an unregistered motorized cart and subject the owner of such motorized cart to penalties set forth in section 1-7. 
(f)  The decal issued by the city shall be nontransferable from the motorized cart for which is it was obtained. All decals must be placed on the front window on the driver's side; at the lowest corner of the windshield on the drivers side. 
(g)  Upon transfer of the motorized cart to the ownership of another person, the registration must be transferred to the new owner within ten business days of the change in ownership at a cost of $15.00. If the registration is not transferred within ten business days it shall be considered an unregistered motorized cart and subject the owner of such motorized cart to penalties set forth in section 1-7. 
(h)  Motorized cart dealers and distributors, along with other commercial establishments, may rent motorized carts to the public for use on designated public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property. Each such establishment renting motorized carts shall be required to register each such motorized cart in accordance with this section and shall maintain a written record of each person who rents each cart. Renters shall be required to furnish positive identification, shall be provided a copy of this article to read, and must be at least 16 years of age. The registration fee and transfer fees and regulations, along with all licensing and operation regulations, shall be consistent with the provisions of this article as pertains to motorized carts. 
(i)  Only those persons 16 years of age and older may register a motorized cart. Motorized cart registration may be in one person's name only, and the registration form must be signed by that person. 
(j)  Any owner or operator registering a motorized cart with the city agrees to abide by all of the requirements of state law and this Code. By registering a motorized cart with the city, the owner or operator verifies that the vehicle qualifies to be classified as such under state law and this Code. 
(k)  The city council may, at its discretion, and by resolution, waive registration requirements for special events of a limited duration to which out-of-city residents may bring motorized carts as participants. Such special events shall last no longer than seven calendar days. 
(l)  Annual registration of motorized cart required. Once a motorized cart is registered with the city police department, the motorized cart registration must be renewed annually prior to the expiration of the month of January. The motorized cart owner is required to provide proof of required liability insurance coverage. There is no fee for renewal. The fee may be adjusted by the mayor and council by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-144), 3-10-2014; Ord. No. 01282, exh. 2014-B(98-144), 6-9-2014)  
Sec. 98-143. - Motorized cart equipment and inspections. 
(a)  All motorized carts shall have a braking system sufficient for the weight and passenger capacity of the vehicle including a parking brake, a reverse warning device functional at all times when the directional control is in the reverse position, a main power switch which shall render the power circuit inoperative when the switch is in the off position or the key or other activating device is removed, such key or other activating device only being removable in the off position, head lamps, reflex reflectors and directional signals (blinkers), tail lamps, a horn, a rearview mirror, safety warning labels, hip restraints (seat belt) and hand holds. 
(b)  All personal transportation vehicles which do not also qualify as motorized carts shall comply with all applicable provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 40, ch. 8, art. 1. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-145), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-144. - Motorized cart operation regulations. 
(a)  Motorized carts may only be driven on designated public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property of the city. 
(1)  The designated public roads shall include all public roads within the jurisdiction of the city which have a speed limit of 30 miles per hour or less or on other public roads as the mayor and city council shall approve, except for Arbacoochee Road, Broad Street, Commerce Place, GA 100 (portions of Bowdon Street (all) and Robertson Avenue between US 78 and Taliaferro Street), GA 120, Hilltop Drive, Honda Parkway, Pequanoc Drive, Stoffel Drive, US 78; and as the mayor and city council shall deem inappropriate for use a designated public road for use by motorized carts. 
(2)  Designated recreation paths only includes recreation paths which are designed to accommodate motorized carts where a sign has been posted advising that motorized carts are allowed. 
(3)  Designated rights-of-way or other public property includes all public rights-of-way and public property of the city except public property excluded by this article, by this subsection, or by state law, and does not include the following: Arbacoochee Road, Broad Street, Commerce Place, GA 100 (portions of Bowdon Street (all) and Robertson Avenue between US 78 and Taliaferro Street), GA 120, Hilltop Drive, Honda Parkway, Pequanoc Drive, Stoffel Drive, US 78. 
(b)  Motorized carts shall not be operated on sidewalks at any time. 
(c)  No person shall operate a motorized cart on a public road of the city unless that road is designated for motorized cart use by this article. The following streets are designated as being authorized to permit motorized cart use: Please review section 98-153 for a current list of designated streets. 
(d)  No motorized cart may cross any street, road or highway which is part of the state highway system unless such crossing is made at a crossing or intersection designated for that purpose by the department of transportation. Please review section 98-154 for a list of current authorized street intersection crossings. 
(e)  Motorized carts may cross streets, roads and highways which are part of the city street system and used by other types of vehicles only at crossings or intersections designated for that purpose by the city. The city council may designate such crossings or intersections from time to time by resolution. 
(f)  Motorized carts may only be operated on public roads, recreational paths, rights-of-way or other public property which are part of the city street system during daylight hours. 
(g)  Motorized cart owners shall maintain their motorized carts in a manner which ensures that an unobstructed view from the driver's seat to the rear is maintained at all times the motorized cart is in operation on public roads. 
(h)  The maximum occupancy of a motorized cart traveling on public roads, sidewalks, paths, rights-of-way or other public property shall be one person per designated seat which is equipped with a hip restraint (seat belt). 
(i)  All operators of motorized carts shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the designated public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property of the city. Where recreation paths exist for motorized carts, they must be used in preference to parallel roads with the exclusion of privately held paths. 
(j)  The operator and all occupants of a motorized cart or other vehicle shall comply with all traffic rules and regulations adopted by the state (O.C.G.A. tit. 40) and the city (this chapter) which govern the operation of motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-146), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-145. - Gasoline-powered motorized carts. 
(a)  Every gasoline-powered motorized cart and personal transportation vehicle shall, at all times, be equipped with an exhaust system in good working order and in constant operation, meeting the following specifications: 
(1)  The exhaust system shall include the piping leading from the flange of the exhaust manifold to and including the muffler and exhaust pipes or include any and all parts specified by the manufacturer. 
(2)  The exhaust system on its own shall be securely fastened, including the consideration of missing or broken brackets or hangers. 
(3)  The engine and power mechanism of every gasoline-powered motorized cart or personal transportation vehicle shall be so equipped, adjusted, and tuned so as to prevent the escape of excessive smoke or fumes. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any gasoline-powered motorized cart or personal transportation vehicle to operate or permit the operation of such gasoline-powered motorized cart or personal transportation vehicle on which any device controlling or abating atmospheric conditions, which is placed on the gasoline-powered motorized cart or personal transportation vehicle by the manufacturer, to render the device unserviceable by removal, alteration, or other interference with its operation. 
(c)  All gasoline-powered motorized carts or personal transportation vehicles shall be maintained in working order and kept in good condition and shall be subject to inspection by city officials at reasonable times and intervals. 
(d)  All gasoline-powered motorized carts or personal transportation vehicles shall be maintained in such condition so that they are incapable of backfiring, or otherwise operating so as to make loud noises; or create noise as a result of an operators equipping the gasoline-powered motorized cart or personal transportation vehicle with a certain device. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-147), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-146. - Motorized cart operator licensing regulations. 
(a)  Those persons possessing a valid motor vehicle driver license issued by this state, other states of the United States of America, or an international agency which permits such person to operate a motor vehicle on the highways of the state may operate and drive a motorized cart on designated public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other permitted public property of the city. 
(b)  No person under the age of 16 years shall be permitted to operate a motorized cart on designated public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-148), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-147. - Personal transportation and low-speed vehicle operator licensing regulations. 
Only those persons possessing a valid motor vehicle driver license issued by this state, other states of the United States of America, or an international agency which permits such person to operate a motor vehicle on the public roads of the state may operate a personal transportation vehicle which does not also qualify as a motorized cart or low-speed vehicle on the public roads within the territorial boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-149), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-148. - Recreation path users—Authorized. 
Authorized users of recreation paths are as follows: 
(1)  Pedestrians; 
(2)  Non-motorized vehicles; 
(3)  Roller skates, roller blades, non-powered scooters and skateboarders (daylight only); 
(4)  Registered motorized carts, provided that the vehicle is operated at a speed not to exceed 15 miles per hour and only on designated recreation paths; 
(5)  Emergency and authorized maintenance vehicles; 
(6)  Bicycles; 
(7)  Wheelchairs; 
(8)  Registered low-speed vehicles, provided that the vehicle is operated at a speed not to exceed 15 miles per hour and only on designated recreation paths; and 
(9)  Registered personal transportation vehicles, provided that the vehicle is operated at a speed not to exceed 15 miles per hour and only on designated recreation paths. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-150), 3-10-2014) 
Editor's note— As of February 2014, there are no recreation paths within the city limits.  
Sec. 98-149. - Recreation path users—Prohibited. 
Prohibited users of recreation paths are as follows: 
(1)  Automobiles and trucks (except authorized emergency and maintenance vehicles); 
(2)  Motorcycles; 
(3)  Motorized bicycles; 
(4)  Mopeds; 
(5)  Horses; 
(6)  Go-carts; 
(7)  Unregistered motorized carts; 
(8)  Unregistered personal transportation vehicles; 
(9)  Motorized scooters; 
(10)  Unregistered low-speed vehicles; and 
(11)  All-terrain vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-151), 3-10-2014) 
Editor's note— As of February 2014, there are no recreation paths within the city limits.  
Sec. 98-150. - Insurance. 
(a)  The owner or operator of a motorized cart is liable for his own actions. Any person who operates or owns a motorized cart is responsible for procuring liability insurance and verifying coverage in terms enough to cover risk involved in using such motorized cart on designated public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way or other public property of the city. The policy limits of said liability insurance shall be not less than $25,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of one person in any one accident, subject to such limit for one person, $50,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident, and $25,000.00 because of injury to or destruction of property. 
(b)  The owner or operator of a motorized cart shall keep proof or evidence of required minimum insurance coverage in the cart at all times during the operation of the cart. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-152), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-151. - Hazardous activities and special rules. 
No individual or group shall engage in hazardous activities. Such hazardous activities include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Racing of any kind. 
(2)  Blocking of public access and preventing unfettered vehicle progress on public streets. 
(3)  Vehicles shall not loiter or park on roads, bridges or in underpasses. 
(4)  Pedestrians should be provided complete right-of-way preference when encountered; if necessary the golf cart must come to a complete stop to allow pedestrians and stray dogs or cats, or wandering wildlife, the opportunity to cross the public right-of-way unmolested or without harassment, to ensure their safe passage. 
(5)  A reasonable audible warning shall be given by operators of motorized carts when approaching pedestrians from the rear. An audible warning device that is arbitrarily loud or abhorrent is not permitted under this article. 
(6)  All laws and ordinances relative to alcohol and the use thereof, including, but not limited to, open container laws, apply to the operator and occupants of motorized carts. 
(7)  Exceeding the manufactured specified occupancy rating. The number of occupants in the motorized cart shall be limited to the number specified by the manufacture of the cart and shall not exceed said occupancy. 
(8)  Horseplay shall not be allowed. All occupants must remain seated at all times that the vehicle is in motion. The cart shall be driven in a straight line where possible without any unnecessary weaving, movement or change of speeds. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-153), 3-10-2014)  
Sec. 98-152. - Penalties. 
A violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a violation of this Code, and if applicable, a violation of the laws of the state. An owner, lessee or operator may be cited to appear in the municipal court or any other court having legal jurisdiction. Upon finding by such court that an owner, lessee, or operator of a motorized cart has violated any provision of this article, such person shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $250.00 for each offense, along with court costs. 
(1)  In the event a third offense is committed within any 24-month period, the registered owner's motorized cart city registration shall be revoked. The registered owner cannot thereafter register a motorized cart for use in the city for a period of two years following the third conviction. Additionally, such person shall be prohibited from operating a motorized cart or on the public roads, recreation paths, rights-of-way, or other public property for a period of two years. 
(2)  Any violation by an operator of a low-speed vehicle shall be charged against the operator according to the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 40 and this Code. Any violation by an owner of a low-speed vehicle shall be charged against the owner according to the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 40 and this Code. 
(3)  Any violation by and operator of a personal transportation vehicle, EPAMD, or other motor vehicle may be charged against the operator according to this Code or according to the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 40. 
(4)  All violations of O.C.G.A. tit. 40 may be subject to penalties and fines as established under state law. 
(Ord. No. 01281, § 1(98-154), 3-10-2014)
